text: BUT BY AND BY THEY CAME TO MY WATCH WHICH I HAD HIDDEN AWAY IN THE INMOST POCKET THAT I HAD AND HAD FORGOTTEN WHEN THEY BEGAN THEIR SEARCH
whisper_text: But by and by they came to my watch, which I had hidden away in the inn most pocket that I had and had forgotten when they began their search.

text: THIS HAD SOME EFFECT IN CALMING HIM
whisper_text: This had some effect in calming him.

text: SUFFICE IT THAT I FOUND MYSELF TAKEN BEFORE THE CHIEF MAGISTRATE AND BY HIS ORDERS WAS PLACED IN AN APARTMENT WITH TWO OTHER PEOPLE WHO WERE THE FIRST I HAD SEEN LOOKING ANYTHING BUT WELL AND HANDSOME
whisper_text: Suffice it that I found myself taken before the chief magistrate, and by his orders was placed in an apartment with two other people. Who were the first I had seen looking anything but well in handsome.

text: THE VINE GREW OUTSIDE MANY OF THE HOUSES AND THERE WERE SOME WITH SIGN BOARDS ON WHICH WAS PAINTED A BOTTLE AND A GLASS THAT MADE ME FEEL MUCH AT HOME
whisper_text: The vine grew outside many of the houses and there were some with signboards on which was painted a bottle and a glass that made me feel much at home

text: THE STREETS WERE NARROW AND UNPAVED BUT VERY FAIRLY CLEAN
whisper_text: The streets were narrow and unpaid but very fairly clean.

text: IN ABOUT FOUR HOURS OF WALKING FROM THE TIME WE STARTED AND AFTER PASSING TWO OR THREE MORE VILLAGES WE CAME UPON A CONSIDERABLE TOWN AND MY GUIDES MADE MANY ATTEMPTS TO MAKE ME UNDERSTAND SOMETHING BUT I GATHERED NO INKLING OF THEIR MEANING EXCEPT THAT I NEED BE UNDER NO APPREHENSION OF DANGER
whisper_text: In about four hours of walking from the time we started and after passing two or three more villages, we came upon a considerable town and my guides made many attempts to make me understand something. But I gathered no inkling of their meaning, except that I need be under no apprehension of danger.

text: THE DESIGN WAS DIFFERENT BUT THE THING WAS CLEARLY THE SAME
whisper_text: The design was different, but the thing was clearly the same.

text: THEY FELT MY PULSE THEY LOOKED AT MY TONGUE THEY LISTENED AT MY CHEST THEY FELT ALL MY MUSCLES AND AT THE END OF EACH OPERATION THEY LOOKED AT THE CHIEF AND NODDED AND SAID SOMETHING IN A TONE QUITE PLEASANT AS THOUGH I WERE ALL RIGHT
whisper_text: They felt my pulse, they looked at my tongue, they listened at my chest, they felt all my muscles, and at the end of each operation they looked at the chief and nodded. And said something in a tone quite pleasant as though I were alright.

text: I SAW A FEW SHEEP WITH ROUNDED NOSES AND ENORMOUS TAILS
whisper_text: I saw a few sheep with rounded noses and enormous tails.

text: EACH FEATURE WAS FINISHED EYELIDS EYELASHES AND EARS BEING ALMOST INVARIABLY PERFECT
whisper_text: Each feature was finished, eyelids, eyelashes and ears being almost invariably perfect.

text: I HAVE ALWAYS DELIGHTED IN AND REVERENCED BEAUTY BUT I FELT SIMPLY ABASHED IN THE PRESENCE OF SUCH A SPLENDID TYPE A COMPOUND OF ALL THAT IS BEST IN EGYPTIAN GREEK AND ITALIAN
whisper_text: I have always delighted in and reverenced beauty, but I felt simply abashed in the presence of such a splendid type, a compound of all that is best in Egyptian Greek and Italian.

text: HE BEGAN PRESENTLY TO RELENT AND SPOKE TO ME IN A KINDER MANNER
whisper_text: He began presently to relent and spoke to me in a kinder manner.

text: THE MEN WERE AS HANDSOME AS THE WOMEN BEAUTIFUL
whisper_text: The man wears handsome as the women beautiful.

text: EVEN ON THIS LEDGE OF HUMAN SOCIETY THERE WAS A STUNTED GROWTH OF SHOPLETS WHICH HAD TAKEN ROOT AND VEGETATED SOMEHOW THOUGH AS IN AN AIR MERCANTILE OF THE BLEAKEST
whisper_text: Even on this ledge of human society there was a stunted growth of shoplets, which had taken and vegetated somehow, though as in an air-American tile of the bleakest.

text: THE COUNTRY WAS HIGHLY CULTIVATED EVERY LEDGE BEING PLANTED WITH CHESTNUTS WALNUTS AND APPLE TREES FROM WHICH THE APPLES WERE NOW GATHERING
whisper_text: The country was highly cultivated every ledge being planted with chestnuts, walnuts, and apple trees from which the apples were now gathering.

text: EVEN IN MIDDLE AGE THEY WERE STILL COMELY AND THE OLD GREY HAIRED WOMEN AT THEIR COTTAGE DOORS HAD A DIGNITY NOT TO SAY MAJESTY OF THEIR OWN
whisper_text: Even in middle age they were still cumbly, and the old great-haired women at their cottage doors had a dignity, not to say majesty of their own.

text: I EXPRESSED BY SIGNS MY ADMIRATION AND PLEASURE TO MY GUIDES AND THEY WERE GREATLY PLEASED
whisper_text: I expressed by signs my admiration and pleasure to my guides, and they were greatly pleased.

text: THE CHILDREN WERE INFINITE IN NUMBER AND EXCEEDINGLY MERRY I NEED HARDLY SAY THAT THEY CAME IN FOR THEIR FULL SHARE OF THE PREVAILING BEAUTY
whisper_text: The children were infinite in number and exceedingly merry. I need hardly say that they came in for their full share of the prevailing beauty

text: THEIR EXPRESSION WAS DIVINE AND AS THEY GLANCED AT ME TIMIDLY BUT WITH PARTED LIPS IN GREAT BEWILDERMENT I FORGOT ALL THOUGHTS OF THEIR CONVERSION IN FEELINGS THAT WERE FAR MORE EARTHLY
whisper_text: Their expression was divine, and as they glanced at me timidly but with parted lips and great bewilderment, I forgot all thoughts of their conversion and feelings that were far more earthly.

text: WE PASSED MANY CASES AND AT LAST CAME TO ONE IN WHICH THERE WERE SEVERAL CLOCKS AND TWO OR THREE OLD WATCHES
whisper_text: We passed many cases and it last came to one in which there were several clocks and two or three old watches.

text: MY GUIDES HOWEVER WERE WELL KNOWN AND THE NATURAL POLITENESS OF THE PEOPLE PREVENTED THEM FROM PUTTING ME TO ANY INCONVENIENCE BUT THEY COULD NOT HELP EYEING ME NOR I THEM
whisper_text: My guides, however, were well known, and the natural politeness of the people prevented them from putting me to any inconvenience. But they could not help eyeing me nor eye them.

text: THE OTHER LOOKED PALE AND ILL BUT HE WAS MARVELLOUSLY SELF CONTAINED AND IT WAS IMPOSSIBLE TO SAY WHAT WAS THE MATTER WITH HIM
whisper_text: The other looked pale and ill, but he was marvelously self-contained, and it was impossible to say what was the matter with him.

text: IN FACT ONE OF THEM WAS PLAINLY VERY MUCH OUT OF HEALTH AND COUGHED VIOLENTLY FROM TIME TO TIME IN SPITE OF MANIFEST EFFORTS TO SUPPRESS IT
whisper_text: In fact, one of them was plainly very much out of health, and coughed violently from time to time in spite of manifest efforts to suppress it.

text: SHORTLY AFTER PASSING ONE OF THESE CHAPELS WE CAME SUDDENLY UPON A VILLAGE WHICH STARTED UP OUT OF THE MIST AND I WAS ALARMED LEST I SHOULD BE MADE AN OBJECT OF CURIOSITY OR DISLIKE
whisper_text: Shortly after passing one of these chapels we came suddenly upon a village which started up out of the mist, and I was alarmed lest I should be made an object of curiosity or dislike.

text: AGAIN THERE WAS A VERY OLD CARRIAGE WHOSE WHEELS IN SPITE OF RUST AND DECAY I COULD SEE HAD BEEN DESIGNED ORIGINALLY FOR IRON RAILS
whisper_text: Again, there was a very old carriage whose wheels, in spite of rest and decay, I could see, had been designed originally for iron rails.

text: IT WAS WRITTEN IN THE UPPER RANGITATA DISTRICT OF THE CANTERBURY PROVINCE AS IT THEN WAS OF NEW ZEALAND AND APPEARED AT CHRISTCHURCH IN THE PRESS NEWSPAPER JUNE THIRTEENTH EIGHTEEN SIXTY THREE
whisper_text: It was written in the Upper Rangatata District of the Canabary Province as it then was of New Zealand, an appeared at Christchurch in the Press newspaper, June 13, 1863.

text: I REGRET THAT REVIEWERS HAVE IN SOME CASES BEEN INCLINED TO TREAT THE CHAPTERS ON MACHINES AS AN ATTEMPT TO REDUCE MISTER DARWIN'S THEORY TO AN ABSURDITY
whisper_text: I regret that reviewers have in some cases been inclined to treat the chapters on machines as an attempt to reduce Mr. Darwin's theory to an absurdity.

text: THERE WAS ALSO ANOTHER CAUSE
whisper_text: There was also another cause.

text: THE FIRST EDITION OF EREWHON SOLD IN ABOUT THREE WEEKS I HAD NOT TAKEN MOULDS AND AS THE DEMAND WAS STRONG IT WAS SET UP AGAIN IMMEDIATELY
whisper_text: The first edition of Iruon sold in about three weeks. I had not taken molds and as the demand was strong it was set up again immediately.

text: I AM SURPRISED HOWEVER THAT THE BOOK AT WHICH SUCH AN EXAMPLE OF THE SPECIOUS MISUSE OF ANALOGY WOULD SEEM MOST NATURALLY LEVELLED SHOULD HAVE OCCURRED TO NO REVIEWER NEITHER SHALL I MENTION THE NAME OF THE BOOK HERE THOUGH I SHOULD FANCY THAT THE HINT GIVEN WILL SUFFICE
whisper_text: I am surprised, however, that the book at which such an example of the species misuse of analogy would seem most naturally leveled should have occurred to no reviewer, neither shall I mention the name of the book here, though I should fancy that the hint given will suffice.

text: I ALSO WROTE ABOUT THIS TIME THE SUBSTANCE OF WHAT ULTIMATELY BECAME THE MUSICAL BANKS AND THE TRIAL OF A MAN FOR BEING IN A CONSUMPTION
whisper_text: I also wrote about this time the substance of what ultimately became the musical banks, and the trial of a man for being in a consumption.

text: ON MY RETURN I PURPOSELY AVOIDED LOOKING INTO IT UNTIL I HAD SENT BACK MY LAST REVISES TO THE PRINTER
whisper_text: On my return, I purposely avoided looking into it until I had sent back my last revises to the printer.

text: I MADE A FEW FURTHER VERY TRIFLING ALTERATIONS BEFORE MOULDS WERE TAKEN BUT SINCE THE SUMMER OF EIGHTEEN SEVENTY TWO AS NEW EDITIONS WERE FROM TIME TO TIME WANTED THEY HAVE BEEN PRINTED FROM STEREOS THEN MADE
whisper_text: I made a few further very trifling alterations before molds were taken, but since the summer of 1872. As new additions were from time to time wanted, they had been printed from stereos then made.

text: I AM STILL FAIRLY WELL SATISFIED WITH THOSE PARTS OF EREWHON THAT WERE REPEATEDLY REWRITTEN BUT FROM THOSE THAT HAD ONLY A SINGLE WRITING I WOULD GLADLY CUT OUT SOME FORTY OR FIFTY PAGES IF I COULD
whisper_text: I am still fairly well satisfied with those parts of Ero-1 that were repeatedly rewritten, but from those that had only a single writing, I would gladly cut out some 40 or 50 pages if I could.

text: THEN I HAD MUCH PLEASURE IN READING IT BUT WAS INDEED SURPRISED AT THE MANY LITTLE POINTS OF SIMILARITY BETWEEN THE TWO BOOKS IN SPITE OF THEIR ENTIRE INDEPENDENCE TO ONE ANOTHER
whisper_text: Then I had much pleasure in reading it, but was indeed surprised that the many little points of similarity between the two books, in spite of their entire independence to one another.

text: THIS HOWEVER MAY NOT BE FOR THE COPYRIGHT WILL PROBABLY EXPIRE IN A LITTLE OVER TWELVE YEARS
whisper_text: This, however, may not be for the copyright will probably expire in a little over 12 years.

text: PREFACE TO SECOND EDITION
whisper_text: Preface to the second edition.

text: THIS IS A MISTAKE THOUGH A PERFECTLY NATURAL ONE
whisper_text: This is a mistake though a perfectly natural one.

text: I SEE FROM MY SECOND PREFACE THAT I TOOK THE BOOK TO MESSRS CHAPMAN AND HALL MAY FIRST EIGHTEEN SEVENTY ONE AND ON THEIR REJECTION OF IT UNDER THE ADVICE OF ONE WHO HAS ATTAINED THE HIGHEST RANK AMONG LIVING WRITERS I LET IT SLEEP TILL I TOOK IT TO MISTER TRUBNER EARLY IN EIGHTEEN SEVENTY TWO
whisper_text: I see for my second preface that I took the book to Miss Eur's Chapman and Hall, May 1, 1871, and on their rejection of it under the advice of one who has attained the highest rank among living writers, I let it sleep till I took it to Mr. Trubner early in 1872.

text: BUT THIS HAD AN EFFECT OF WHICH I HAVE LITTLE REASON TO COMPLAIN FOR I WAS ALLOWED ALMOST TO CALL THEM LIFE LONG SELF DECEIVERS TO THEIR FACES AND THEY SAID IT WAS QUITE TRUE BUT THAT IT DID NOT MATTER
whisper_text: But this had an effect of which I have little reason to complain for I was allowed almost to call them lifelong self-dosevers to their faces, and they said it was quite true, but that it did not matter.

text: I MUST NOT CONCLUDE WITHOUT EXPRESSING MY MOST SINCERE THANKS TO MY CRITICS AND TO THE PUBLIC FOR THE LENIENCY AND CONSIDERATION WITH WHICH THEY HAVE TREATED MY ADVENTURES
whisper_text: I must not conclude without expressing my most sincere thanks to my critics and to the public for the leniency and consideration with which they have treated my adventures.

text: I ATTRIBUTE ITS UNLOOKED FOR SUCCESS MAINLY TO TWO EARLY FAVOURABLE REVIEWS THE FIRST IN THE PALL MALL GAZETTE OF APRIL TWELFTH AND THE SECOND IN THE SPECTATOR OF APRIL TWENTIETH
whisper_text: I attribute its unlooked for success mainly to two early favorable reviews. The first in the Palmol Gazette of April 12th, and the second in the spectator of April 20th.

text: IF THE READER WILL EXCUSE ME I WILL SAY NOTHING OF MY ANTECEDENTS NOR OF THE CIRCUMSTANCES WHICH LED ME TO LEAVE MY NATIVE COUNTRY THE NARRATIVE WOULD BE TEDIOUS TO HIM AND PAINFUL TO MYSELF
whisper_text: If the reader will excuse me, I will say nothing of my antecedents, nor of the circumstances which led me to leave my native country. The narrative would be tedious to him and painful to myself.

text: IT WILL BE SEEN THAT I DID NOT SUCCEED IN MY DESIGN AND THAT HOWEVER MUCH I MAY HAVE MET WITH THAT WAS NEW AND STRANGE I HAVE BEEN UNABLE TO REAP ANY PECUNIARY ADVANTAGE
whisper_text: It will be seen that I did not succeed in my design, and that however much I may have met with that was new and strange, I have been unable to reap any pecuniary advantage.

text: THE COUNTRY WAS THE GRANDEST THAT CAN BE IMAGINED
whisper_text: The country was the grandest that can be imagined.

text: I WAS TO SEE THE SHEEP NOT NECESSARILY CLOSE AT HAND NOR TO GET THEM IN A SINGLE MOB BUT TO SEE ENOUGH OF THEM HERE AND THERE TO FEEL EASY THAT NOTHING HAD GONE WRONG THIS WAS NO DIFFICULT MATTER FOR THERE WERE NOT ABOVE EIGHT HUNDRED OF THEM AND BEING ALL BREEDING EWES THEY WERE PRETTY QUIET
whisper_text: I was to see the sheep not necessarily close at hand, or to get them in a single mob, but to see enough of them here and there to feel easy that nothing had gone wrong. This was no difficult matter, for there were not above 800 of them, and being all breeding used they were pretty quiet.

text: THERE WERE A GOOD MANY SHEEP WHICH I KNEW AS TWO OR THREE BLACK EWES AND A BLACK LAMB OR TWO AND SEVERAL OTHERS WHICH HAD SOME DISTINGUISHING MARK WHEREBY I COULD TELL THEM
whisper_text: There were good many sheep which I knew as two or three black use and a black lamb or two, and several others which had some distinguishing mark whereby I could tell them.

text: SO LONELY AND SO SOLEMN WITH THE SAD GREY CLOUDS ABOVE AND NO SOUND SAVE A LOST LAMB BLEATING UPON THE MOUNTAIN SIDE AS THOUGH ITS LITTLE HEART WERE BREAKING
whisper_text: So lonely and so solemn, with the sad grey clouds above, and no sound save a lost lamb bleeding upon them outside, as though it's a little heart we're breaking.

text: SHEEP AND CATTLE WERE INTRODUCED AND BRED WITH EXTREME RAPIDITY MEN TOOK UP THEIR FIFTY THOUSAND OR ONE HUNDRED THOUSAND ACRES OF COUNTRY GOING INLAND ONE BEHIND THE OTHER TILL IN A FEW YEARS THERE WAS NOT AN ACRE BETWEEN THE SEA AND THE FRONT RANGES WHICH WAS NOT TAKEN UP AND STATIONS EITHER FOR SHEEP OR CATTLE WERE SPOTTED ABOUT AT INTERVALS OF SOME TWENTY OR THIRTY MILES OVER THE WHOLE COUNTRY
whisper_text: Sheep and cattle were introduced and bred with extreme rapidity. Men took up their 50,000 or 100,000 acres of country, going inland one behind the other. Till in a few years there was not an acre between the sea and the front ranges which was not taken up. And stations either for sheep or cattle were spotted, about an intervals of some 20 or 30 miles over the whole country.

text: EACH MUST CRY LOUDER AND WANDER FARTHER YET MAY LUCK BE WITH THEM BOTH THAT THEY MAY FIND THEIR OWN AT NIGHTFALL
whisper_text: Each must cry louder and wander farther yet, may luck be with them both that they may find their own at nightfall.

text: IT IS SURPRISING HOW SOON THE EYE BECOMES ACCUSTOMED TO MISSING TWENTY SHEEP OUT OF TWO OR THREE HUNDRED
whisper_text: It is surprising how soon the eye becomes accustomed to missing 20 sheep out of 2 or 300.

text: IT WAS A MONOTONOUS LIFE BUT IT WAS VERY HEALTHY AND ONE DOES NOT MUCH MIND ANYTHING WHEN ONE IS WELL
whisper_text: It was a monotonous life, but it was very healthy, and one does not much mind anything one won as well.

text: I HAD NO MONEY BUT IF I COULD ONLY FIND WORKABLE COUNTRY I MIGHT STOCK IT WITH BORROWED CAPITAL AND CONSIDER MYSELF A MADE MAN
whisper_text: I had no money, but if I could only find workable country, I might stock it with borrowed capital, and consider myself a made man.

text: I WAS DELIGHTED WITH THE COUNTRY AND THE MANNER OF LIFE
whisper_text: I was delighted with the country and the manner of life.

text: NO ONE WHO IS HIMSELF HONEST WILL DOUBT MY BEING SO
whisper_text: No one who is himself honest will doubt my being so.

text: THERE WAS NO ONE IN THE WHOLE WORLD WHO HAD THE SMALLEST IDEA SAVE THOSE WHO WERE THEMSELVES ON THE OTHER SIDE OF IT IF INDEED THERE WAS ANY ONE AT ALL COULD I HOPE TO CROSS IT
whisper_text: There was no one in the whole world who had the smallest idea. Save those who were themselves on the other side of it. If indeed there was anyone at all, could I hope to cross it?

text: I WOULD TRY THE NEARER RANGE AND SEE HOW FAR I COULD GO
whisper_text: I would try the nearer range and see how far I could go.

text: I REACHED MY DESTINATION IN ONE OF THE LAST MONTHS OF EIGHTEEN SIXTY EIGHT BUT I DARE NOT MENTION THE SEASON LEST THE READER SHOULD GATHER IN WHICH HEMISPHERE I WAS
whisper_text: I reached my destination in one of the last months of 1868, but I dare not mention the season, lest the reader should gather in which hemisphere I was.

text: VICTORIA BUNS SEVENTEEN THIRTY TWO
whisper_text: Victoria Buns, 1732

text: MODE BOIL THE RICE IN WATER UNTIL IT IS QUITE TENDER POUR OFF THE WATER AND PUT THE RICE BEFORE IT IS COLD TO THE FLOUR
whisper_text: Mode. Boil the rice and water until it is quite tender. Pour off the water and put the rice before it is cold to the flower.

text: SEVENTEEN EIGHTEEN

THESE BUNS MAY BE VARIED BY ADDING A FEW CURRANTS CANDIED PEEL OR CARAWAY SEEDS TO THE OTHER INGREDIENTS AND THE ABOVE MIXTURE ANSWERS FOR HOT CROSS BUNS BY PUTTING IN A LITTLE GROUND ALLSPICE AND BY PRESSING A TIN MOULD IN THE FORM OF A CROSS IN THE CENTRE OF THE BUN
whisper_text: These buns may be varied by adding a few currents, Candied peel, or caraway seeds to the other ingredients, and the above mixture answers for hot cross buns by putting in a little ground all spice, and by pressing a tin mold in the form of a cross in the center of the bun.

text: SOME OF THE PREPARATIONS OF MAIZE FLOUR ARE VERY GOOD AND WHEN PARTAKEN IN MODERATION SUITABLE FOOD FOR ALMOST EVERYBODY
whisper_text: Some of the preparations of maize flour are very good, and when partaken in moderation, suitable food for almost everybody.

text: HOT ROLLS
whisper_text: Hot Rolls.

text: SUFFICIENT ALLOW TWO CRUMPETS TO EACH PERSON
whisper_text: sufficient, allow two crumpets to each person.

text: MUFFINS AND CRUMPETS SHOULD ALWAYS BE SERVED ON SEPARATE DISHES AND BOTH TOASTED AND SERVED AS EXPEDITIOUSLY AS POSSIBLE
whisper_text: muffins and crumpets should always be served on separate dishes and both toasted and served as expeditiously as possible.

text: EXCELLENT ROLLS
whisper_text: Excellent roles.

text: IF CARRIED ANY DISTANCE IT SHOULD BE STORED AWAY IN AIR TIGHT VESSELS
whisper_text: If carried any distance, it should be stored away in airtight vessels.

text: FROM FIFTEEN TO TWENTY MINUTES WILL BE REQUIRED TO BAKE THEM NICELY
whisper_text: From 15 to 20 minutes will be required to bake them nicely.

text: TO MAKE GOOD HOME MADE BREAD
whisper_text: to make good homemade bread.

text: ANOTHER ADVANTAGE THE RED WHEATS POSSESS IS THEIR COMPARATIVE IMMUNITY FROM THE ATTACKS OF MILDEW AND FLY
whisper_text: Another advantage the Redweets possess is their comparative immunity from the attacks of Mildu and Fly.

text: MODE WHISK THE EGG STIR IN THE SUGAR AND BEAT THESE INGREDIENTS WELL TOGETHER BEAT THE BUTTER TO A CREAM STIR IN THE GROUND RICE CURRANTS AND CANDIED PEEL AND AS MUCH FLOUR AS WILL MAKE IT OF SUCH A CONSISTENCY THAT IT MAY BE ROLLED INTO SEVEN OR EIGHT BALLS
whisper_text: Mode. Whisk the egg, stir in the sugar, and beat these ingredients well together. Beat the butter to a cream, stir in the ground rice, currents, and candied peel, and as much flour as will make it of such a consistency that it may be rolled into seven or eight balls.

text: SEVENTEEN THIRTY FOUR
ILLUSTRATION ITALIAN MILLET
whisper_text: Illustration Italian Millet.

text: WHEN THEY ARE QUITE HOT DIVIDE THEM LENGTHWISE INTO THREE PUT SOME THIN FLAKES OF GOOD BUTTER BETWEEN THE SLICES PRESS THE ROLLS TOGETHER AND PUT THEM IN THE OVEN FOR A MINUTE OR TWO BUT NOT LONGER OR THE BUTTER WOULD OIL TAKE THEM OUT OF THE OVEN SPREAD THE BUTTER EQUALLY OVER DIVIDE THE ROLLS IN HALF AND PUT THEM ON TO A VERY HOT CLEAN DISH AND SEND THEM INSTANTLY TO TABLE
whisper_text: When they are quite hot, divide them lengthwise into three. Put some thin flakes of good butter between the slices, press the rolls together, and put them in the oven for a minute or two. But not longer, or the butter would oil. Take them out of the oven, spread the butter equally over, divide the rolls in half, and put them on to a very hot, clean dish, and send them instantly to table.

text: HE SAYS THAT BY CUTTING THROUGH FOUR OR FIVE SLICES AT A TIME ALL THE BUTTER IS SQUEEZED OUT OF THE UPPER ONES WHILE THE BOTTOM ONE IS SWIMMING IN FAT LIQUID
whisper_text: He says that by cutting through four or five slices at a time, all the butter is squeezed out of the upper ones while the bottom one is swimming in fat liquid.

text: ITALIAN RUSKS
whisper_text: Italian Rusks

text: A YELLOW VARIETY CALLED GOLDEN MILLET IS SOLD IN THE GROCERS SHOPS FOR MAKING PUDDINGS AND IS VERY DELICATE AND WHOLESOME
whisper_text: A yellow variety called golden millet is sold in the grocer's shops for making puttings and is very delicate and wholesome.

text: NEXT TAKE EITHER A LARGE TABLESPOONFUL OF BREWER'S YEAST WHICH HAS BEEN RENDERED SOLID BY MIXING IT WITH PLENTY OF COLD WATER AND LETTING IT AFTERWARDS STAND TO SETTLE FOR A DAY AND NIGHT OR NEARLY AN OUNCE OF GERMAN YEAST PUT IT INTO A LARGE BASIN AND PROCEED TO MIX IT SO THAT IT SHALL BE AS SMOOTH AS CREAM WITH THREE QUARTERS PINT OF WARM MILK AND WATER OR WITH WATER ONLY THOUGH EVEN A VERY LITTLE MILK WILL MUCH IMPROVE THE BREAD
whisper_text: Next, take either a large tablespoon full of brewery's yeast, which has been rendered solid by mixing it with plenty of cold water, and letting it afterwards stand a settle for a day and night, or nearly an ounce of German yeast. Put it into a large basin and proceed to mix it so that it shall be as smooth as cream, with Â¾ pint of warm milk and water, or with water only. So even a very little milk will much improve the bread.

text: TO MAKE HOT BUTTERED TOAST SEVENTEEN TWENTY SIX
whisper_text: to make hot buttered toast, 1726.

text: MOVE IT BACKWARDS AND FORWARDS UNTIL THE BREAD IS NICELY COLOURED THEN TURN IT AND TOAST THE OTHER SIDE AND DO NOT PLACE IT SO NEAR THE FIRE THAT IT BLACKENS
whisper_text: Move it backwards and forwards until the bread is nicely colored. Then turn it and toast the other side. And do not place it so near the fire that it blackens.

text: MODE PUT THE FLOUR INTO A LARGE EARTHENWARE BOWL OR DEEP PAN THEN WITH A STRONG METAL OR WOODEN SPOON HOLLOW OUT THE MIDDLE BUT DO NOT CLEAR IT ENTIRELY AWAY FROM THE BOTTOM OF THE PAN AS IN THAT CASE THE SPONGE OR LEAVEN AS IT WAS FORMERLY TERMED WOULD STICK TO IT WHICH IT OUGHT NOT TO DO
whisper_text: Mode, put the flower into a large earthenware bowl or deep pan, then with a strong metal or wooden spoon hollow out the middle, but do not clear it entirely away from the bottom of the pan, as in that case the sponge or leaven as it was formerly termed would stick to it, which it ought not to do.

text: IT HAS BEEN INTRODUCED INTO ITALY WHERE THEY MAKE A COARSE BREAD FROM IT AND IT IS ALSO EMPLOYED IN PASTRY AND PUDDINGS THEY ALSO USE IT FOR FEEDING HORSES AND DOMESTIC FOWLS
whisper_text: It has been introduced into Italy where they make a coarse bread from it. And it is also employed in pastry and puttings. They also use it for feeding horses and domestic fowls.

text: THEY SHOULD BE KEPT IN A CLOSED TIN CANISTER IN A DRY PLACE TO PRESERVE THEIR CRISPNESS
whisper_text: they should be kept in a closed tin canister in a dry place to preserve their crispness.

text: SOYER RECOMMENDS THAT EACH SLICE SHOULD BE CUT INTO PIECES AS SOON AS IT IS BUTTERED AND WHEN ALL ARE READY THAT THEY SHOULD BE PILED LIGHTLY ON THE DISH THEY ARE INTENDED TO BE SERVED ON
whisper_text: Sawyer recommends that each slice should be cut into pieces as soon as it is buttered and when all are ready, that they should be piled lightly on the dish they are intended to be served on.

text: SEVENTEEN TWENTY FOUR

TURN IT THEN ON TO A PASTE BOARD OR VERY CLEAN DRESSER AND WITH A LARGE SHARP KNIFE DIVIDE IT IN TWO MAKE IT UP QUICKLY INTO LOAVES AND DISPATCH IT TO THE OVEN MAKE ONE OR TWO INCISIONS ACROSS THE TOPS OF THE LOAVES AS THEY WILL RISE MORE EASILY IF THIS BE DONE
whisper_text: Turn it then onto a paste board or very clean dresser, and with a large sharp knife divided in two. Make it up quickly into loaves and dispatch it to the oven. Make one or two incisions across the top of the loaves as they will rise more easily if this be done.

text: ILLUSTRATION RUSKS
whisper_text: Illustration, Rusks.

text: CUT AS MANY NICE EVEN SLICES AS MAY BE REQUIRED RATHER MORE THAN ONE QUARTER INCH IN THICKNESS AND TOAST THEM BEFORE A VERY BRIGHT FIRE WITHOUT ALLOWING THE BREAD TO BLACKEN WHICH SPOILS THE APPEARANCE AND FLAVOUR OF ALL TOAST
whisper_text: Cut as many nice even slices as may be required, rather more than one quarter inch in thickness, and toast them before a very bright fire without allowing the bread to blacken, which spoils the appearance and flavor of all toast.

text: NEVER USE NEW BREAD FOR MAKING ANY KIND OF TOAST AS IT EATS HEAVY AND BESIDES IS VERY EXTRAVAGANT
whisper_text: Never use new bread for making any kind of toast as it eats heavy and besides it is very extravagant.

text: MODE PUT THE MILK AND BUTTER INTO A SAUCEPAN AND KEEP SHAKING IT ROUND UNTIL THE LATTER IS MELTED
whisper_text: Mode. Put the milk and butter into a saucepan and keep shaking it round until the ladder is melted.

text: THEN PLACE THE PAN ON A STRONG CHAIR OR DRESSER OR TABLE OF CONVENIENT HEIGHT POUR INTO THE SPONGE THE REMAINDER OF THE WARM MILK AND WATER STIR INTO IT AS MUCH OF THE FLOUR AS YOU CAN WITH THE SPOON THEN WIPE IT OUT CLEAN WITH YOUR FINGERS AND LAY IT ASIDE
whisper_text: Then place the pan on a strong chair or dresser or table of convenient height. Pour into the sponge the remainder of the warm milk and water. Stir into it as much of the flowers you can with the spoon. Then wipe it out clean with your fingers and lay it aside.

text: IT WILL GROW ON POOR SOILS AND IS EXTREMELY PRODUCTIVE

text: HE STRUCK AMBROSCH ON THE BACK AND THE BOY SMILED KNOWINGLY
whisper_text: He struck Ambrose on the back, and the boy smiled knowingly.

text: NOW WHY IS THAT OTTO
whisper_text: Now, why is that auto?

text: ANTONIA POINTED UP TO THE SKY AND QUESTIONED ME WITH HER GLANCE
whisper_text: Antonia pointed up to the sky and questioned me with her glance.

text: WE STOOD PANTING ON THE EDGE OF THE RAVINE LOOKING DOWN AT THE TREES AND BUSHES THAT GREW BELOW US
whisper_text: We stood panting on the edge of the ravine, looking down at the trees and bushes that grew below us.

text: I NOTICED HOW WHITE AND WELL SHAPED HIS OWN HANDS WERE
whisper_text: I noticed how white and well shaped his own hands were.

text: SHE POINTED INTO THE GOLD COTTONWOOD TREE BEHIND WHOSE TOP WE STOOD AND SAID AGAIN WHAT NAME
whisper_text: She pointed into the gold cottonwood tree behind his top we stood and said again, what name?

text: IT'S NO BETTER THAN A BADGER HOLE NO PROPER DUGOUT AT ALL
whisper_text: It's no better than a badger hole. No proper dugout at all.

text: AMBROSCH HE MAKE GOOD FARMER
whisper_text: Ambrose, you make good farmer.

text: SHE WAS QUICK AND VERY EAGER
whisper_text: She was quick and very eager.

text: THE FAMILY HAD BEEN LIVING ON CORNCAKES AND SORGHUM MOLASSES FOR THREE DAYS
whisper_text: The family had been living on corn cakes and sorghum molasses for three days.

text: I BECAME SOMEWHAT EMBARRASSED FOR I WAS USED TO BEING TAKEN FOR GRANTED BY MY ELDERS
whisper_text: I became somewhat embarrassed for I was used to being taken for granted by my elders.

text: HE WAS BORN LIKE THAT THE OTHERS ARE SMART
whisper_text: He was born like that. The others are smart.

text: VERY GLAD VERY GLAD SHE EJACULATED
whisper_text: Very glad, very glad she ejaculated.

text: PRESENTLY AGAINST ONE OF THOSE BANKS I SAW A SORT OF SHED THATCHED WITH THE SAME WINE COLORED GRASS THAT GREW EVERYWHERE
whisper_text: Presently, against one of those banks, I saw a sort of shed, thatched with the same wine-colored grass that grew everywhere.

text: EVEN FROM A DISTANCE ONE COULD SEE THAT THERE WAS SOMETHING STRANGE ABOUT THIS BOY
whisper_text: Even from a distance, one could see that there was something strange about this boy.

text: WHEN I CAME UP HE TOUCHED MY SHOULDER AND LOOKED SEARCHINGLY DOWN INTO MY FACE FOR SEVERAL SECONDS
whisper_text: When I came up, he touched my shoulder and looked searchingly down into my face for several seconds.

text: SHE MADE MISSUS SHIMERDA UNDERSTAND THE FRIENDLY INTENTION OF OUR VISIT AND THE BOHEMIAN WOMAN HANDLED THE LOAVES OF BREAD AND EVEN SMELLED THEM AND EXAMINED THE PIES WITH LIVELY CURIOSITY EXCLAIMING MUCH GOOD MUCH THANK
whisper_text: She made Mrs. Shamir to understand the friendly intention of our visit, and the Bohemian woman handled the loaves of bread, and even smelled them, and examined the pies with lively curiosity, exclaiming much good, much think.

text: SHE GOT UP ON HER KNEES AND WRUNG HER HANDS
whisper_text: She got up on her knees and wrung her hands.

text: AFTER ANTONIA HAD SAID THE NEW WORDS OVER AND OVER SHE WANTED TO GIVE ME A LITTLE CHASED SILVER RING SHE WORE ON HER MIDDLE FINGER
whisper_text: After Antonya had said the new words over and over, she wanted to give me a little chased silver ring she wore on her middle finger.

text: MY GRANDMOTHER ALWAYS SPOKE IN A VERY LOUD TONE TO FOREIGNERS AS IF THEY WERE DEAF
whisper_text: My grandmother always spoke in a very loud tone to foreigners as if they were deaf.

text: HER SKIN WAS BROWN TOO AND IN HER CHEEKS SHE HAD A GLOW OF RICH DARK COLOR
whisper_text: Her skin was brown too, and in her cheeks she had a glow of rich dark color.

text: I REMEMBERED WHAT THE CONDUCTOR HAD SAID ABOUT HER EYES
whisper_text: I remembered what the conductor had said about her eyes.

text: YOU'LL GET FIXED UP COMFORTABLE AFTER WHILE MISSUS SHIMERDA MAKE GOOD HOUSE
whisper_text: You'll get fixed up comfortable after a while Mrs. Schumerida. Make good house.

text: WE WERE SO DEEP IN THE GRASS THAT WE COULD SEE NOTHING BUT THE BLUE SKY OVER US AND THE GOLD TREE IN FRONT OF US
whisper_text: We were so deep in the grass that we could see nothing but the blue sky over us, and the gold tree in front of us.

text: OCCASIONALLY ONE OF THE HORSES WOULD TEAR OFF WITH HIS TEETH A PLANT FULL OF BLOSSOMS AND WALK ALONG MUNCHING IT THE FLOWERS NODDING IN TIME TO HIS BITES AS HE ATE DOWN TOWARD THEM
whisper_text: Occasionally, one of the horses would tear off with his teeth, a plant full of blossoms, and walk along munching it, the flowers nodding in time to his bites as he ate down toward them.

text: IT WAS SO LONG THAT IT BUSHED OUT BEHIND HIS EARS AND MADE HIM LOOK LIKE THE OLD PORTRAITS I REMEMBERED IN VIRGINIA
whisper_text: It was so long that it busched out behind his ears and made him look like the old portraits I remember in Virginia.

text: SHE LOOKED AT ME HER EYES FAIRLY BLAZING WITH THINGS SHE COULD NOT SAY
whisper_text: She looked at me, her eyes fairly blazing with things she could not say.

text: THE WIND WAS SO STRONG THAT I HAD TO HOLD MY HAT ON AND THE GIRLS SKIRTS WERE BLOWN OUT BEFORE THEM
whisper_text: The wind was so strong that I had to hold my hat on and the girl's skirts were blown out before them.

text: AT THAT MOMENT THE FATHER CAME OUT OF THE HOLE IN THE BANK
whisper_text: At that moment the father came out of the hole in the bank.

text: FUCHS BROUGHT UP A SACK OF POTATOES AND A PIECE OF CURED PORK FROM THE CELLAR AND GRANDMOTHER PACKED SOME LOAVES OF SATURDAY'S BREAD A JAR OF BUTTER AND SEVERAL PUMPKIN PIES IN THE STRAW OF THE WAGON BOX
whisper_text: Fooks brought up a sack of potatoes and a piece of cured pork from the cellar, and grandmother packed some loaves of Saturday's bread, a jar of butter, and several pumpkin pies in the straw of the wagon box.

text: IN ARISTOCRACIES EVERY MAN HAS ONE SOLE OBJECT WHICH HE UNCEASINGLY PURSUES BUT AMONGST DEMOCRATIC NATIONS THE EXISTENCE OF MAN IS MORE COMPLEX THE SAME MIND WILL ALMOST ALWAYS EMBRACE SEVERAL OBJECTS AT THE SAME TIME AND THESE OBJECTS ARE FREQUENTLY WHOLLY FOREIGN TO EACH OTHER AS IT CANNOT KNOW THEM ALL WELL THE MIND IS READILY SATISFIED WITH IMPERFECT NOTIONS OF EACH
whisper_text: In aristocracies, every man has one soul object which he unceasingly pursues. But amongst democratic nations, the existence of man is more complex. The same mind will almost always embrace several objects at the same time, and these objects are frequently wholly foreign to each other. As it cannot know them all well, the mind is readily satisfied with imperfect notions of each.

text: IF I APPLAUD THE FREEDOM WHICH ITS INHABITANTS ENJOY HE ANSWERS FREEDOM IS A FINE THING BUT FEW NATIONS ARE WORTHY TO ENJOY IT
whisper_text: If I applaud the freedom which its inhabitants enjoy, he answers, freedom is a fine thing, but few nations are worthy to enjoy it.

text: IN ARISTOCRATIC COUNTRIES THE GREAT POSSESS IMMENSE PRIVILEGES UPON WHICH THEIR PRIDE RESTS WITHOUT SEEKING TO RELY UPON THE LESSER ADVANTAGES WHICH ACCRUE TO THEM
whisper_text: In aristocratic countries, the great possess immense privileges upon which their pride rests without seeking to rely upon the lesser advantages which accruise at them.

text: CHAPTER SIXTEEN WHY THE NATIONAL VANITY OF THE AMERICANS IS MORE RESTLESS AND CAPTIOUS THAN THAT OF THE ENGLISH
whisper_text: Chapter 16. Why the national vanity of the Americans is more restless and captures than that of the English?

text: IN ARISTOCRATIC COMMUNITIES THE PEOPLE READILY GIVE THEMSELVES UP TO BURSTS OF TUMULTUOUS AND BOISTEROUS GAYETY WHICH SHAKE OFF AT ONCE THE RECOLLECTION OF THEIR PRIVATIONS THE NATIVES OF DEMOCRACIES ARE NOT FOND OF BEING THUS VIOLENTLY BROKEN IN UPON AND THEY NEVER LOSE SIGHT OF THEIR OWN SELVES WITHOUT REGRET
whisper_text: In aristocratic communities, the people readily give themselves up to bursts of tumultuous and boisterous guillity, which shake off at once the recollection of their privations. The natives of democracies are not fond of being thus violently broken in upon, and they never lose sight of their own selves without regret.

text: AN AMERICAN INSTEAD OF GOING IN A LEISURE HOUR TO DANCE MERRILY AT SOME PLACE OF PUBLIC RESORT AS THE FELLOWS OF HIS CALLING CONTINUE TO DO THROUGHOUT THE GREATER PART OF EUROPE SHUTS HIMSELF UP AT HOME TO DRINK
whisper_text: An American, instead of going in a leisure hour to dance merrily at some place of public resort, as the fellows of his co-ling continue to do throughout the greater part of Europe, shut himself up at home to drink.

text: WHEN AN ARISTOCRACY CARRIES ON THE PUBLIC AFFAIRS ITS NATIONAL PRIDE NATURALLY ASSUMES THIS RESERVED INDIFFERENT AND HAUGHTY FORM WHICH IS IMITATED BY ALL THE OTHER CLASSES OF THE NATION
whisper_text: When an aristocracy carries on the public affairs, its national pride naturally assumes this reserved, indifferent, and haughty form, which is imitated by all the other classes of the nation.

text: I BELIEVE THE SERIOUSNESS OF THE AMERICANS ARISES PARTLY FROM THEIR PRIDE
whisper_text: I believe the seriousness of the Americans arises partly from their pride.

text: THIS IS MORE ESPECIALLY THE CASE AMONGST THOSE FREE NATIONS WHICH FORM DEMOCRATIC COMMUNITIES
whisper_text: This is more especially the case amongst those free nations which form democratic communities.

text: THESE PERSONS THEN DISPLAYED TOWARDS EACH OTHER PRECISELY THE SAME PUERILE JEALOUSIES WHICH ANIMATE THE MEN OF DEMOCRACIES THE SAME EAGERNESS TO SNATCH THE SMALLEST ADVANTAGES WHICH THEIR EQUALS CONTESTED AND THE SAME DESIRE TO PARADE OSTENTATIOUSLY THOSE OF WHICH THEY WERE IN POSSESSION
whisper_text: These persons then, displayed towards each other, precisely the same pure-all jealousies which animate the men of democracies, the same eagerness to snatch the small advantages which are equals contested, and the same desire to parade ostentatiously those of which they were in possession.

text: THE AMERICANS IN THEIR INTERCOURSE WITH STRANGERS APPEAR IMPATIENT OF THE SMALLEST CENSURE AND INSATIABLE OF PRAISE
whisper_text: The Americans in their intercourse with strangers appear impatient with the smallest center, an insatiable of praise.

text: THEY THEREFORE ENTERTAIN A CALM SENSE OF THEIR SUPERIORITY THEY DO NOT DREAM OF VAUNTING PRIVILEGES WHICH EVERYONE PERCEIVES AND NO ONE CONTESTS AND THESE THINGS ARE NOT SUFFICIENTLY NEW TO THEM TO BE MADE TOPICS OF CONVERSATION
whisper_text: They therefore entertain a calm sense of their superiority. They do not dream of vanting privileges, which everyone perceives, at no one contests. And these things are not sufficiently new to them to be made topics of conversation.

text: THEN THERE ARE IN ALL CLASSES A VERY LARGE NUMBER OF MEN CONSTANTLY OCCUPIED WITH THE SERIOUS AFFAIRS OF THE GOVERNMENT AND THOSE WHOSE THOUGHTS ARE NOT ENGAGED IN THE DIRECTION OF THE COMMONWEALTH ARE WHOLLY ENGROSSED BY THE ACQUISITION OF A PRIVATE FORTUNE
whisper_text: Then there are, in all classes, a very large number of men constantly occupied with the series affairs of the government, and those whose thoughts are not engaged in the direction of the Commonwealth are wholly engrossed by the acquisition of a private fortune.

text: I DO NOT BELIEVE IN SUCH REPUBLICS ANY MORE THAN IN THAT OF PLATO OR IF THE THINGS WE READ OF REALLY HAPPENED I DO NOT HESITATE TO AFFIRM THAT THESE SUPPOSED DEMOCRACIES WERE COMPOSED OF VERY DIFFERENT ELEMENTS FROM OURS AND THAT THEY HAD NOTHING IN COMMON WITH THE LATTER EXCEPT THEIR NAME
whisper_text: I do not believe in such republics anymore than in that of Plato. Or if the things we read off really happened, I do not hesitate to affirm that these supposed democracies were composed of very different elements from ours, and that they had nothing in common with the latter except their name.

text: THEY STAND UNMOVED IN THEIR SOLITARY GREATNESS WELL ASSURED THAT THEY ARE SEEN OF ALL THE WORLD WITHOUT ANY EFFORT TO SHOW THEMSELVES OFF AND THAT NO ONE WILL ATTEMPT TO DRIVE THEM FROM THAT POSITION
whisper_text: They stand unmoved in their solitary greatness, well assured that they are seen of all the world without any effort to show themselves off, and that no one will attempt to drive them from that position.

text: IF I SAY TO AN AMERICAN THAT THE COUNTRY HE LIVES IN IS A FINE ONE AY HE REPLIES THERE IS NOT ITS FELLOW IN THE WORLD
whisper_text: If I say to an American that the country he lives in is a fine one, I, he replies, there is not a fellow in the world.

text: IF IT SHOULD BE IN AN UNSOUND STATE IT MUST BE ON NO ACCOUNT MADE USE OF
whisper_text: If it should be in an unsound state, it must be on no account made use of.

text: MODE PUT THE MILK IN A VERY CLEAN SAUCEPAN AND LET IT BOIL
whisper_text: Mode. Put the milk in a very clean saucepan and let it boil.

text: THEN ADD THE YOLKS OF THE EGGS WELL BEATEN STIR THEM TO THE SAUCE BUT DO NOT ALLOW IT TO BOIL AND SERVE VERY HOT
whisper_text: Then add the yolks of the eggs well beaten. Stir them to the sauce, but do not allow it to boil and serve very hot.

text: WHEN THE THREE INGREDIENTS ARE PROPERLY PREPARED POUND THEM ALTOGETHER IN A MORTAR FOR SOME TIME FOR THE MORE QUENELLES ARE POUNDED THE MORE DELICATE THEY ARE
whisper_text: When the three ingredients are properly prepared, pound them all together in a mortar for some time. For the more canals are pounded, the more delicate they are.

text: BOIL THEM BEFORE THEY ARE PUT INTO THE SOUP OR OTHER DISH THEY MAY BE INTENDED FOR
whisper_text: Boil them before they are put into the soup or other dish they may be intended for.

text: IT WILL BE WELL TO STATE IN THE BEGINNING OF THIS RECIPE THAT FRENCH FORCEMEAT OR QUENELLES CONSIST OF THE BLENDING OF THREE SEPARATE PROCESSES NAMELY PANADA UDDER AND WHATEVER MEAT YOU INTEND USING PANADA
whisper_text: It will be well to state in the beginning of this recipe that French Forced Meat or Cornels consists of the blending of three separate processes, namely Panada, Udder, and whatever meat you intend using. Panada

text: PUT THE SUGAR WITH ONE QUARTER PINT OF WATER IN A SAUCEPAN OVER THE FIRE REMOVE THE SCUM AS IT RISES AND ADD THE LEMON PEEL AND GINGER WITH THE OUTSIDE SCRAPED OFF WHEN THE SYRUP IS TOLERABLY THICK TAKE IT OFF THE FIRE AND WHEN COLD WIPE THE CUCUMBERS DRY AND PUT THEM IN
whisper_text: Put the sugar with 1 Â¼ pint of water in a saucepan over the fire. Remove the scum as it rises and add the lemon peel and ginger with the outside scraped off. When the syrup is tolerably thick, take it off the fire and when cold, wipe the cucumbers dry and put them in.

text: ILLUSTRATION GINGER
whisper_text: Illustration, Ginger.

text: ADD THE WINE AND IF NECESSARY A SEASONING OF CAYENNE WHEN IT WILL BE READY TO SERVE
whisper_text: Add the wine and if necessary, a seasoning of cayenne when it will be ready to serve.

text: NOTE THE WINE IN THIS SAUCE MAY BE OMITTED AND AN ONION SLICED AND FRIED OF A NICE BROWN SUBSTITUTED FOR IT
whisper_text: Note, the wine in this sauce may be omitted and an onion sliced and fried of a nice brown substituted for it.

text: THE GINGER PLANT KNOWN TO NATURALISTS AS ZINGIBER OFFICINALE IS A NATIVE OF THE EAST AND WEST INDIES
whisper_text: The ginger plant known to naturalists as Zingibur Efficientale is a native of the East and West Indies.

text: SEASONABLE THIS RECIPE SHOULD BE USED IN JUNE JULY OR AUGUST
whisper_text: Seasonable. This recipe should be used in June, July or August.

text: FRENCH FORCEMEAT
whisper_text: French Force Meat

text: LEMON JUICE MAY BE ADDED AT PLEASURE
whisper_text: Lemon juice may be added at pleasure.

whisper_text: Illustration, Pestil and Mortar.

text: MODE PARE AND SLICE THE CUCUMBERS AS FOR THE TABLE SPRINKLE WELL WITH SALT AND LET THEM REMAIN FOR TWENTY FOUR HOURS STRAIN OFF THE LIQUOR PACK IN JARS A THICK LAYER OF CUCUMBERS AND SALT ALTERNATELY TIE DOWN CLOSELY AND WHEN WANTED FOR USE TAKE OUT THE QUANTITY REQUIRED
whisper_text: Mode. Pair and slice the cucumbers as for the table. Sprinkle well with salt and let them remain for 24 hours. Strain off the liquor, pack in jars, a thick layer of cucumbers and salt alternately. Tie down closely and when wanted for use take out the quantity required.

text: BEAT THE EGGS STIR TO THEM THE MILK AND POUNDED SUGAR AND PUT THE MIXTURE INTO A JUG
whisper_text: Beat the eggs, stir to them the milk and pounded sugar, and put the mixture into a jug.

text: BOIL FOR FIVE MINUTES MINCE IT VERY SMALL AND MIX IT WITH THE OTHER INGREDIENTS
whisper_text: Boil for five minutes, mince it very small and mix it with the other ingredients.

text: IT IS HARDIER THAN THE ORANGE AND AS ONE OF THE CITRON TRIBE WAS BROUGHT INTO EUROPE BY THE ARABIANS
whisper_text: It is harder than the orange and, as one of the Citron tribe, was brought into Europe by the Arabians.

text: WHEN QUITE CRISP DIP ONE SIDE OF THE SIPPET INTO THE BEATEN WHITE OF AN EGG MIXED WITH A LITTLE FLOUR AND PLACE IT ON THE EDGE OF THE DISH
whisper_text: When quite crisp, dip one side of the sippet into the beaten white of an egg mixed with a little flour and place it on the edge of the dish.

text: SEASONABLE THIS SHOULD BE MADE ABOUT EASTER AS AT THIS TIME EGGS ARE PLENTIFUL AND CHEAP
whisper_text: Seasonable. This should be made about Easter as at this time eggs are plentiful and cheap.

text: ILLUSTRATION SAGE
whisper_text: Illustration, Sage.

text: SIMMER FOR A MINUTE OR TWO AND SERVE IN A TUREEN
whisper_text: Simmer for a minute or two and serve in a charine.

text: NOW BEAT AND STRAIN THE EGGS WORK THESE UP WITH THE OTHER INGREDIENTS AND THE FORCEMEAT WILL BE READY FOR USE
whisper_text: Now, beat and strain the eggs. Work these up with the other ingredients, and the first meat will be ready for use.

text: PLACE THE JUG IN A SAUCEPAN OF BOILING WATER KEEP STIRRING WELL UNTIL IT THICKENS BUT DO NOT ALLOW IT TO BOIL OR IT WILL CURDLE
whisper_text: Place the jug in a saucepan of boiling water. Keep stirring well until it thickens, but do not allow it to boil or it will curdle.

text: ORIGINALLY THE MOST VALUABLE OF THESE WERE FOUND IN THE SPICE ISLANDS OR MOLUCCAS OF THE INDIAN OCEAN AND WERE HIGHLY PRIZED BY THE NATIONS OF ANTIQUITY
whisper_text: Originally, the most valuable of these were found in the Spice Islands or Maluchas of the Indian Ocean, and were highly prized by the nations of antiquity.

text: ANY ONE WITH THE SLIGHTEST PRETENSIONS TO REFINED COOKERY MUST IN THIS PARTICULAR IMPLICITLY FOLLOW THE EXAMPLE OF OUR FRIENDS ACROSS THE CHANNEL
whisper_text: Anyone with the slightest pretentions to refine cooked green must, in this particular, implicitly follow the example of our friends across the channel.

text: POUND WELL AND BIND WITH ONE OR TWO EGGS WHICH HAVE BEEN PREVIOUSLY BEATEN AND STRAINED
whisper_text: pound well and bind with one or two eggs which have been previously beaten and strained.

whisper_text: Illustration, Marjoram.

text: IF THE QUENELLES ARE NOT FIRM ENOUGH ADD THE YOLK OF ANOTHER EGG BUT OMIT THE WHITE WHICH ONLY MAKES THEM HOLLOW AND PUFFY INSIDE
whisper_text: If the quenelles are not firm enough, add the yolk of another egg, but omit the white, which only makes them hollow and puffy inside.

text: THE LONG PEPPER IS LESS AROMATIC THAN THE BLACK BUT ITS OIL IS MORE PUNGENT
whisper_text: The long pepper is less aromatic than the black, but its oil is more pungent.

text: WHEN IT IS SUFFICIENTLY THICK TAKE IT OFF AS IT SHOULD NOT BOIL
whisper_text: when it is sufficiently thick, take it off as it should not boil.

whisper_text: It's sufficient for a moderate size tadic or pike.

whisper_text: It's sufficient to serve with 5 or 6 macro.

text: SUFFICIENT HALF THIS QUANTITY FOR TWO SLICES OF SALMON
whisper_text: sufficient half this quantity for two slices of salmon

text: A STORE OF PICKLED EGGS WILL BE FOUND VERY USEFUL AND ORNAMENTAL IN SERVING WITH MANY FIRST AND SECOND COURSE DISHES
whisper_text: A store of pickled eggs will be found very useful and ornamental in serving with many first and second-course dishes.

text: FRIED BREAD FOR BORDERS
whisper_text: Fried bread for borders.

text: THE LEMON WAS FIRST CULTIVATED IN ENGLAND IN THE BEGINNING OF THE SEVENTEENTH CENTURY AND IS NOW OFTEN TO BE FOUND IN OUR GREEN HOUSES
whisper_text: The lemon was first cultivated in England in the beginning of the 17th century and is now often to be found in our green houses.

text: VARIOUS DISHES ARE FREQUENTLY ORNAMENTED AND GARNISHED WITH ITS GRACEFUL LEAVES AND THESE ARE SOMETIMES BOILED IN SOUPS ALTHOUGH IT IS MORE USUALLY CONFINED IN ENGLISH COOKERY TO THE MACKEREL SAUCE AS HERE GIVEN
whisper_text: Various dishes are frequently ornamented and garnished with its graceful leaves and these are sometimes boiled in soups, although it is more usually confined in English cookery to the macro sauce as here given.

text: MODE CUT UP THE ONION AND CARROT INTO SMALL RINGS AND PUT THEM INTO A STEWPAN WITH THE HERBS MUSHROOMS BAY LEAF CLOVES AND MACE ADD THE BUTTER AND SIMMER THE WHOLE VERY GENTLY OVER A SLOW FIRE UNTIL THE ONION IS QUITE TENDER
whisper_text: Mode. Cut up the onion and carrot into small rings and put them into a stew pan with herbs, mushrooms, bay leaf, cloves and mace. Add the butter and simmer the whole very gently over a slow fire until the onion is quite tender.

text: THIS JUICE WHICH IS CALLED CITRIC ACID MAY BE PRESERVED IN BOTTLES FOR A CONSIDERABLE TIME BY COVERING IT WITH A THIN STRATUM OF OIL
whisper_text: This juice, which is called citric acid, may be preserved in bottles for a considerable time by covering it with a thin stratum of oil.

text: THE FAT THEY ARE FRIED IN SHOULD BE CLEAR AND THE CRUMBS SHOULD NOT HAVE THE SLIGHTEST APPEARANCE OR TASTE OF HAVING BEEN IN THE LEAST DEGREE BURNT
whisper_text: The fat there fried and should be clear and the crumbs should not have the slightest appearance or taste of having been in the least degree burnt.
