whisper_text: illustration, long pepper.

text: ILLUSTRATION THE LEMON
whisper_text: Illustration, the lemon.

text: MODE MIX ALL THE INGREDIENTS WELL TOGETHER CAREFULLY MINCING THEM VERY FINELY BEAT UP THE EGG MOISTEN WITH IT AND WORK THE WHOLE VERY SMOOTHLY TOGETHER
whisper_text: Mode. Mix all the ingredients well together, carefully mincing them very finely. Beat up the egg, moisten with it, and work the whole very smoothly together.

text: IT IS A NATIVE OF PORTUGAL AND WHEN ITS LEAVES ARE USED AS A SEASONING HERB THEY HAVE AN AGREEABLE AROMATIC FLAVOUR
whisper_text: It is a native of Portugal and when its leaves are used as a seasoning herb, they have an agreeable aromatic flavor.

text: THE LEMON THIS FRUIT IS A NATIVE OF ASIA AND IS MENTIONED BY VIRGIL AS AN ANTIDOTE TO POISON
whisper_text: The Lemon. This fruit is a native of Asia and is mentioned by Virgil as an antidote to poison.

text: LONG PEPPER THIS IS THE PRODUCE OF A DIFFERENT PLANT FROM THAT WHICH PRODUCES THE BLACK IT CONSISTING OF THE HALF RIPE FLOWER HEADS OF WHAT NATURALISTS CALL PIPER LONGUM AND CHABA
whisper_text: Long pepper. This is the produce of a different plant from that which produces the black. It consisting of the half ripe flower heads have what naturalists call Piper Longum and Chaba.

text: FRIED BREAD CRUMBS
whisper_text: Fried breadcrumbs.

text: TO PICKLE EGGS
whisper_text: to pickle eggs.

text: CONTINUE IN THIS MANNER TILL THE BORDER IS COMPLETED ARRANGING THE SIPPETS A PALE AND A DARK ONE ALTERNATELY
whisper_text: Continue in this manner until the border is completed, arranging the cipits of pale and a dark one alternately.

text: FORCEMEAT FOR COLD SAVOURY PIES
whisper_text: Force meat for cold savory pies.

text: PUT THE UDDER INTO A STEWPAN WITH SUFFICIENT WATER TO COVER IT LET IT STEW GENTLY TILL QUITE DONE WHEN TAKE IT OUT TO COOL
whisper_text: Put the edger into a stew pan with sufficient water to cover it. Let it stew gently till quite done, when take it out to cool.

text: ILLUSTRATION THE CUCUMBER
whisper_text: Illustration, the Q-Cover.

text: SOLID ROCKS OF SALT ARE ALSO FOUND IN VARIOUS PARTS OF THE WORLD AND THE COUNTY OF CHESTER CONTAINS MANY OF THESE MINES AND IT IS FROM THERE THAT MUCH OF OUR SALT COMES
whisper_text: Solid rocks of salt are also found in various parts of the world, and in the country of Chester contains many of these minds. And it is from there that much of our salt comes.

text: OTHER SWEET HERBS ARE CULTIVATED FOR PURPOSES OF MEDICINE AND PERFUMERY THEY ARE MOST GRATEFUL BOTH TO THE ORGANS OF TASTE AND SMELLING AND TO THE AROMA DERIVED FROM THEM IS DUE IN A GREAT MEASURE THE SWEET AND EXHILARATING FRAGRANCE OF OUR FLOWERY MEADS
whisper_text: Other sweet herbs are cultivated for purposes of medicine and perfumery. They are most grateful both to the organs of taste and smelling, and to the aroma derived from them is due in a great measure the sweet and exhilarating fragrance of our flowery needs.

text: MODE PUT THE WHOLE OF THE INGREDIENTS INTO A BOTTLE AND LET IT REMAIN FOR A FORTNIGHT IN A WARM PLACE OCCASIONALLY SHAKING UP THE CONTENTS
whisper_text: Mode. Put the hole of the ingredients into a bottle and let it remain for a fortnight in a warm place, occasionally shaking up the contents.

text: IN JAMAICA IT FLOWERS ABOUT AUGUST OR SEPTEMBER FADING ABOUT THE END OF THE YEAR
whisper_text: In Jamaica, it flowers about August or September, fading about the end of the year.

text: BEAT THE YOLKS OF THE OTHER TWO EGGS ADD THEM WITH A LITTLE FLOUR AND SALT TO THOSE POUNDED MIX ALL WELL TOGETHER AND ROLL INTO BALLS
whisper_text: Beat the yolks of the other two eggs, add them with a little flour and salt to those pounded. Mix all well together and roll into balls.

text: THEY OUGHT TO BE TAKEN UP IN THE AUTUMN AND WHEN DRIED IN THE HOUSE WILL KEEP TILL SPRING
whisper_text: They ought to be taken up in the autumn, and when dried in the house will keep till spring.

text: ILLUSTRATION BASIL
whisper_text: Illustration, Basil.

text: SOME SPRINGS ARE SO HIGHLY IMPREGNATED WITH SALT AS TO HAVE RECEIVED THE NAME OF BRINE SPRINGS AND ARE SUPPOSED TO HAVE BECOME SO BY PASSING THROUGH THE SALT ROCKS BELOW GROUND AND THUS DISSOLVING A PORTION OF THIS MINERAL SUBSTANCE
whisper_text: Some springs are so highly impregnated with salt as to have received the name of brine springs and are supposed to have become so by passing through the salt rocks below ground and thus dissolving a portion of this mineral substance.

text: MODE CHOOSE THE GREENEST CUCUMBERS AND THOSE THAT ARE MOST FREE FROM SEEDS PUT THEM IN STRONG SALT AND WATER WITH A CABBAGE LEAF TO KEEP THEM DOWN TIE A PAPER OVER THEM AND PUT THEM IN A WARM PLACE TILL THEY ARE YELLOW THEN WASH THEM AND SET THEM OVER THE FIRE IN FRESH WATER WITH A VERY LITTLE SALT AND ANOTHER CABBAGE LEAF OVER THEM COVER VERY CLOSELY BUT TAKE CARE THEY DO NOT BOIL
whisper_text: Mode. Choose the greenest cucumbers and those that are most free from seeds. Put them in strong salt and water with a cabbage leaf to keep them down. Tie a paper over them and put them in a warm place till they are yellow. Then wash them and set them over the fire in fresh water with a very little salt and another cabbage leaf over them. Cover very closely but take care they do not boil.

text: PLACE IT OVER THE FIRE KEEP CONSTANTLY STIRRING TO PREVENT ITS BURNING AND WHEN QUITE DRY PUT IN A SMALL PIECE OF BUTTER
whisper_text: Place it over the fire, keep constantly stirring to prevent its burning, and when quite dry, put in a small piece of butter.

text: WHAT WILL THE MORAL PHILOSOPHERS WHO APPEAR AT THIS TIME HAVE TO PREACH
whisper_text: What will the moral philosophers who appear at this time have to preach?

text: EVERY ELEVATION OF THE TYPE MAN HAS HITHERTO BEEN THE WORK OF AN ARISTOCRATIC SOCIETY AND SO IT WILL ALWAYS BE A SOCIETY BELIEVING IN A LONG SCALE OF GRADATIONS OF RANK AND DIFFERENCES OF WORTH AMONG HUMAN BEINGS AND REQUIRING SLAVERY IN SOME FORM OR OTHER
whisper_text: Every elevation of the type man has hitherto been the work of an aristocratic society, and so it will always be, a society believing in a long scale of gradations of rank and differences of worth among human beings, and requiring slavery in some form or other.

text: ON THIS ACCOUNT THE PEOPLE OF ONE NATION UNDERSTAND ONE ANOTHER BETTER THAN THOSE BELONGING TO DIFFERENT NATIONS EVEN WHEN THEY USE THE SAME LANGUAGE OR RATHER WHEN PEOPLE HAVE LIVED LONG TOGETHER UNDER SIMILAR CONDITIONS OF CLIMATE SOIL DANGER REQUIREMENT TOIL THERE ORIGINATES THEREFROM AN ENTITY THAT UNDERSTANDS ITSELF NAMELY A NATION
whisper_text: On this account, the people of one nation understand one another better than those belonging to different nations, even when they use the same language. Or, rather, when people have lived long together under similar conditions of climate, soil, danger, requirement, toil, their originates, their from and entity that understands itself, namely a nation.

text: THE GREATER THE DANGER THE GREATER IS THE NEED OF AGREEING QUICKLY AND READILY ABOUT WHAT IS NECESSARY NOT TO MISUNDERSTAND ONE ANOTHER IN DANGER THAT IS WHAT CANNOT AT ALL BE DISPENSED WITH IN INTERCOURSE
whisper_text: The greater the danger, the greater is the need of agreeing quickly and readily about what is necessary. Not to misunderstand one another in danger. That is what cannot at all be dispensed within intercourse.

text: THE DISTINCTIONS OF MORAL VALUES HAVE EITHER ORIGINATED IN A RULING CASTE PLEASANTLY CONSCIOUS OF BEING DIFFERENT FROM THE RULED OR AMONG THE RULED CLASS THE SLAVES AND DEPENDENTS OF ALL SORTS
whisper_text: The distinctions of moral values have either originated in a ruling cast, pleasantly conscious of being different from the ruled, or among the ruled class, the slaves, and dependents of all sorts.

text: THIS IS THE PROBLEM OF RACE
whisper_text: This is the problem of race.

text: THE HIGHEST INSTINCT FOR PURITY PLACES HIM WHO IS AFFECTED WITH IT IN THE MOST EXTRAORDINARY AND DANGEROUS ISOLATION AS A SAINT FOR IT IS JUST HOLINESS THE HIGHEST SPIRITUALIZATION OF THE INSTINCT IN QUESTION
whisper_text: The highest instinct for purity places him who is affected with it in the most extraordinary and dangerous isolation as a saint. For it is just holiness, the highest spiritualization of the instinct in question.

text: BUT YOU MISUNDERSTAND HIM WHEN YOU COMPLAIN ABOUT IT
whisper_text: but you must understand him when you complain about it.

text: IN FACT CONFORMABLY TO THE SLOW RISE OF THE DEMOCRATIC SOCIAL ORDER AND ITS CAUSE THE BLENDING OF THE BLOOD OF MASTERS AND SLAVES THE ORIGINALLY NOBLE AND RARE IMPULSE OF THE MASTERS TO ASSIGN A VALUE TO THEMSELVES AND TO THINK WELL OF THEMSELVES WILL NOW BE MORE AND MORE ENCOURAGED AND EXTENDED BUT IT HAS AT ALL TIMES AN OLDER AMPLER AND MORE RADICALLY INGRAINED PROPENSITY OPPOSED TO IT AND IN THE PHENOMENON OF VANITY THIS OLDER PROPENSITY OVERMASTERS THE YOUNGER
whisper_text: In fact, conformably to the slow rise of the democratic social order and its cause, the blending of the blood of masters and slaves, the original noble and rare impulse of the masters to assign a value to themselves and to think well of themselves will now be more and more encouraged and extended. But it has at all times an older, ample and more radically ingrained propensity opposed to it, and in the phenomenon of vanity this older propensity overmasters the younger.

text: HERE IS THE SEAT OF THE ORIGIN OF THE FAMOUS ANTITHESIS GOOD AND EVIL POWER AND DANGEROUSNESS ARE ASSUMED TO RESIDE IN THE EVIL A CERTAIN DREADFULNESS SUBTLETY AND STRENGTH WHICH DO NOT ADMIT OF BEING DESPISED
whisper_text: Here is the seat of the origin of the famous antithesis, good and evil. Power and dangerousness are assumed to reside in the evil, a certain dreadfulness, subtlety and strength which do not admit of being despised.

text: ACCORDING TO SLAVE MORALITY THEREFORE THE EVIL MAN AROUSES FEAR ACCORDING TO MASTER MORALITY IT IS PRECISELY THE GOOD MAN WHO AROUSES FEAR AND SEEKS TO AROUSE IT WHILE THE BAD MAN IS REGARDED AS THE DESPICABLE BEING
whisper_text: According to slave morality, therefore, the evil man arouses fear. According to master morality, it is precisely the good man who arouses fear and seeks to arouse it, while the bad man is regarded as the despicable being.

text: THE MOST VARIED EXPERIENCE TEACHES IT WHAT ARE THE QUALITIES TO WHICH IT PRINCIPALLY OWES THE FACT THAT IT STILL EXISTS IN SPITE OF ALL GODS AND MEN AND HAS HITHERTO BEEN VICTORIOUS THESE QUALITIES IT CALLS VIRTUES AND THESE VIRTUES ALONE IT DEVELOPS TO MATURITY
whisper_text: The most varied experience teaches it what are the qualities to which it principally owes the fact that it still exists, in spite of all gods and men, and has hitherto been victorious. These qualities, it calls virtues, and these virtues alone it develops to maturity.

text: THERE MUST BE A SORT OF REPUGNANCE IN ME TO BELIEVE ANYTHING DEFINITE ABOUT MYSELF IS THERE PERHAPS SOME ENIGMA THEREIN
whisper_text: There must be a sort of repuglance in me to believe anything definite about myself. Is there perhaps some enigma therein?

text: OCCASIONALLY TOO THE WAKING CALL COMES TOO LATE THE CHANCE WHICH GIVES PERMISSION TO TAKE ACTION WHEN THEIR BEST YOUTH AND STRENGTH FOR ACTION HAVE BEEN USED UP IN SITTING STILL AND HOW MANY A ONE JUST AS HE SPRANG UP HAS FOUND WITH HORROR THAT HIS LIMBS ARE BENUMBED AND HIS SPIRITS ARE NOW TOO HEAVY
whisper_text: Occasionally, to the waking call comes too late. The chance which gives permission to take action when their best youth and strength for action have been used up in sitting still, and how many of one just as he sprang up, has found with horror that his limbs are benumbed, and his spirits are now too heavy.

text: PROBABLY BUT FORTUNATELY NOTHING FOR MY OWN TEETH PERHAPS IT BETRAYS THE SPECIES TO WHICH I BELONG BUT NOT TO MYSELF AS IS SUFFICIENTLY AGREEABLE TO ME BUT WHAT HAS HAPPENED TO YOU
whisper_text: Probably, but fortunately nothing from my own teeth. Perhaps it betrays the species to which I belong, but not to myself as it is sufficiently agreeable to me. But what has happened to you?

text: A MAN'S ESTIMATES OF VALUE BETRAY SOMETHING OF THE STRUCTURE OF HIS SOUL AND WHEREIN IT SEES ITS CONDITIONS OF LIFE ITS INTRINSIC NEEDS
whisper_text: A man's estimates of value betray something of the structure of his soul, and wherein it sees its conditions of life, its intrinsic needs.

text: EVERYWHERE THAT SLAVE MORALITY GAINS THE ASCENDANCY LANGUAGE SHOWS A TENDENCY TO APPROXIMATE THE SIGNIFICATIONS OF THE WORDS GOOD AND STUPID
whisper_text: Everywhere that slave morality gains the ascendancy, language shows a tendency to approximate the significations of the word good and stupid.

text: AND WHOEVER THOU ART WHAT IS IT THAT NOW PLEASES THEE
whisper_text: And whoever thou art, what is it that now pleases thee?

text: HE HONOURS WHATEVER HE RECOGNIZES IN HIMSELF SUCH MORALITY EQUALS SELF GLORIFICATION
whisper_text: He honors whatever he recognizes in himself, such morality equals self-glorification.

text: VARIATIONS WHETHER THEY BE DEVIATIONS INTO THE HIGHER FINER AND RARER OR DETERIORATIONS AND MONSTROSITIES APPEAR SUDDENLY ON THE SCENE IN THE GREATEST EXUBERANCE AND SPLENDOUR THE INDIVIDUAL DARES TO BE INDIVIDUAL AND DETACH HIMSELF
whisper_text: Variations, whether they be deviations into the higher, finer, and rarer, or deteriorations and monstrosities, appear suddenly on the scene in the greatest exuberance and splendor. The individual dares to be individual and attach himself.

text: AT THIS TURNING POINT OF HISTORY THERE MANIFEST THEMSELVES SIDE BY SIDE AND OFTEN MIXED AND ENTANGLED TOGETHER A MAGNIFICENT MANIFOLD VIRGIN FOREST LIKE UP GROWTH AND UP STRIVING A KIND OF TROPICAL TEMPO IN THE RIVALRY OF GROWTH AND AN EXTRAORDINARY DECAY AND SELF DESTRUCTION OWING TO THE SAVAGELY OPPOSING AND SEEMINGLY EXPLODING EGOISMS WHICH STRIVE WITH ONE ANOTHER FOR SUN AND LIGHT AND CAN NO LONGER ASSIGN ANY LIMIT RESTRAINT OR FORBEARANCE FOR THEMSELVES BY MEANS OF THE HITHERTO EXISTING MORALITY
whisper_text: At this turning point of history, there manifest themselves, side by side, and often mixed and entangled together, a magnificent, manifold, virgin-forest-like, upgrowth, and upstriving, a kind of tropical tempo in the rivalry of growth, and an extraordinary decay and self-destruction, owing to the savagely opposing and seemingly exploding egoisms, which strive with one another for sun and light, and can no longer assign any limit restraint or forbearance for themselves by means of the hitherto existing morality.

text: PROBABLY A PESSIMISTIC SUSPICION WITH REGARD TO THE ENTIRE SITUATION OF MAN WILL FIND EXPRESSION PERHAPS A CONDEMNATION OF MAN TOGETHER WITH HIS SITUATION
whisper_text: Probably a pessimistic suspicion with regard to the entire situation of man will find expression, perhaps a condemnation of man, together with his situation.

text: ONLY NAME IT WHATEVER I HAVE I OFFER THEE
whisper_text: Only name it, whatever I have I ask for thee.

text: OR HE WILL EVEN SAY FOR MANY REASONS I CAN DELIGHT IN THE GOOD OPINION OF OTHERS PERHAPS BECAUSE I LOVE AND HONOUR THEM AND REJOICE IN ALL THEIR JOYS PERHAPS ALSO BECAUSE THEIR GOOD OPINION ENDORSES AND STRENGTHENS MY BELIEF IN MY OWN GOOD OPINION PERHAPS BECAUSE THE GOOD OPINION OF OTHERS EVEN IN CASES WHERE I DO NOT SHARE IT IS USEFUL TO ME OR GIVES PROMISE OF USEFULNESS ALL THIS HOWEVER IS NOT VANITY
whisper_text: Or he will even say, for many reasons I can delight in the good opinion of others, perhaps because I love and honor them, and rejoice in all their joys. Perhaps also because their good opinion endorses and strengthens my belief in my own good opinion. Perhaps because the good opinion of others, even in cases where I do not share it, is useful to me, or gives promise of usefulness. All this, however, is not vanity.

text: PROFOUND SUFFERING MAKES NOBLE IT SEPARATES ONE OF THE MOST REFINED FORMS OF DISGUISE IS EPICURISM ALONG WITH A CERTAIN OSTENTATIOUS BOLDNESS OF TASTE WHICH TAKES SUFFERING LIGHTLY AND PUTS ITSELF ON THE DEFENSIVE AGAINST ALL THAT IS SORROWFUL AND PROFOUND
whisper_text: Profound suffering makes noble. It separates. One of the most refined forms of disguise is Epicurism, along with a certain ostentatious boldness of taste, which takes suffering lightly and puts itself on the defensive against all that is sorrowful and profound.

text: I DO NOT KNOW HE SAID HESITATINGLY PERHAPS THE HARPIES HAVE FLOWN OVER MY TABLE
whisper_text: I do not know, he said, as attatingly, perhaps the harpies have flown over my table.

text: WE TRUTHFUL ONES THE NOBILITY IN ANCIENT GREECE CALLED THEMSELVES
whisper_text: We truthful ones, the nobility in ancient Greece called themselves,

text: NOTHING BUT NEW WHYS NOTHING BUT NEW HOWS NO COMMON FORMULAS ANY LONGER MISUNDERSTANDING AND DISREGARD IN LEAGUE WITH EACH OTHER DECAY DETERIORATION AND THE LOFTIEST DESIRES FRIGHTFULLY ENTANGLED THE GENIUS OF THE RACE OVERFLOWING FROM ALL THE CORNUCOPIAS OF GOOD AND BAD A PORTENTOUS SIMULTANEOUSNESS OF SPRING AND AUTUMN FULL OF NEW CHARMS AND MYSTERIES PECULIAR TO THE FRESH STILL INEXHAUSTED STILL UNWEARIED CORRUPTION
whisper_text: Nothing but new wise, nothing but new howls, no common formulas any longer, misunderstanding and disregard in league with each other, decay, deterioration, and the loftiest desires frightfully entangled, the genius of the race overflowing from all the conucopias of good and bad, a portentious simultaneousness of spring and autumn, full of new charms and mysteries peculiar to the fresh, still exhausted, still unwirried corruption.

text: TO SUFFOCATE WITH HIS MEMORIES TO HIM WHO HAS THE DESIRES OF A LOFTY AND DAINTY SOUL AND ONLY SELDOM FINDS HIS TABLE LAID AND HIS FOOD PREPARED THE DANGER WILL ALWAYS BE GREAT NOWADAYS HOWEVER IT IS EXTRAORDINARILY SO
whisper_text: to suffocate with his memories. To him who has the desires of a lofty and dainty soul and only seldom finds his table-aid and his food prepared, the danger will always be great. Nowadays, however, it is extraordinarily so.

text: ALSO IN ALL LOVES AND FRIENDSHIPS ONE HAS THE EXPERIENCE THAT NOTHING OF THE KIND CONTINUES WHEN THE DISCOVERY HAS BEEN MADE THAT IN USING THE SAME WORDS ONE OF THE TWO PARTIES HAS FEELINGS THOUGHTS INTUITIONS WISHES OR FEARS DIFFERENT FROM THOSE OF THE OTHER
whisper_text: Also, in all loves and friendships, one has the experience that nothing of the kind continues when the discovery has been made that in using the same words, one of the two parties has feelings, thoughts, intuitions, wishes, or fears, different from those of the other.

text: IN OUR VERY DEMOCRATIC OR RATHER VERY PLEBEIAN AGE EDUCATION AND CULTURE MUST BE ESSENTIALLY THE ART OF DECEIVING DECEIVING WITH REGARD TO ORIGIN WITH REGARD TO THE INHERITED PLEBEIANISM IN BODY AND SOUL
whisper_text: In our very democratic or rather very plebeian age, education and culture must be essentially the art of deceiving, deceiving with regard to origin, with regard to the inherited plebeianism in body and soul.

text: THE NOBLE SOUL ACCEPTS THE FACT OF HIS EGOISM WITHOUT QUESTION AND ALSO WITHOUT CONSCIOUSNESS OF HARSHNESS CONSTRAINT OR ARBITRARINESS THEREIN BUT RATHER AS SOMETHING THAT MAY HAVE ITS BASIS IN THE PRIMARY LAW OF THINGS IF HE SOUGHT A DESIGNATION FOR IT HE WOULD SAY IT IS JUSTICE ITSELF
whisper_text: The noble soul accepts the fact of his egoism without question, and also without consciousness of harshness, constraint, or arbitraryness therein. But rather, there is something that may have its basis in the primary law of things. If he sought a designation for it, he would say, it is justice itself.

text: WHICHEVER GROUPS OF SENSATIONS WITHIN A SOUL AWAKEN MOST READILY BEGIN TO SPEAK AND GIVE THE WORD OF COMMAND THESE DECIDE AS TO THE GENERAL ORDER OF RANK OF ITS VALUES AND DETERMINE ULTIMATELY ITS LIST OF DESIRABLE THINGS
whisper_text: Whichever groups of sensations within a soul awaken most readily, begin to speak and give the word of command, these decide as to the general order of rank of its values, and determine ultimately its list of desirable things.

text: AND TO CHOOSE FOR COMPANY THAT ROGUISH AND CHEERFUL VICE POLITENESS
whisper_text: and to choose for company that Rogus and Cheerful Vice Politeness.

text: DANGER IS AGAIN PRESENT THE MOTHER OF MORALITY GREAT DANGER THIS TIME SHIFTED INTO THE INDIVIDUAL INTO THE NEIGHBOUR AND FRIEND INTO THE STREET INTO THEIR OWN CHILD INTO THEIR OWN HEART INTO ALL THE MOST PERSONAL AND SECRET RECESSES OF THEIR DESIRES AND VOLITIONS
whisper_text: Danger is again present, the mother of morality great danger. This time shifted into the individual, into the neighbor and friend, into the street, into their own child, into their own heart, into all the most personal and secret recesses of their desires and volitions.

text: IT IS OBVIOUS THAT EVERYWHERE THE DESIGNATIONS OF MORAL VALUE WERE AT FIRST APPLIED TO MEN AND WERE ONLY DERIVATIVELY AND AT A LATER PERIOD APPLIED TO ACTIONS IT IS A GROSS MISTAKE THEREFORE WHEN HISTORIANS OF MORALS START WITH QUESTIONS LIKE WHY HAVE SYMPATHETIC ACTIONS BEEN PRAISED
whisper_text: It is obvious that everywhere the designations of moral value were at first applied to men, and were only derivatively and at a later period applied to actions. It is a gross mistake, therefore, when historians of morals start with questions like, why have sympathetic actions been praised?

text: ONE BLANKET WILL BE ENOUGH TO CARRY OR YOU MAY FOREGO THE PLEASURE AND BURDEN ALTOGETHER AS WOOD FOR FIRES IS EVERYWHERE ABUNDANT
whisper_text: One blanket will be enough to carry, or you may forego the pleasure and burden altogether, as wood for fires is everywhere abundant.

text: THE BIG MEADOWS LIE NEAR THE FOOT OF LASSEN'S BUTTE A BEAUTIFUL SPACIOUS BASIN SET IN THE HEART OF THE RICHLY FORESTED MOUNTAINS SCARCELY SURPASSED IN THE GRANDEUR OF ITS SURROUNDINGS BY TAHOE
whisper_text: The big meadows lie near the foot of Lassen's butte, a beautiful spacious basin set in the heart of the richly forested mountains, scarcely surpassed in the grandeur of its surroundings by Tahoe.

text: A THOUSAND THOUSAND VOICES ARE HEARD BUT SO FINELY BLENDED THEY SEEM A PART OF THE NIGHT ITSELF AND MAKE A DEEPER SILENCE
whisper_text: A thousand, thousand voices are heard. But so finally blended, they seem a part of the night itself, and make a deeper silence.

text: THEN FELL THE GLOAMING MAKING EVERYTHING STILL MORE FORBIDDING AND MYSTERIOUS
whisper_text: Then fell the gloaming, making everything still more forbidding and mysterious.

text: AT SUCH TIME ITS HEIGHT SEEMS MUCH LESS AS IF CROUCHING AND WEARY IT WERE TAKING REST
whisper_text: At such time, its height seems much less, as if crouching and weary, it were taking rest.

text: THEY ARE BROAD RUGGED CREVASSED CLOUDLIKE MASSES OF DOWN GRINDING ICE POURING FORTH STREAMS OF MUDDY WATER AS MEASURES OF THE WORK THEY ARE DOING IN SCULPTURING THE ROCKS BENEATH THEM VERY UNLIKE THE LONG MAJESTIC GLACIERS OF ALASKA THAT RIVERLIKE GO WINDING DOWN THE VALLEYS THROUGH THE FORESTS TO THE SEA
whisper_text: They were broad, rugged, crevast, cloud-like masses of downgrinding ice, pouring forth streams of muddy water as measures of the work they are doing and sculpturing the rocks beneath them. Very unlike the long majestic glaciers of Alaska, that river-like go winding down the valleys through the forests to the sea.

text: WHILE TRAVELING WITH A COMPANY OF HUNTERS I SAW ABOUT FIFTY IN ONE FLOCK
whisper_text: While traveling with a company of hunters, I saw about 50 in one flock.

text: LARGE FLOCKS DWELL HERE FROM YEAR TO YEAR WINTER AND SUMMER DESCENDING OCCASIONALLY INTO THE ADJACENT SAGE PLAINS AND LAVA BEDS TO FEED BUT EVER READY TO TAKE REFUGE IN THE JAGGED CRAGS OF THEIR MOUNTAIN AT EVERY ALARM
whisper_text: Large flocks dwell here from year to year, winter and summer, descending occasionally into the adjacent sage plains and lava beds to feed, but ever ready to take refuge in the jagged crags of their mountain and every alarm.

text: THE DUCKS LESS WARY KEPT THEIR PLACES MERELY SWIMMING IN AND OUT THROUGH OPENINGS IN THE RUSHES RIPPLING THE GLASSY WATER AND RAISING SPANGLES IN THEIR WAKE
whisper_text: The ducks, less wary, kept their places merely swimming in and out through openings in the rushes, rippling the glassy water and raising spangles in their wake.

text: YET STRANGE TO SAY THERE ARE DAYS EVEN HERE SOMEWHAT DULL LOOKING WHEN THE MOUNTAIN SEEMS UNCOMMUNICATIVE SENDING OUT NO APPRECIABLE INVITATION AS IF NOT AT HOME
whisper_text: Yet strange to say, there are days, even here, somewhat dull looking, when the mountain seems uncommunicative, sending out no appreciable invitation, as if not at home.

text: BUT NEITHER THE GLORIFIED WOODS ON THE ONE HAND NOR THE LAKE ON THE OTHER COULD AT FIRST HOLD THE EYE
whisper_text: But neither the glorified woods on the one hand, nor the lake on the other, could it first hold the eye.

text: THEN THE SHINING OF THE WET LEAVES IS DELIGHTFUL AND THE STEAMY FRAGRANCE AND THE BURST OF BIRD SONG FROM A MULTITUDE OF THRUSHES AND FINCHES AND WARBLERS THAT HAVE NESTS IN THE CHAPARRAL
whisper_text: Then the shining of the wet leaves is delightful, and the steamy fragrance and the burst of bird song from a multitude of thrushes and finches and warblers that have nests in the chaparral.

text: THE GREAT WILDS OF OUR COUNTRY ONCE HELD TO BE BOUNDLESS AND INEXHAUSTIBLE ARE BEING RAPIDLY INVADED AND OVERRUN IN EVERY DIRECTION AND EVERYTHING DESTRUCTIBLE IN THEM IS BEING DESTROYED
whisper_text: The great wilds of our country, once held to be boundless and inexhaustible, are being rapidly invaded and overrun in every direction, and everything destructible in them is being destroyed.

text: BUT IT IS FAR BETTER TO GO AFOOT
whisper_text: But it is far better to go a foot.

text: MOST OF THE DRAINAGE OF THE GLACIER VANISHES AT ONCE IN THE POROUS ROCKS TO REAPPEAR IN SPRINGS IN THE DISTANT VALLEY AND IT IS ONLY IN TIME OF FLOOD THAT THE CHANNEL CARRIES MUCH WATER THEN THERE ARE SEVERAL FINE FALLS IN THE GORGE SIX HUNDRED FEET OR MORE IN HEIGHT
whisper_text: Most of the drainage of the glacier vanishes at once in the porous rocks to appear in springs in the distant valley, and it is only in time of flood that the channel carries much water. Then there are several fine falls in the gorge, 600 feet or more in height.

text: SHOULD THE VOLUME OF THE STREAM WHERE YOU STRIKE IT SEEM SMALL THEN YOU WILL KNOW THAT YOU ARE ABOVE THE SPRING IF LARGE NEARLY EQUAL TO ITS VOLUME AT ITS CONFLUENCE WITH THE PITT RIVER THEN YOU ARE BELOW IT AND IN EITHER CASE HAVE ONLY TO FOLLOW THE RIVER UP OR DOWN UNTIL YOU COME TO IT
whisper_text: Should the volume of the stream where you strike it seems small, then you will know that you are above the spring. If large, nearly equal to its volume at its confluence with the pit river, then you are below it. And in either case, have only to follow the river up or down until you come to it.

text: MOUNT BREMER IS THE MOST NOTED STRONGHOLD OF THE SHEEP IN THE WHOLE SHASTA REGION
whisper_text: Mount Bremer is the most noted stronghold of the sheep in the whole Shasta region.

text: GO QUIETLY ALONE NO HARM WILL BEFALL YOU
whisper_text: Go quietly, alone. No harm will befall you.

text: THE ASCENT OF LASSEN'S BUTTE IS AN EASY WALK AND THE VIEWS FROM THE SUMMIT ARE EXTREMELY TELLING
whisper_text: The Ascent of Lassen's Bute is an easy walk, and the views from the summit are extremely telling.

text: IN APPROACHING IT ITS SUSPICIOUS LOOKING YELLOW SPOTTED HOOD AND WATCHFUL ATTITUDE WILL BE LIKELY TO MAKE YOU GO CAUTIOUSLY THROUGH THE BOG WHERE IT STANDS AS IF YOU WERE APPROACHING A DANGEROUS SNAKE
whisper_text: In approaching it, its suspicious-looking yellow-spotted hood and watchful attitude will be likely to make you go cautiously through the bog where it stands, as if you were approaching a dangerous snake.

text: TRACING RIVERS TO THEIR FOUNTAINS MAKES THE MOST CHARMING OF TRAVELS
whisper_text: Tracing rivers to their fountains makes the most charming of travels.

text: ASPLENIUM EPILOBIUM HEUCHERA HAZEL DOGWOOD AND ALDER MAKE A LUXURIOUS FRINGE AND SETTING AND THE FORESTS OF DOUGLAS SPRUCE ALONG THE BANKS ARE THE FINEST I HAVE EVER SEEN IN THE SIERRA
whisper_text: A splenium, epilobium, huchera, hazel, dogwood, and alder make a luxurious fringe and setting, and the forests of Douglas Bruce along the banks are the finest I have ever seen in this

text: IN SETTING OUT FROM STRAWBERRY VALLEY BY BEARING OFF TO THE NORTHWESTWARD A FEW MILES YOU MAY SEE
whisper_text: and setting out from Strawberry Valley by bearing off to the northwestward a few miles you may see.

text: THE LOFTY ICY SHASTA TOWERING HIGH ABOVE ALL SEEMS BUT AN HOUR'S WALK FROM YOU THOUGH THE DISTANCE IN AN AIR LINE IS ABOUT SIXTY MILES
whisper_text: The lofty icy shasta, towering high above all, seems but an hour's walk from you, though the distance in an airline is about 60 miles.

text: PERHAPS THE PROFESSION OF DOING GOOD MAY BE FULL BUT EVERY BODY SHOULD BE KIND AT LEAST TO HIMSELF
whisper_text: Perhaps the profession of doing good may be full, but everybody should be kind at least to himself.

text: HERE YOU STRIKE THE OLD EMIGRANT ROAD WHICH LEADS OVER THE LOW DIVIDE TO THE EASTERN SLOPES OF THE MOUNTAIN
whisper_text: Here you strike the old immigrant road, which leads over the low divide to the eastern slopes of the mountain.

text: THUS THE SHASTA RIVER ISSUES FROM A LARGE LAKE LIKE SPRING IN SHASTA VALLEY AND ABOUT TWO THIRDS OF THE VOLUME OF THE MC CLOUD GUSHES FORTH IN A GRAND SPRING ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN A FEW MILES BACK FROM ITS IMMEDIATE BASE
whisper_text: Thus the Shasta River issues from a large lake-like spring in Shasta Valley, and about two-thirds of the volume of the MacLeod gushes forth in a grand spring on the east side of the mountain, a few miles back from its immediate base.

text: THE LONG GRAY SLOPES LEADING UP TO THE GLACIER SEEM REMARKABLY SMOOTH AND UNBROKEN
whisper_text: The long grey slopes leading up to the glacier seem remarkably smooth and unbroken.

text: REGAINING THE LOW GROUND AT THE BASE OF THE MOUNTAIN AND HOLDING ON IN YOUR GRAND ORBIT YOU PASS THROUGH A BELT OF JUNIPER WOODS CALLED THE CEDARS TO SHEEP ROCK AT THE FOOT OF THE SHASTA PASS
whisper_text: Regaining the low ground at the base of the mountain and holding on in your grand orbit, you pass through a belt of Juniper Woods called the Seaters, to Sheeprock at the foot of the Shasta Pass.

text: THE VIVID GREEN OF THE BOULDERS BENEATH THE WATER IS VERY STRIKING AND COLORS THE ENTIRE STREAM WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE PORTIONS BROKEN INTO FOAM
whisper_text: The vivid green of the boulders beneath the water is very striking and colors the entire stream with the exception of the portions broken into foam.

text: IT IS THREE OR FOUR MILES LONG AND TERMINATES AT AN ELEVATION OF ABOUT NINE THOUSAND FIVE HUNDRED FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL IN MORAINE SPRINKLED ICE CLIFFS SIXTY FEET HIGH
whisper_text: It is three or four miles long and terminates at an elevation of about 9,500 feet above sea level. In moreane sprinkled ice cliffs, 60 feet high.

text: AS THE LIFE BLOOD OF THE LANDSCAPES THE BEST OF THE WILDERNESS COMES TO THEIR BANKS AND NOT ONE DULL PASSAGE IS FOUND IN ALL THEIR EVENTFUL HISTORIES
whisper_text: As the lifeblood of the landscapes, the best of the wilderness comes to their banks, and not one dull passage is found in all their eventful histories.

text: ARCTIC BEAUTY AND DESOLATION WITH THEIR BLESSINGS AND DANGERS ALL MAY BE FOUND HERE TO TEST THE ENDURANCE AND SKILL OF ADVENTUROUS CLIMBERS BUT FAR BETTER THAN CLIMBING THE MOUNTAIN IS GOING AROUND ITS WARM FERTILE BASE ENJOYING ITS BOUNTIES LIKE A BEE CIRCLING AROUND A BANK OF FLOWERS
whisper_text: Arctic beauty and desolation, with their blessings and dangers, all may be found here to test the endurance and skill of adventurous climbers. But far better than climbing the mountain is going around its warm, fertile base, enjoying its bounties like a bee circling around a bank of flowers.

text: SHASTA RAMBLES AND MODOC MEMORIES
whisper_text: Shaster Rambles and Modoc Memories.

text: TRACING THE MC CLOUD TO ITS HIGHEST SPRINGS AND OVER THE DIVIDE TO THE FOUNTAINS OF FALL RIVER NEAR FORT CROOK THENCE DOWN THAT RIVER TO ITS CONFLUENCE WITH THE PITT ON FROM THERE TO THE VOLCANIC REGION ABOUT LASSEN'S BUTTE THROUGH THE BIG MEADOWS AMONG THE SOURCES OF THE FEATHER RIVER AND DOWN THROUGH FORESTS OF SUGAR PINE TO THE FERTILE PLAINS OF CHICO THIS IS A GLORIOUS SAUNTER AND IMPOSES NO HARDSHIP
whisper_text: Tracing the Maccloud to its highest springs, and over the divide to the fountains of Fall River near Fort Crook, vents down that river to its confluence with the pit, on from there to the volcanic region about Lassen's Bute, through the big meadows among the sources of the Feather River, and down through forests of sugar pine to the fertile plains of Chico. This is a glorious saunter and imposes no hardship.

text: IT IS LINED WITH EMERALD ALGAE AND MOSSES AND SHADED WITH ALDER WILLOW AND THORN BUSHES WHICH GIVE IT A FINE SETTING
whisper_text: It is lined with emerald algae and mosses and shaded with alder, willow and thorn bushes, which give it a fine setting.

text: UNDER CERTAIN CONDITIONS YOU MAY HEAR THE ROAR OF THE WATER RUSHING FROM THE ROCK AT A DISTANCE OF HALF A MILE OR EVEN MORE OR YOU MAY NOT HEAR IT UNTIL WITHIN A FEW RODS
whisper_text: Under certain conditions, you may hear the roar of the water rushing from the rock at a distance of half a mile or even more. Or you may not hear it until within a few rods.

text: TRACING THIS WILD CHANGING CHANNEL GORGE GULLY OR CANYON THE SECTIONS WILL SHOW MOUNT SHASTA AS A HUGE PALIMPSEST CONTAINING THE RECORDS LAYER UPON LAYER OF STRANGELY CONTRASTED EVENTS IN ITS FIERY ICY HISTORY
whisper_text: Tracing this wild-changing channel gorge, Gully or Canyon, the sections will show Mount Shasta as a huge palimp zest, containing the records layer upon layer of strangely contrasted events in its fiery icy history.

text: SLIGHT RAINSTORMS ARE LIKELY TO BE ENCOUNTERED IN A TRIP ROUND THE MOUNTAIN BUT ONE MAY EASILY FIND SHELTER BENEATH WELL THATCHED TREES THAT SHED THE RAIN LIKE A ROOF
whisper_text: Slight rainstorms are likely to be encountered in a trip around the mountain, but one may easily find shelter beneath well-fetched trees that shed the rain like a roof.

text: EVERY LANDSCAPE LOW AND HIGH SEEMS DOOMED TO BE TRAMPLED AND HARRIED
whisper_text: Every landscape low and high seems doomed to be trampled and harried.

text: THUS ONE SAUNTERS ON AND ON IN THE GLORIOUS RADIANCE IN UTTER PEACE AND FORGETFULNESS OF TIME
whisper_text: Thus one's sulters on and on in the glorious radiance, in utter peace and forgetfulness of time.

text: THEIR LONG MASSIVE EARS GIVE THEM A VERY STRIKING APPEARANCE
whisper_text: their long, massive ears give them a very striking appearance.

text: TWO OR THREE MILES FARTHER ON IS THE MAIN STRONGHOLD OF THE MODOCS HELD BY THEM SO LONG AND DEFIANTLY AGAINST ALL THE SOLDIERS THAT COULD BE BROUGHT TO THE ATTACK
whisper_text: Two or three miles farther on is the main stronghold of the motox, held by them so long and defiantly against all the soldiers that could be brought to the attack.

text: THEN DARKNESS LIKE DEATH
whisper_text: then darkness like death.

text: THE MULE DEER ARE NEARLY AS HEAVY
whisper_text: The mule deer are nearly as heavy.

text: ONLY A LITTLE FOOD WILL BE REQUIRED
whisper_text: Only a little food will be required.

text: EVERY CRYSTAL DANCES RESPONSIVE TO THE TOUCHES OF THE SUN AND CURRENTS OF SAP IN THE GROWING CELLS OF ALL THE VEGETATION ARE EVER IN A VITAL WHIRL AND RUSH AND THOUGH MANY FEET AND WINGS ARE FOLDED HOW MANY ARE ASTIR
whisper_text: Every crystal dances responsive to the touches of the sun, and the currents of sap in the growing cells of all the vegetation are ever in a vital whirl and rush, and though many feet and wings are folded, how many are a stir?

text: BECAUSE HE TALKED SO LITTLE HIS WORDS HAD A PECULIAR FORCE THEY WERE NOT WORN DULL FROM CONSTANT USE
whisper_text: Because he talked so little, his words had a peculiar force. They were not worn dull from constant use.

text: HE GAVE THANKS FOR OUR FOOD AND COMFORT AND PRAYED FOR THE POOR AND DESTITUTE IN GREAT CITIES WHERE THE STRUGGLE FOR LIFE WAS HARDER THAN IT WAS HERE WITH US
whisper_text: He gave thanks for our food and comfort, and prayed for the poor and destitute in great cities, where the struggle for life was harder than it was here with us.

text: AT ABOUT FOUR O'CLOCK A VISITOR APPEARED MISTER SHIMERDA WEARING HIS RABBIT SKIN CAP AND COLLAR AND NEW MITTENS HIS WIFE HAD KNITTED
whisper_text: At about four o'clock, a visitor appeared. Mr. Shamirda, wearing his rabbit skin cap and collar, and new mittens, his wife had knitted.

text: HE MADE THE SIGN OF THE CROSS OVER ME PUT ON HIS CAP AND WENT OFF IN THE DARK
whisper_text: He made the sign of the cross over me, put on his cap and went off in the dark.

text: ALL AFTERNOON HE SAT IN THE DINING ROOM
whisper_text: All afternoon he sat in the dining room.

text: HIS FACE HAD A LOOK OF WEARINESS AND PLEASURE LIKE THAT OF SICK PEOPLE WHEN THEY FEEL RELIEF FROM PAIN
whisper_text: His face had a look of weariness and pleasure like that of sick people when they feel relief from pain

text: HE SAT STILL AND PASSIVE HIS HEAD RESTING AGAINST THE BACK OF THE WOODEN ROCKING CHAIR HIS HANDS RELAXED UPON THE ARMS
whisper_text: He sat still and a passive, his head resting against the back of the wooden rocking chair, his hands relaxed upon the arms.

text: MORNING PRAYERS WERE LONGER THAN USUAL
whisper_text: Morning prayers were longer than usual.

text: GRANDFATHER CAME DOWN WEARING A WHITE SHIRT AND HIS SUNDAY COAT
whisper_text: grandfather came down wearing a white shirt and his Sunday coat.

text: WHEN HE MOUNTED HIS HORSE AT THE DOOR I SAW THAT HE HAD A HATCHET SLUNG TO HIS BELT AND HE GAVE GRANDMOTHER A MEANING LOOK WHICH TOLD ME HE WAS PLANNING A SURPRISE FOR ME
whisper_text: When he mounted his horse at the door, I saw that he had a hatchet slung to his belt, and he gave grandmother a meaning look, which told me he was planning a surprise for me.

text: FROM UNDER THE LINING HE NOW PRODUCED A COLLECTION OF BRILLIANTLY COLORED PAPER FIGURES SEVERAL INCHES HIGH AND STIFF ENOUGH TO STAND ALONE
whisper_text: From under the lining he now produced a collection of brilliantly colored paper figures, several inches high and stiff enough to stand alone.

text: BY THE TIME WE HAD PLACED THE COLD FRESH SMELLING LITTLE TREE IN A CORNER OF THE SITTING ROOM IT WAS ALREADY CHRISTMAS EVE
whisper_text: By the time we had placed the cold, fresh-smelling little tree in a corner of the sitting room, it was already Christmas Eve.

text: ON THE WHITE PAGES I GROUPED SUNDAY SCHOOL CARDS AND ADVERTISING CARDS WHICH I HAD BROUGHT FROM MY OLD COUNTRY
whisper_text: On the white pages I grouped Sunday school cards and advertising cards which I had brought from my old country.

text: SHE CUT SQUARES OF COTTON CLOTH AND WE SEWED THEM TOGETHER INTO A BOOK
whisper_text: She cuts squares of cotton cloth and we sewed them together into a book.

text: I HAD WANTED TO GET SOME PICTURE BOOKS FOR YULKA AND ANTONIA EVEN YULKA WAS ABLE TO READ A LITTLE NOW
whisper_text: I had wanted to get some picture books for Yulka and Antonia. Even Yulka was able to read a little now.

text: ANYWAY HE WOULD NEVER ALLOW ONE OF HIS HORSES TO BE PUT TO SUCH A STRAIN
whisper_text: Anyway, he would never allow one of his horses to be put to such a strain.

text: THEY SAT ABOUT THE HOUSE MOST OF THE DAY AS IF IT WERE SUNDAY GREASING THEIR BOOTS MENDING THEIR SUSPENDERS PLAITING WHIPLASHES
whisper_text: They sought about the house most of the day, as if it were Sunday, greasing their boots, mending their suspenders, plating whiplashes.

text: HE USED TO HELP MY FATHER CUT CHRISTMAS TREES FOR ME IN VIRGINIA AND HE HAD NOT FORGOTTEN HOW MUCH I LIKED THEM
whisper_text: He used to help my father cut Christmas trees for me in Virginia, and he had not forgotten how much I liked them.

text: I CAN SEE THEM NOW EXACTLY AS THEY LOOKED WORKING ABOUT THE TABLE IN THE LAMPLIGHT JAKE WITH HIS HEAVY FEATURES SO RUDELY MOULDED THAT HIS FACE SEEMED SOMEHOW UNFINISHED OTTO WITH HIS HALF EAR AND THE SAVAGE SCAR THAT MADE HIS UPPER LIP CURL SO FEROCIOUSLY UNDER HIS TWISTED MUSTACHE
whisper_text: I can see them now, exactly as they looked, working about the table in the lamp light. Jake with his heavy features so rudely molded that his face seemed somehow unfinished. Otto with his half ear and the savage scar that made his upper lip curl so ferociously under his twisted moustache.

text: I PUT ON MY CAP AND RAN OUT TO MEET JAKE
whisper_text: I put on my cap and ran out to meet Jake.

text: IT WAS THE FIRST TIME MISSUS SHIMERDA HAD BEEN TO OUR HOUSE AND SHE RAN ABOUT EXAMINING OUR CARPETS AND CURTAINS AND FURNITURE ALL THE WHILE COMMENTING UPON THEM TO HER DAUGHTER IN AN ENVIOUS COMPLAINING TONE
whisper_text: It was the first time Mrs. Shemerda had been to our house, and she ran about examining our carpets and curtains and furniture, all the while commenting upon them to her daughter in an envious complaining tone.

text: THE WEEK FOLLOWING CHRISTMAS BROUGHT IN A THAW AND BY NEW YEAR'S DAY ALL THE WORLD ABOUT US WAS A BROTH OF GRAY SLUSH AND THE GUTTERED SLOPE BETWEEN THE WINDMILL AND THE BARN WAS RUNNING BLACK WATER
whisper_text: The week following Christmas brought in a thaw, and by New Year's Day all the world about us was a broth of grey slush, and the guttered slope between the windmill and the barn was running black water.

text: YOU'VE GOT A BIRTHDAY PRESENT THIS TIME JIM AND NO MISTAKE
whisper_text: You've got a birthday present this time, Jim, in no mistake.

text: THEY BEGAN TO LAUGH BOISTEROUSLY WHEN THEY SAW ME CALLING
whisper_text: They began to laugh boisterously when they saw me calling.

text: BUT YOU SEE A BODY NEVER KNOWS WHAT TRAITS POVERTY MIGHT BRING OUT IN EM
whisper_text: But you see, a lot he never knows what trait's poverty might bring out in him.

text: FOR AMBROSCH MY MAMA COME HERE
whisper_text: For Ambrose, my mama come here.

text: YOUR MAMA I SAID ANGRILY WANTS OTHER PEOPLE'S THINGS
whisper_text: Your mama, I said angrily wants other people's things.

text: WISHING HIM SAID MARY IN A TONE OF INQUIRY
whisper_text: Wishing him said Mary in a tone of inquiry.

text: SHE OPENED THE DOOR SOFTLY THERE SAT MISSUS WILSON IN THE OLD ROCKING CHAIR WITH ONE SICK DEATH LIKE BOY LYING ON HER KNEE CRYING WITHOUT LET OR PAUSE BUT SOFTLY GENTLY AS FEARING TO DISTURB THE TROUBLED GASPING CHILD WHILE BEHIND HER OLD ALICE LET HER FAST DROPPING TEARS FALL DOWN ON THE DEAD BODY OF THE OTHER TWIN WHICH SHE WAS LAYING OUT ON A BOARD PLACED ON A SORT OF SOFA SETTEE IN A CORNER OF THE ROOM
whisper_text: She opened the door softly. There sat Mrs. Wilson in the old rocking-chair. With one sick, death-like boy lying on her knee, crying without let or pause. But softly, gently, as fearing to disturb the troubled gasping child while behind her, old Alice let her fast-dropping tears fall down on the dead body of the other twin, which she was laying out on a board-placed, on a sort of sofa-sati in the corner of the room.

text: BUT WILL HE THANK ME FOR IT
whisper_text: but will he think before it?

text: BUT THE BEST OF HER PLANS THE HOLIEST THAT WHICH IN SOME MEASURE REDEEMED THE VANITY OF THE REST WERE THOSE RELATING TO HER FATHER HER DEAR FATHER NOW OPPRESSED WITH CARE AND ALWAYS A DISHEARTENED GLOOMY PERSON
whisper_text: But the best of her plans, the holiest, that which in some measure redeemed the vanity of the rest, were those relating to her father, her dear father. Now pressed with care and always a disheartened gloomy person.

text: THERE WAS SOMETHING OF KEEN PRACTICAL SHREWDNESS ABOUT HER WHICH CONTRASTED VERY BEWITCHINGLY WITH THE SIMPLE FOOLISH UNWORLDLY IDEAS SHE HAD PICKED UP FROM THE ROMANCES WHICH MISS SIMMONDS YOUNG LADIES WERE IN THE HABIT OF RECOMMENDING TO EACH OTHER YES
whisper_text: There was something of keen, practical shrewdness about her, which contrasted very bewitchingly with the simple, foolish, unwirldly ideas she had picked up from the romances which Miss Simmons young ladies were in the habit of recommending to each other. Yes.

text: OVER THE CHILD WHICH YET BREATHED THE FATHER BENT WATCHING ANXIOUSLY FOR SOME GROUND OF HOPE WHERE HOPE THERE WAS NONE
whisper_text: Over the child which yet breathed the Father bent, watching anxiously for some ground of hope where hope there was none.

text: THEN THE MOTHER LIFTED UP HER VOICE AND WEPT
whisper_text: Then the mother lifted up her voice and wept.

text: MARY I ALMOST LOATHE MYSELF WHEN I FEEL I WOULD NOT GIVE UP THIS MINUTE WHEN MY BROTHERS LIE DEAD AND FATHER AND MOTHER ARE IN SUCH TROUBLE FOR ALL MY LIFE THAT'S PAST AND GONE AND MARY AS SHE TRIED TO RELEASE HER HAND YOU KNOW WHAT MAKES ME FEEL SO BLESSED
whisper_text: Mary, I almost loathed myself when I feel I would not give up this minute when my brothers lie dead and father and mother are in such trouble for all my life that's passed and gone and Mary, as she tried to release her hand. You know what makes me feel so blessed.

text: BUT HE STAYED LONG THERE AND AT LAST HIS STURDY FRAME SHOOK WITH HIS STRONG AGONY
whisper_text: But he stayed long there and at last his sturdy frame shook with his strong agony.

text: HOW INFINITE THE WEALTH OF LOVE AND HOPE GARNERED IN THESE SAME TINY TREASURE HOUSES AND OH
whisper_text: How infinite the wealth of love and hope garnered in these same tiny treasure houses and oh.

text: WHAT BANKRUPTS IN THE WORLD WE FEEL WHEN DEATH LIKE SOME REMORSELESS CREDITOR SEIZES ON ALL WE FONDLY THOUGHT OUR OWN THE TWINS
whisper_text: What bankrupts in the world we feel when death, like some remorseless creditor ceases on all we fondly thought our own? The twins.

text: OH JEM DON'T GIVE WAY SO I CANNOT BEAR TO SEE YOU
whisper_text: Oh, Gem, don't give way, so I cannot bear to see you.

text: HE REMAINED UP STAIRS UNTIL AFTER THE EARLY DAWN SHOWED MARY THAT SHE NEED HAVE NO FEAR OF GOING HOME THROUGH THE DESERTED AND QUIET STREETS TO TRY AND GET A LITTLE SLEEP BEFORE WORK HOUR
whisper_text: He remained upstairs until after the early dawn showed Mary that she need have no fear of going home through the deserted and quiet streets to try and get a little sleep before work hour.

text: HE DID NOT SPEAK AS THOUGH FEARING TO DESTROY BY SOUND OR MOTION THE HAPPINESS OF THAT MOMENT WHEN HER SOFT HAND'S TOUCH THRILLED THROUGH HIS FRAME AND HER SILVERY VOICE WAS WHISPERING TENDERNESS IN HIS EAR
whisper_text: He did not speak, as though fearing to destroy by sound or motion the happiness of that moment when her soft hands touched thrilled through his frame, and her silvery voice was whispering tenderness in his ear.

text: SO LEAVING KIND MESSAGES TO GEORGE AND JANE WILSON AND HESITATING WHETHER SHE MIGHT DARE TO SEND A FEW KIND WORDS TO JEM AND DECIDING THAT SHE HAD BETTER NOT SHE STEPPED OUT INTO THE BRIGHT MORNING LIGHT SO FRESH A CONTRAST TO THE DARKENED ROOM WHERE DEATH HAD BEEN
whisper_text: So leaving kind messages to George and Jane Wilson, and hesitating whether she might dare to send a few kind words to Jim, and deciding that she had better not. She stepped out into the bright morning light, so fresh a contrast to the darkened room where death had been.

text: THE GHOUL LIKE FEVER WAS NOT TO BE BRAVED WITH IMPUNITY AND BAULKED OF ITS PREY
whisper_text: The ghoul-like fever was not to be braved with impunity, and barked of its prey.

text: THEN ALICE BROKE THE SILENCE BY SAYING
whisper_text: Then Alice broke the silence by saying,

text: AFORE CHRISTMAS TIME I WAS AS FULL AS FULL COULD BE OF GOING HOME FOR GOOD AND ALL YO HAN HEARD HOW I'VE WISHED IT THIS TERRIBLE LONG TIME
whisper_text: For Christmas time I was as full as full could be of going home for good and all. You and heard how I've wished it this terrible long time.

text: THE BOARD NOT SO FORMIDABLE AS SHE HAD IMAGINED HAD INQUIRED INTO HER CASE AND INSTEAD OF SENDING HER TO STOKE CLAYPOLE HER HUSBAND'S BUCKINGHAMSHIRE PARISH AS SHE HAD DREADED HAD AGREED TO PAY HER RENT
whisper_text: The board, not so formidable as she had imagined, had inquired into her case, and, instead of sending her to stoke clay-pull, her husband's buckeom-shire-parish, as she had dreaded, had agreed to pay her rent.

text: HER THOUGHTS RAN ON JEM'S MANNER AND WORDS NOT BUT WHAT SHE HAD KNOWN THE TALE THEY TOLD FOR MANY A DAY BUT STILL SHE WISHED HE HAD NOT PUT IT SO PLAINLY
whisper_text: Her thoughts ran on Jim's manner in words, not but what she had known the tale they told for many a day, but still she wished he had not put it so plainly.

whisper_text: Don't, Jim, please. Don't whispered she again, believing that his silence was only another form of grief.

whisper_text: And now that it hath pleased her to deny me this, love my master of his great goodness, hath placed all my beattitude there, where my hope will not fail me.

whisper_text: But when I still speak not, one of them, who before had been talking with another, addressed me by my name, saying, to what end love has to vow this lady, saying that thou can't not support her presence.

whisper_text: The second part is divided into two. Four, and the first, I speak of her as regards the nobleness of her soul, relating some of her virtues proceeding from her soul. text: IN THE SECOND I TELL WHAT IS UNDERSTOOD OF HER ON EARTH HERE MY LADY IS DESIRED
whisper_text: In the second, I tell what is understood of her on earth. Here, my lady is desired.

whisper_text: And I declare that when I speak thereof, love sheds such perfect sweetness over me, that if my courage failed not, certainly, to him my listeners must be all resigned.

whisper_text: The second begins here, an angel. The third here, dear song, I know.

whisper_text: So to the road thou shalt be reconciled, and find the Lady, and with the Lady, love.

whisper_text: Then those ladies began to talk closely together, and as I have seen snow fall among the rain, so was their talk mingled with size.

text: IN THE FOURTH REPEATING TO WHOM I PURPOSE SPEAKING I TELL THE REASON WHY I SPEAK TO THEM
whisper_text: and the fourth, repeating to whom my purpose speaking, I tell the reason why I speak to them.

text: IN THE THIRD I SAY WHAT IT IS I PURPOSE TO SPEAK SO AS NOT TO BE IMPEDED BY FAINTHEARTEDNESS
whisper_text: In the third, I say what it is I purpose to speak so as not to be impeded by faintheartedness.

text: THE FIRST PART IS DIVIDED INTO FOUR

whisper_text: Whatever her sweet eyes are turned upon, spirits of love do issue thence and flame, which, through their eyes who then may look on them, pierce to the hard-steep chamber everyone.

whisper_text: which thing being thus there came a day when certain ladies to whom it was well known, they haven't been with me at diverse times in my trouble. We're met together for the pleasure of gentle company.

whisper_text: Thereafter, this sonnet bred in me desire to write down in verse four other things touching my condition, the which things it seemed to me that I had not yet made manifest.

whisper_text: A word should be said here of the title of Dante's autobiography.

whisper_text: On January 25 he wrote, many and many thanks for a most essential service most thoroughly performed.

text: AND IF YOU HAVE TIME IT WOULD BE A GREAT SERVICE TO TRANSLATE THE ANALYSES OF THE POEMS WHICH I OMITTED
whisper_text: And if you have time, it would be a great service to translate the analyses of the poem which I admitted.

text: THROUGHOUT THE VITA NUOVA THERE IS A STRAIN LIKE THE FIRST FALLING MURMUR WHICH REACHES THE EAR IN SOME REMOTE MEADOW AND PREPARES US TO LOOK UPON THE SEA
whisper_text: Throughout the Vita Nuava there is a strain like the first falling murmur which reaches the ear in some remote meadow and prepares us to look upon the sea.

text: THIS BOOK IN ITS ORIGINAL FORM WAS RECEIVED WITH FAVOUR AND SETTLED THE CLAIM OF ROSSETTI TO RANK AS A POETIC TRANSLATOR OR INDEED AS A POET IN HIS OWN RIGHT
whisper_text: This book in its original form was received with favor and settled the claim of Rosetti to rank as a poetic translator or indeed as a poet in his own right.

text: HE TRANSLATED AT AN EARLY AGE CHIEFLY BETWEEN EIGHTEEN FORTY FIVE AND EIGHTEEN FORTY NINE A GREAT NUMBER OF POEMS BY THE ITALIANS CONTEMPORARY WITH DANTE OR PRECEDING HIM AND AMONG OTHER THINGS HE MADE A VERSION OF THE WHOLE VITA NUOVA PROSE AND VERSE
whisper_text: He translated it in early age, chiefly between 1845 and 1849, a great number of poems by the Italians contemporary with Dante or preceding him, and, among other things, he made a version of the whole Vittanova, prose and verse.

text: THE ONLY TRUE MOTIVE FOR PUTTING POETRY INTO A FRESH LANGUAGE MUST BE TO ENDOW A FRESH NATION AS FAR AS POSSIBLE WITH ONE MORE POSSESSION OF BEAUTY
whisper_text: The only true motive for putting poetry into a fresh language must be to endow a fresh nation as far as possible with one more possession of beauty.

text: THE LIFE BLOOD OF RHYTHMICAL TRANSLATION IS THIS COMMANDMENT THAT A GOOD POEM SHALL NOT BE TURNED INTO A BAD ONE
whisper_text: The lifeblood of rhythmical translation is this commandment that a good poem shall not be turned into a bad one.

text: IT IS THEREFORE AND ON ALL ACCOUNTS UNNECESSARY TO SAY MUCH MORE OF THE WORK HERE THAN IT SAYS FOR ITSELF
whisper_text: It is therefore, and on all accounts, unnecessary to say much more of the work here, than it says for itself.

text: OFTEN WOULD HE AVAIL HIMSELF OF ANY SPECIAL GRACE OF HIS OWN IDIOM AND EPOCH IF ONLY HIS WILL BELONGED TO HIM OFTEN WOULD SOME CADENCE SERVE HIM BUT FOR HIS AUTHOR'S STRUCTURE SOME STRUCTURE BUT FOR HIS AUTHOR'S CADENCE OFTEN THE BEAUTIFUL TURN OF A STANZA MUST BE WEAKENED TO ADOPT SOME RHYME WHICH WILL TALLY AND HE SEES THE POET REVELLING IN ABUNDANCE OF LANGUAGE WHERE HIMSELF IS SCANTILY SUPPLIED
whisper_text: Often would he avail himself of any special grace of his own idiom and epoch if only his will belonged to him. Often would some cadence serve him, but for his author's structure, some structure but for his author's cadence. Often the beautiful turn of a stanza must be weakened to adopt some rhyme which will tally, and he sees the poet reveling in abundance of language where himself is scantily supplied.

text: THIS HAS INDUCED SOME EDITORS OF THE VITA NUOVA TO EXPLAIN THE TITLE AS MEANING EARLY LIFE
whisper_text: This has induced some editors of the Vita Nova to explain the title as meaning early life.

text: POETRY NOT BEING AN EXACT SCIENCE LITERALITY OF RENDERING IS ALTOGETHER SECONDARY TO THIS CHIEF LAW
whisper_text: Poetry not being an exact science, the derality of rendering is altogether secondary to this chief law.

text: MY NOTES WHICH YOU HAVE TAKEN THE TROUBLE OF REVISING ARE OF COURSE QUITE PALTRY AND USELESS

text: THESE WILDERING PHANTASIES THEN CARRIED ME TO SEE MY LADY DEAD

whisper_text: And in his speech he laughed and laughed again, then, while it was his pleasure to remain, I chanced to look the way he had drawn near, and saw the ladies' Joan and Beatrice approach me. This the other following, one in a second marvel instantly.

whisper_text: Then saw I, many broken hinted sights, in the uncertain state I stepped into.

whisper_text: and so strong was my fantasy that I wept again in very truth and said with my true voice, oh excellent soul, how blessed is he that now look at the pondy?

whisper_text: And at the first it seemed to me that I saw certain faces of women with their hair loosened, which called out to me, They'll shout, surely die. After the witch, other terrible and unknown appearances, said unto me, thou art dead.

whisper_text: when being aroused I opened my eyes and knew that it had been a deception.

whisper_text: where by other ladies who were about the room, becoming aware of my discomfort by reason of the moan that she made, who, indeed, was of my very near kindred, led her away from where I was, and then set themselves to awaken me, thinking that I dreamed and sang, sleepin' along her and be not disquieted.

whisper_text: And therewith all such a bewilderment possessed me, that I shut my eyes for peace. And in my brain did cease order of thought and every healthful thing.

whisper_text: This lady's right name was Joan, but because of her comeliness, or at least it was so imagined, she was called of many primavera, spring, and went by that name among them.

whisper_text: In my hew was such that they looked at each other and thought of death, saying under their breath, most tenderly, O let us comfort him. Then unto me, what dream was thine that it hath shaken thee so much?

whisper_text: That penance hath no blame, which Magdalene found sweet, purging our shame. Self-punishment is virtue, all men know.

whisper_text: Heaven helped that body, which a little mind housed in a head lacking ears, tongue, and eyes, and senseless but for smell can tyrannize.

whisper_text: The people is a beast of muddy brain that knows not its own force and therefore stands loaded with wood and stone, the powerless hands of a mere child guided with bit and rain. whisper_text: Well too if he, like love, would filter our horde, with pleasure to ourselves, sluicing our vein and vigor to perpetuate the strain of life by spilth of life within us stored.

whisper_text: Quinci impara astupirti.

whisper_text: He lives thy loss. He dies from every limb mangled by thee, lightening of Godhead shine, from which thy darkness hath not where to hide.

whisper_text: who may condemn his superstition.

text: THE SAVAGE PHILOSOPHER THE DUAL MIND
whisper_text: The Savage philosopher, the dual mind.

text: THE ORIGINAL ATTITUDE OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN TOWARD THE ETERNAL THE GREAT MYSTERY THAT SURROUNDS AND EMBRACES US WAS AS SIMPLE AS IT WAS EXALTED
whisper_text: The original attitude of the American Indian toward the eternal, the great mystery that surrounds and embraces us was as simple as it was exalted.

text: HERE IS THE SUPREME MYSTERY THAT IS THE ESSENCE OF WORSHIP WITHOUT WHICH THERE CAN BE NO RELIGION AND IN THE PRESENCE OF THIS MYSTERY OUR ATTITUDE CANNOT BE VERY UNLIKE THAT OF THE NATURAL PHILOSOPHER WHO BEHOLDS WITH AWE THE DIVINE IN ALL CREATION
whisper_text: Here's the supreme mystery that is the essence of worship, without which there can be no religion and in the presence of this mystery our attitude cannot be very unlike that of the natural philosopher, who beholds with awe the divine and all creation.

text: IT WAS NOT THEN WHOLLY FROM IGNORANCE OR IMPROVIDENCE THAT HE FAILED TO ESTABLISH PERMANENT TOWNS AND TO DEVELOP A MATERIAL CIVILIZATION
whisper_text: It was not then, wholly from ignorance or improvedance, that he failed to establish permanent towns and to develop a material civilization.

text: THE FIRST BAMBEDAY OR RELIGIOUS RETREAT MARKED AN EPOCH IN THE LIFE OF THE YOUTH WHICH MAY BE COMPARED TO THAT OF CONFIRMATION OR CONVERSION IN CHRISTIAN EXPERIENCE
whisper_text: The first, then, day, or religious retreat marked an epoch in the life of the youth, which may be compared to that of confirmation or conversion in the Christian experience.

text: KNOWING THAT GOD SETS NO VALUE UPON MATERIAL THINGS HE TOOK WITH HIM NO OFFERINGS OR SACRIFICES OTHER THAN SYMBOLIC OBJECTS SUCH AS PAINTS AND TOBACCO
whisper_text: Knowing that God sets no value upon material things, he took with him no offerings or sacrifices other than symbolic objects such as paints and tobacco.

text: TO THE UNTUTORED SAGE THE CONCENTRATION OF POPULATION WAS THE PROLIFIC MOTHER OF ALL EVILS MORAL NO LESS THAN PHYSICAL
whisper_text: To the untudored sage, the concentration of population was the prolific mother of all evils, moral, no less than physical.

text: AT THE SOLEMN HOUR OF SUNRISE OR SUNSET HE TOOK UP HIS POSITION OVERLOOKING THE GLORIES OF EARTH AND FACING THE GREAT MYSTERY AND THERE HE REMAINED NAKED ERECT SILENT AND MOTIONLESS EXPOSED TO THE ELEMENTS AND FORCES OF HIS ARMING FOR A NIGHT AND A DAY TO TWO DAYS AND NIGHTS BUT RARELY LONGER
whisper_text: At the solemn hour of sunrise or sunset, he took up his position overlooking the glories of earth and facing the great mystery. And there he remained, naked erect silent and motionless, exposed to the elements and forces of his arming, for a night and a day to two days and nights, but rarely longer.

text: AMONG US ALL MEN WERE CREATED SONS OF GOD AND STOOD ERECT AS CONSCIOUS OF THEIR DIVINITY
whisper_text: Among us all men were created sons of God and stood erect as conscious of their divinity.

text: IN THIS TYPE OF PRAYER THERE WAS NO BESEECHING OF FAVOR OR HELP
whisper_text: In this type of prayer, there was no besieging of favor or help.

text: FROM THE SUN AS THE UNIVERSAL FATHER PROCEEDS THE QUICKENING PRINCIPLE IN NATURE AND IN THE PATIENT AND FRUITFUL WOMB OF OUR MOTHER THE EARTH ARE HIDDEN EMBRYOS OF PLANTS AND MEN
whisper_text: From the sun as the universal father proceeds the quickening principle in nature, and in the patient and fruitful womb of our mother, the earth, are hidden embryos of plants and men.

text: THAT SOLITARY COMMUNION WITH THE UNSEEN WHICH WAS THE HIGHEST EXPRESSION OF OUR RELIGIOUS LIFE IS PARTLY DESCRIBED IN THE WORD BAMBEDAY LITERALLY MYSTERIOUS FEELING WHICH HAS BEEN VARIOUSLY TRANSLATED FASTING AND DREAMING
whisper_text: That solitary communion with the unseen, which was the highest expression of our religious life, is partly described in the word Bambide, literally mysterious feeling, which has been variously translated, fasting and dreaming.

text: WHEN HE RETURNED TO THE CAMP HE MUST REMAIN AT A DISTANCE UNTIL HE HAD AGAIN ENTERED THE VAPOR BATH AND PREPARED HIMSELF FOR INTERCOURSE WITH HIS FELLOWS
whisper_text: When he returned to the camp, he must remain at a distance until he had again entered the vapor bath and prepared himself for intercourse with his fellows.

text: IT WAS SILENT BECAUSE ALL SPEECH IS OF NECESSITY FEEBLE AND IMPERFECT THEREFORE THE SOULS OF MY ANCESTORS ASCENDED TO GOD IN WORDLESS ADORATION
whisper_text: It was silent because all speech is of necessity, feeble and imperfect. Therefore, the souls of my ancestors ascend to God in wordless adoration.

text: THIS IS THE MATERIAL OR PHYSICAL PRAYER
whisper_text: This is the material or physical prayer.

text: IN HIS OWN THOUGHT HE ROSE SUPERIOR TO THEM HE SCORNED THEM EVEN AS A LOFTY SPIRIT ABSORBED IN ITS STERN TASK REJECTS THE SOFT BEDS THE LUXURIOUS FOOD THE PLEASURE WORSHIPING DALLIANCE OF A RICH NEIGHBOR
whisper_text: In his own thought he rose superior to them. He scorned them, even as lofty spirit absorbed in its stern task rejects the soft beds, the luxurious food, the pleasure worshiping dalliance of the rich neighbor.

text: THE HISTORIANS OF THE WHITE RACE ADMIT THAT THE INDIAN WAS NEVER THE FIRST TO REPUDIATE HIS OATH
whisper_text: The historians of the White Race admit that the Indian was never the first to repudiate his oath.

text: NOTHING OF THE MARVELOUS COULD ASTONISH HIM AS THAT A BEAST SHOULD SPEAK OR THE SUN STAND STILL
whisper_text: Nothing of the marvelous could astonish him, as that a beast should speak or the sun stands till.

text: NONE MIGHT EXHORT OR CONFESS OR IN ANY WAY MEDDLE WITH THE RELIGIOUS EXPERIENCE OF ANOTHER
whisper_text: None might exhort or confess or in any way metal with the religious experience of another.

text: THE FAMILY WAS NOT ONLY THE SOCIAL UNIT BUT ALSO THE UNIT OF GOVERNMENT
whisper_text: The family was not only the social unit, but also the unit of government.

text: HIS DAILY DEVOTIONS WERE MORE NECESSARY TO HIM THAN DAILY FOOD
whisper_text: His daily devotions were more necessary to him than daily food.

text: WHENEVER IN THE COURSE OF THE DAILY HUNT THE RED HUNTER COMES UPON A SCENE THAT IS STRIKINGLY BEAUTIFUL OR SUBLIME A BLACK THUNDERCLOUD WITH THE RAINBOW'S GLOWING ARCH ABOVE THE MOUNTAIN A WHITE WATERFALL IN THE HEART OF A GREEN GORGE A VAST PRAIRIE TINGED WITH THE BLOOD RED OF SUNSET HE PAUSES FOR AN INSTANT IN THE ATTITUDE OF WORSHIP
whisper_text: Whenever in the course of the Daily Hunt, the red hunter comes upon a scene that is strikingly beautiful or sublime, a black thunder cloud with the rainbows glowing arch above the mountain. A white waterfall in the heart of the green gorge, a vast prairie tinged with the blood red of sunset, he pauses for an instant in the attitude of worship.

text: THE REMOTER DEGREES OF KINSHIP WERE FULLY RECOGNIZED AND THAT NOT AS A MATTER OF FORM ONLY FIRST COUSINS WERE KNOWN AS BROTHERS AND SISTERS THE NAME OF COUSIN CONSTITUTED A BINDING CLAIM AND OUR RIGID MORALITY FORBADE MARRIAGE BETWEEN COUSINS IN ANY KNOWN DEGREE OR IN OTHER WORDS WITHIN THE CLAN
whisper_text: The remote degrees of kinship were fully recognized, and that not as a matter of form only, first cousins were known as brothers and sisters. The name of cousin constituted a binding claim, an rigid morality for bad marriage between cousins in any known degree, or in other words within the clan.

text: HE HAD NEITHER A NATIONAL ARMY NOR AN ORGANIZED CHURCH
whisper_text: He had neither a National Army nor an organized church.

whisper_text: It is well known that the American Indian had somehow developed a cult power, and although in the latter days there have been many imposter and allowing for the vanity and weakness of human nature, it is fair to assume that there must have been some even in the old days, yet there are well attested instances of remarkable prophecies and other mystic practice.

text: AS A SPECIAL MARK OF RESPECT THE BODY OF A YOUNG WOMAN OR A WARRIOR WAS SOMETIMES LAID OUT IN STATE IN A NEW TEEPEE WITH THE USUAL HOUSEHOLD ARTICLES AND EVEN WITH A DISH OF FOOD LEFT BESIDE IT NOT THAT THEY SUPPOSED THE SPIRIT COULD USE THE IMPLEMENTS OR EAT THE FOOD BUT MERELY AS A LAST TRIBUTE
whisper_text: As a special mark of respect, the body of a young woman or a warrior was sometimes laid out in state in a new teepee, with the usual household articles and even with a dish of food left beside it, not that they supposed the spirit could use the implements or eat the food but merely as a last tribute.

whisper_text: If a man were slain in battle, it was an old custom to place his body against a tree or rock in a sitting position always facing the enemy to indicate his undaunted defiance and bravery even in death.

text: THE OLD WOMAN BEHAVED VERY KINDLY TO THEM BUT IN REALITY SHE WAS A WICKED OLD WITCH WHO WAY LAID CHILDREN AND BUILT THE BREADHOUSE IN ORDER TO ENTICE THEM IN BUT AS SOON AS THEY WERE IN HER POWER SHE KILLED THEM COOKED AND ATE THEM AND MADE A GREAT FESTIVAL OF THE DAY
whisper_text: The old woman behaved very kindly to them, but in reality she was a bigot old witch who waylaid children and built the breadhouse in order to entice them in. But as soon as they were in her power, she killed them, cooked them and ate them, and made a great festival of the day.

text: AND SO THROUGH MANY QUESTIONS AND MANY EXPERIMENTS THEY LEARN AT LAST HOW TO USE THE CONTENTS OF THIS ONE STOREHOUSE
