text: THE SILVER IS ALL RIGHT THANK GOODNESS SHE SAID BUT YOUR BANJO GIRL HAS TAKEN A PAIR OF YOUR SISTER'S SILK STOCKINGS AND THOSE NEW SHOES OF HERS WITH THE SILVER BUCKLES AND SHE'S LEFT THESE
whisper_text: The silver is all right, thank goodness, she said. But your banjo girl has taken a pair of your sister's silk stockings and those new shoes of hers with the silver buckles. And she's left these.

text: HER LITTLE FOOT TAPPED THE GRAVEL IMPATIENTLY
whisper_text: Her little foot tapped the gravel impatiently.

text: NEVER HAD ANY ACT SEEMED SO IMPOSSIBLE
whisper_text: Never had any act seem so impossible.

text: THE LADY AND THE GUITAR CERTAINLY PASSED THE NIGHT AT HILL VIEW VILLA BUT WHEN HIS MOTHER VERY ANGRY AND VERY FRIGHTENED CAME UP WITH HIM AT ABOUT NOON THE HOUSE LOOKED JUST AS USUAL AND NO ONE WAS THERE BUT THE CHARWOMAN
whisper_text: The lady and the guitar certainly passed the night at Hillview Villa, but when his mother very angry and very frightened came up with him at about noon, the house looked just as usual, and no one was there but the charwoman.

text: YOU SEE PAPA'S SO VERY RICH AND AT HOME THEY EXPECT ME TO TO GET ACQUAINTED WITH DUKES AND THINGS AND SHE STOPPED
whisper_text: You see, Papaso very rich, and at home they expect me to get acquainted with dukes and things, and she stopped.

text: AND AGAIN HE LISTENED WITH A QUIET PLEASURE
whisper_text: And again, he listened with a quiet pleasure.

text: WELL THEN I WENT INTO LODGINGS THAT WICKED WOMAN HAD LEFT ME ONE STREET SUIT AND TO DAY THEY TURNED ME OUT BECAUSE MY MONEY WAS ALL GONE
whisper_text: Well, then, I went into lodgings that wicked woman had left me one street suit, and today they turned me out because my money was all gone.

text: SHE SAID AGAIN YOU ARE KIND
whisper_text: She said again you are kind.

text: THEN THERE WAS SILENCE THEN A SIGH AND THE SOUND OF LIGHT MOVING FEET ON THE GRAVEL
whisper_text: Then there was silence, then a sigh, and the sound of light moving feet on the gravel.

text: I WILL CATCH THE NIGHT TRAIN AND BRING MY MOTHER UP TO MORROW THEN WE WILL SEE WHAT CAN BE DONE
whisper_text: I will catch the night train and bring my mother up tomorrow, then we will see what can be done.

text: YOU ARE KIND SHE SAID FOR THE THIRD TIME AND REACHED HER HAND OUT TO HIM HE DID NOT KISS IT THEN ONLY TOOK IT IN HIS AND FELT HOW SMALL AND COLD IT WAS THEN IT WAS TAKEN AWAY
whisper_text: You are kind. She said for the third time and reached her hand out to him. He did not kiss it then, only took it in his and felt how small and cold it was. Then it was taken away.

text: ALL THE SAME HE ADDED IRRELEVANTLY YOU SHALL HAVE THE LATCH KEY
whisper_text: While the same he added to Relovently, you shall have the Latch Key.

text: I SHALL LOCK UP ALL THE DOORS AND WINDOWS IN THE HOUSE AND THEN I SHALL GIVE YOU MY LATCH KEY AND YOU CAN LET YOURSELF IN AND STAY THE NIGHT HERE THERE IS NO ONE IN THE HOUSE
whisper_text: I shall lock up all the doors and windows in the house, and then I shall give you my latch key, and you can let yourself in and stay the night here. There is no one in the house.

text: THE YOUNG MAN DREW A DEEP BREATH OF RELIEF AND LIGHTED THE WAX CANDLES IN THE SOLID SILVER CANDLESTICKS ON HIS WRITING TABLE FOR NOW THE LATE SUMMER DUSK WAS FALLING AND THAT ORGAN PLEASE HEAVEN MADE FULL THE MEASURE OF THE DAY'S APPOINTED TORTURE
whisper_text: The young man drew a deep breath of relief, and lighted the wax candles in the solid silver candle sticks on his writing table. For now the late summer dusk was falling, and that organ, please heaven, made full the measure of the days appointed torture.

text: THE LAST STRAINS OF THE ILL TREATED ILL FATED INTERMEZZO HAD DIED AWAY AND AFTER THEM HAD DIED AWAY ALSO THE RUMBLING OF THE WHEELS OF THE MURDEROUS BARREL ORGAN THAT HAD SO GAILY EXECUTED THAT ALONG WITH THE NINE OTHER TUNES OF ITS REPERTORY TO THE ADMIRATION OF THE HOUSEMAID AT THE WINDOW OF THE HOUSE OPPOSITE AND THE CROWING DELIGHT OF THE TWO BABIES NEXT DOOR
whisper_text: The last strains of the ill-treated, ill-fated intermezzo had died away, and after them had died away also the rumbling of the wheels of the murderous barrel organ that had so galley executed that, along with the nine other tunes of its repatory, to the admiration of the housemaid at the window of the house opposite, and the crowing delight of the two babies next door.

text: LET ME THINK HE SAID OH HOW GLAD I AM THAT YOU HAPPENED TO COME THIS WAY
whisper_text: Let me think, he said, how glad I am that you happen to come this way.

text: IT WASN'T I WHO SAID THAT SAID THE GIRL SMILING BUT THAT'S SO ANYHOW AND THEN SHE SIGHED
whisper_text: It wasn't I who said that said the girl smiling but that's so anyhow and then she sighed

text: IS IT ONLY THAT YOU'RE POOR WHY THAT'S NOTHING I'M POOR TOO SHE LAUGHED
whisper_text: Is it only that you're poor? Why that's nothing, I'm poor too. She laughed.

text: LOOK HERE HE SAID THIS IS ALL NONSENSE YOU KNOW YOU ARE TIRED OUT AND THERE'S SOMETHING WRONG WHAT IS IT
whisper_text: Look here, he said. This is all nonsense. You know you are tired out and there's something wrong. What is it?

text: THEN SHE TURNED TOWARDS THE QUARTER INDICATED AND DISAPPEARED ROUND THE LAUREL BUSHES
whisper_text: Then she turned towards the quarter indicated and disappeared round the laurel bushes.

text: HE HAD NO TIME TO THINK BUT HE WAS AWARE THAT THIS WAS THE MOST EXCITING ADVENTURE THAT HAD EVER HAPPENED TO HIM
whisper_text: He had no time to think, but he was aware that this was the most exciting adventure that had ever happened to him.

text: SHE HERSELF SHOULD HAVE BEEN A POEM A LYRIC IN A WHITE GOWN AND GREEN SCARF COMING TO HIM THROUGH THE LONG GRASS UNDER THE BLOSSOMED BOUGHS
whisper_text: She herself should have been a poem, a lyric in a white gown and green scarf, coming to him through the long grass under the blossomed boughs.

text: WHAT OPINION WOULD HE FORM OF THE PURITY OF HER MIND THE INNOCENCE OF HER SOUL IF AN INCIDENT LIKE THIS FAILED TO SHOCK HER DEEPLY
whisper_text: What opinion would he form of the purity of her mind, the innocence of her soul, if an incident like this failed to shock her deeply?

text: COULDN'T HELP IT THEN HOW CAN I EVER TRUST YOU
whisper_text: Couldn't help it. Then how can I ever trust you?

text: DO YOU THINK I'M NOT SORRY NOW
whisper_text: Do you think I'm not sorry now?

text: FOLLOWING THE TINGLE OF RELIEF CAME A SHARP SICKENING PINCH OF JEALOUSY AND MORTIFICATION THESE INSPIRED HER
whisper_text: Following the tingle of relief came a sharp sickening pinch of jealousy and mortification. These inspired her.

text: HER HANDS SHOULD HAVE BEEN FULL OF BLUEBELLS AND SHE SHOULD HAVE HELD THEM UP TO HIS FACE IN MAIDENLY DEFENCE AS HE SPRANG FORWARD TO TAKE HER IN HIS ARMS
whisper_text: Her hands should have been full of bluebells, and she should have held them up to his face and made inly defense as he sprang forward to take her in his arms.

text: AND HE STRODE DOWN BETWEEN THE MARBLE TABLES AND OUT BY THE SWING DOOR IT WAS A VERY GOOD EXIT
whisper_text: And he strode down between the marble tables and out by the swing door. It was a very good exit.

text: THE SETTING OF THE SCENE SEEMED TO HER ALL IMPORTANT
whisper_text: The setting of the scene seemed to her all important.

text: THE KEEN WIND THRUST ITSELF EVEN INSIDE THE HIGH COLLAR OF HER JACKET
whisper_text: The keen wind thrust itself even inside the high collar of her jacket.

text: HER HANDS AND FEET WERE ACHING WITH COLD
whisper_text: Her hands and feet were aching with cold.

text: IT WAS BITTERLY COLD BUT THE EMBANKMENT WAS MORE ROMANTIC THAN A RAILWAY CARRIAGE
whisper_text: It was bitterly cold, but the embankment was more romantic than a railway carriage.

text: AT THE CORNER HE REMEMBERED THAT HE HAD GONE AWAY WITHOUT PAYING FOR THE TEA AND HIS NATURAL IMPULSE WAS TO GO BACK AND REMEDY THAT ERROR
whisper_text: At the corner he remembered that he had gone away without paying for the tea, and his natural impulse was to go back and remedy that error.

text: HE HAD BEEN LATE HE HAD OFFERED NO EXCUSE NO EXPLANATION
whisper_text: He had been late. He had offered no excuse, no explanation.

text: HE STOOD UP SUDDENLY DO YOU MEAN IT
whisper_text: He stood up suddenly. Do you mean it?

text: SHE WOULD HAVE SHARED HIS SORROW AND SHOWN HERSELF HALF WIFE HALF ANGEL FROM HEAVEN IN THIS DARK HOUR
whisper_text: She would have shared his sorrow and shown herself half-wife, half-angel from heaven in this dark hour.

text: AND CURIOUSLY ENOUGH SHE WAS HARDLY CURIOUS AT ALL ABOUT WHAT HE MIGHT HAVE TO SAY
whisper_text: And curiously enough, she was hardly curious at all about what he might have to say.

text: HE CHECKED THE SILLY IMPULSE
whisper_text: He checked the Sillium Pulse.

text: SO HE ENLISTED AND WENT TO SOUTH AFRICA AND HE NEVER CAME HOME COVERED WITH MEDALS AND GLORY WHICH WAS RATHER HIS IDEA TO THE FEW SIMPLE WORDS OF EXPLANATION THAT WOULD HAVE MADE ALL STRAIGHT AND REPAID HER AND HIM FOR ALL THE PAST
whisper_text: So he enlisted and went to South Africa, and he never came home covered with medals and glory, which was rather his idea, to the few simple words of explanation that would have made all straight and repaid her and him for all the past.

text: SHE ONLY WISHED FOR MAY AND THE ORCHARD INSTEAD OF JANUARY AND THE DINGY DUSTY WAITING ROOM THE PLAIN FACED PREOCCUPIED TRAVELLERS THE DIM DESOLATE WEATHER
whisper_text: She only wished for May and the orchard, instead of January and the dingy dusty waiting-room, the plain-faced preoccupied travelers, the dim, desolate weather.

text: SHE SAID HOW FRIGHTFULLY COLD IT IS
whisper_text: she said how frightfully cold it is.

text: ARE YOU REALLY GOING TO THROW ME OVER FOR A THING LIKE THIS
whisper_text: Are you really going to throw me over for a thing like this?

text: BUT HERE THE ONLY THING THAT OCCURRED TO HER WAS TO STOP AND LOOK IN ONE OF THE SHOPS TILL HE SHOULD ASK HER WHAT SHE WAS LOOKING AT
whisper_text: But here, the only thing that occurred to her was to stop and look in one of the shops till he should ask her what she was looking at.

text: AND YESTERDAY I HAD A LETTER FROM HER AND SHE SEEMS TO EXPECT TO THINK AND I THOUGHT I OUGHT TO TELL YOU DARLING
whisper_text: And yesterday I had a letter from her and she seems to expect to think and I thought I had to tell you darling.

text: YOU SEE THAT SHE KNEW EXACTLY HOW A TRYST IS CONDUCTED IN THE PAGES OF THE STANDARD POETS AND OF THE CHEAPER WEEKLY JOURNALS
whisper_text: You see that she knew exactly how a trist is conducted in the pages of the standard poets and of the cheaper weekly journals.

text: I DON'T WONDER YOU WERE AFRAID TO TELL ME SHE BEGAN YOU DON'T LOVE ME YOU'VE NEVER LOVED ME I WAS AN IDIOT TO BELIEVE YOU DID
whisper_text: I don't wonder you were afraid to tell me she began, you don't love me, you've never loved me. I was an idiot to believe you did.

text: NO IT'S ONLY PAINFUL FOR BOTH OF US
whisper_text: No, it's only painful for both of us.

text: I DIDN'T THINK A DECENT MAN COULD DO SUCH THINGS SHE WAS PULLING ON HER GLOVES GO HOME AND GLOAT OVER IT ALL
whisper_text: I didn't think a decent man could do such things. She was pulling on her gloves. Go home and glowed over at all.

text: THOSE FOUR TRUE WORDS WOUNDED HER MORE THAN ALL THE REST
whisper_text: Those four true words wounded her more than all the rest.

text: SHE HAD TO THE FULL LIMIT ALLOWED OF HER READING AND HER ENVIRONMENT THE LITERARY SENSE
whisper_text: She had to the full limit allowed of her reading in her environment the literary sense.

text: A SHOCK OF UNBELIEVABLE RELIEF TINGLED THROUGH HER SO THAT WAS ALL WHAT WAS IT COMPARED WITH HER FEARS
whisper_text: A shock of unbelievable relief tingled through her, so that was all, but was it compared with her fears?

text: ONE CAN ALMOST IMAGINE HIMSELF IN ONE OF THE FAMOUS RATHSKELLERS OF OLD HEIDELBERG NOT AT THE SCHLOSS OF COURSE FOR HERE YOU CANNOT LOOK DOWN ON THE WEISER AS IT FLOWS BENEATH THE WINDOWS OF THE GREAT WINE STUBE ON THE HILL
whisper_text: One can almost imagine himself in one of the famous rath-scalers of Old Heidelberg. Not at the Schloss, of course. For here you cannot look down on the visor as it flows beneath the windows of the great winech through the On the Hill.

text: THOMPSON OPENED A LARGE RESTAURANT IN O'FARRELL STREET JUST ABOVE FILLMORE AND FOR TWO YEARS OR MORE DID A THRIVING BUSINESS HIS PLACE BEING NOTED FOR ITS GOOD COOKING AND ITS SPLENDID SERVICE
whisper_text: Thompson opened a large restaurant in Oferrall Street, just above Fillmore, and for two years or more did a thriving business, his place being noted for its good cooking and its splendid service.

text: OF COURSE THESE ARE NOT THE ENTIRE MENUS BUT OF ALL THE WELL PREPARED DISHES THESE ARE THEIR BEST
whisper_text: Of course, these are not the entire menus, but of all the well-prepared dishes, these are their best.

text: THE FLY TRAP AND CHARLIE'S FASHION THE FIRST IN SUTTER STREET NEAR KEARNY AND THE OTHER IN MARKET NEAR SUTTER SERVE WELL COOKED FOODS ESPECIALLY SOUP SALADS AND FISH
whisper_text: The flytrap and Charlie's fashion, the first in Sutter Street near Keirney and the other in market near Sutter, serve well-cooked foods, especially soup, salads and fish.

text: SAN FRANCISCO'S CARE FREE SPIRIT WAS FULLY EXEMPLIFIED BEFORE THE ASHES OF THE GREAT FIRE OF NINETEEN O SIX WERE COLD
whisper_text: San Francisco's Carefree Spirit was fully exemplified before the ashes of the great fire of 1906 were cold.

text: AT THE CORNER OF MARKET AND EDDY STREETS IS THE ODEON DOWN IN A BASEMENT WITH DECORATIONS OF MOST GARISH ORDER
whisper_text: At the corner of Market in Eddie Streets is the Odin, down in a basement with decorations of most garish order.

text: THE POODLE DOG HAS A HOTEL ATTACHMENT WHERE ONE MAY GET ROOMS OR FULL APARTMENTS
whisper_text: The Poodle Dog has a hotel attachment where one may get rooms or full apartments.

text: THE RESTAURANTS OF THE PRESENT DAY THAT APPROACH NEAREST THE OLD BOHEMIAN RESTAURANTS OF PRE FIRE DAYS OF THE FRENCH CLASS ARE JACK'S IN SACRAMENTO STREET BETWEEN MONTGOMERY AND KEARNY FELIX IN MONTGOMERY STREET BETWEEN CLAY AND WASHINGTON AND THE POODLE DOG BERGEZ FRANKS IN BUSH STREET BETWEEN KEARNY AND GRANT AVENUE
whisper_text: The restaurants of the present day that approach nearest the old Bohemian restaurants of pre-fire days of the French class are jacks in Sacramento street between Montgomery and Kearney, Felix in Montgomery street between Clay and Washington and the Poodle dog Berga's Franks in Bush street between Kearney and Grant Avenue.

text: THE HOF BRAU HOWEVER IS LESS DISTINCTIVELY GERMAN AS THE GREATER NUMBER OF ITS PATRONS ARE AMERICANS
whisper_text: The Hofbrow, however, is less distinctively German, as the greater number of its patrons are Americans.

text: PUT INTO THE OVEN AGAIN AND COOK FOR HALF AN HOUR BASTING FREQUENTLY WITH THE ORIGINAL BRINE
whisper_text: Put into the oven again and cook for half an hour, basting frequently with the original brine.

text: THEN TAKE IT OUT OF THE ROASTING PAN AND PUT IT INTO A CASSEROLE AFTER SPRINKLING IT WITH TWO OUNCES OF FLOUR
whisper_text: Then, take it out of the roasting pan and put it into a casserole after sprinkling it with two ounces of flour.

text: SEASON WITH SALT AND PEPPER AND A LITTLE SUGAR TO TASTE
whisper_text: Season with salt and pepper and a little sugar to taste.

text: AT THE TWO MENTIONED ONE PAYS FOR THE SURROUNDINGS AS WELL AS FOR THE FOOD AND SOMETIMES THIS IS WORTH PAYING FOR
whisper_text: At the two mentioned, one pays for the surroundings, as well as for the food, and sometimes this is worth paying for.

text: JOHN TAIT IS THE PRESIDING SPIRIT HERE HE HAVING MADE REPUTATION AS CLUB MANAGER AND THEN AS MANAGER OF THE CLIFF HOUSE
whisper_text: John Tate is the presiding spirit here. He having made reputation as club manager and then as manager of the Cliff House.

text: STRAIN THE SAUCE THROUGH A FINE COLLANDER AND ADD A FEW RAISINS A PIECE OF HONEY CAKE OR GINGER SNAPS AND THE MEAT OF ONE FRESH TOMATO
whisper_text: Strain the sauce through a fine colander and add a few raisins, a piece of honey cake or ginger snaps, and the meat of one fresh tomato.

text: IN THIS SAME DISTRICT IS THE MINT IN COMMERCIAL STREET BETWEEN MONTGOMERY AND KEARNY STREETS
whisper_text: In this same district is the Mint in commercial street between Montgomery and Kierney Streets.

text: THIS GARISH DISPLAY OF MIRRORS AND ELABORATE DECORATION OF CEILING AND PILLARS GIVES IT THE APPEARANCE OF THE ABODE OF SATURNALIA BUT DECORUM IS THE RULE AMONG THE PATRONS
whisper_text: This garish display of mirrors and elaborate decoration of ceiling and pillars gives it the appearance of the abode of Saturnalia, but decorum is the rule among the patrons.

text: PUT IN THE OVEN AND BROWN TO A GOLDEN COLOR
whisper_text: Put in the oven and round to a golden color.

text: THEY ALSO HAVE AS THE CHEF IN CHARGE OF THE ABALONE DISHES HERBERT FORMERLY CHEF FOR ONE OF THE YACHT CLUBS OF THE COAST WHO CLAIMS TO HAVE THE ONLY PROPER RECIPE FOR MAKING ABALONE'S TENDER
whisper_text: They also have as the chef in charge of the Abelone dishes Herbert, formerly chef of one of the yacht clubs of the coast, who claims to have the only proper recipe for making Abelone's tender.

text: THE CUISINE IS OF THE BEST AND THE CHEFS RANK AT THE TOP OF THEIR ART
whisper_text: The cuisine is of the best and the chef's rank at the top of their art.

text: IF YOU KNOW HOW TO ORDER AND DO NOT CARE TO COUNT THE COST WHEN YOU ORDER PROBABLY THE BEST DINNER AT THESE RESTAURANTS CAN BE HAD AT EITHER BLANCO'S OR THE POODLE DOG
whisper_text: If you know how to order and do not care to count the cost when you order, probably the best dinner at these restaurants can be had at either Blanco's or the Poodle Dog.

text: THE SPECIALTY OF THE HOF BRAU IS ABALONE'S AND THEY HAVE AS A FEATURE THIS SHELL FISH COOKED IN SEVERAL WAYS
whisper_text: The specialty of the Hoffbrow is Abelonies, and they have as a feature this shellfish cooked in several ways.

text: TO THE PICKLE ADD TWO LARGE ONIONS CUT IN QUARTERS TWO FRESH CARROTS AND ABOUT ONE OUNCE OF MIXED WHOLE ALLSPICE BLACK PEPPERS CLOVES AND BAY LEAVES
whisper_text: To the pickle, add 2 large onions, cut in quarters, 2 fresh carrots, and about 1 ounce of mixed whole-all-spice, black peppers, cloves, and bay leaves.

text: HERE THERE IS ALWAYS GOOD MUSIC AND FOOD WELL COOKED AND WELL SERVED AND ALWAYS A LIVELY CROWD DURING THE LUNCHEON DINNER AND AFTER THEATRE HOURS THE ROOM IS NOT LARGE BUT ITS DIMENSIONS ARE GREATLY MAGNIFIED OWING TO THE COVERING OF MIRRORS WHICH LINE THE WALLS
whisper_text: Here, there is always good music and food well cooked and well served, and always a lively crowd during the luncheon, dinner, and after theater hours. The room is not large, but its dimensions are greatly magnified, owing to the covering of mirrors which line the walls.

text: IN EITHER OF THESE RESTAURANTS YOU WILL BE SERVED WITH THE BEST THE MARKET AFFORDS COOKED THE RIGHT WAY
whisper_text: In either of these restaurants you will be served with the best the market affords, cooked the right way.

text: WHEN DONE TAKE THE MEAT OUT OF THE SAUCE
whisper_text: When done, take the meat out of the sauce.

text: WE FINALLY GOT HIM TO SELECT THE ONE PRIZED ABOVE ALL OTHERS AND THIS IS WHAT CHEF SCHEILER GAVE US
whisper_text: We finally got him to select the one prized above all others, and this is what Chef Schiller gave us.

text: IN ADDITION TO ABALONE'S THE HOF BRAU MAKES A SPECIALTY OF LITTLE OREGON CRAWFISH
whisper_text: In addition to abalone's, the Hofbrough makes a specialty of little Oregon craft fish.

text: HIS PRICES ARE MODERATE AND HIS COOKING AND VIANDS OF THE BEST AND WILL SATISFY THE MOST CRITICAL OF THE GOURMETS
whisper_text: His prices are moderate and his cooking in vions of the best, and will satisfy the most critical of the gourmets.

text: IT IS AN IDEA THAT IS WORTH WHILE BUT UNFORTUNATELY THE PROPRIETORS DEPEND TOO MUCH ON THE DECORATIVE FEATURE AND TOO LITTLE ON THE FOOD AND HOW THEY SERVE IT
whisper_text: It is an idea that is worthwhile, but, unfortunately, the proprietors depend too much on the decorative feature and too little on the food and how they serve it.

text: HERE AS WELL AS IN A NUMBER OF OTHER PLACES ONE CAN WELL APPRECIATE THE COLLOQUIAL DEFINITION OF CABARET
whisper_text: Here, as well as in a number of other places, one can well appreciate the colloquial definition of cabaret.

text: ONE OF HIS WAITERS PHIL TYSON WAS ONE OF THE EARLIER ONES TO GO BACK INTO THE BURNED DISTRICT TO BEGIN BUSINESS AND HE OPENED A RESTAURANT CALLED THE DEL MONTE IN POWELL STREET NEAR MARKET BUT IT WAS TOO EARLY FOR SUCCESS AND CLOSED AFTER A SHORT CAREER
whisper_text: One of his waiters, Phil Tyson, was one of the earlier ones to go back into the Byrne district to begin business, and he opened a restaurant called the Del Monte in Powell Street near market. But it was too early for success and closed after a short career.

text: IT HAS CHANGED FROM WHAT IT WAS IN THE OLD DAYS BUT IS STILL AN EXCELLENT PLACE TO DINE
whisper_text: It has changed from what it was in the old days, but is still an excellent place to dine.

text: BOTH SERVE GOOD SPANISH DINNERS AT REASONABLE PRICES
whisper_text: both serve good Spanish dinners at reasonable prices.

text: UNDER ORDINARY CIRCUMSTANCES THE ABALONE IS TOUGH AND UNPALATABLE BUT AFTER THE DEFT MANIPULATION OF HERBERT THEY ARE TENDER AND MAKE A FINE DISH EITHER FRIED AS CHOWDER OR A LA NEWBERG
whisper_text: Under ordinary circumstances, the abalone is tough and unpalatable. But after the deft manipulation of Herbert, they are tender and make a fine dish, either fried, as chowder or alanooburg.

text: BUT IF YOU REALLY LOVE GOOD MUSIC MUSIC THAT HAS MELODY AND RHYTHM AND SOOTHING CADENCES GO TO THE HEIDELBERG INN AND LISTEN TO THE CONCERT WHICH IS A FEATURE OF THE PLACE EVERY EVENING
whisper_text: But, if you really love good music, music that has melody and rhythm and soothing cadences, go to the Heidelberg Inn and listen to the concert, which is a feature of the place every evening.

text: TOMATO BASKETS TOMATO BASKETS ARE CHARMING ACCESSORIES FOR HOLDING VEGETABLE SALAD CHICKEN SHRIMPS COLD BEANS ASPARAGUS TIPS SHREDDED CELERY CUCUMBERS CUT IN CUBES AND MINCED PEPPERS
whisper_text: Tomato baskets. Tomato baskets are charming accessories for holding vegetable salad, chicken, shrimps, cold beans, asparagus tips, shredded celery, cucumbers cut in cubes and minced peppers.

text: ASPARAGUS SALAD COOK THE ASPARAGUS IN SALTED WATER DRAIN AND CHILL
whisper_text: Asparagus salad. Cook the asparagus in salted water, drain and chill.

text: STRAIN AND BOTTLE AND PUT IN ICE BOX SHAKE BEFORE USING EACH TIME
whisper_text: Strain and bottle and put in icebox, shake before using each time.

text: BIRDS NEST SALAD HAVE READY AS MANY CRISP LEAVES OF LETTUCE AS MAY BE REQUIRED TO MAKE A DAINTY LITTLE NEST FOR EACH PERSON
whisper_text: Bird's Nest Salad. Have ready as many crisp leaves of lettuce as may be required to make a dainty little nest for each person.

text: HANDLES OF WATERCRESS MAY BE ATTACHED TO THESE BASKETS
whisper_text: Handles of watercress may be attached to these baskets.

text: STIR THE SOAKED GELATIN IN WHILE THE CUCUMBER IS HOT
whisper_text: Stir the soaked gelatin in while the cucumber is hot.

text: CAULIFLOWER MAYONNAISE TAKE COLD BOILED CAULIFLOWER BREAK INTO BRANCHES ADDING SALT PEPPER AND VINEGAR TO SEASON
whisper_text: cauliflower mayonnaise. Take cold boiled cauliflower, break into branches, adding salt, pepper, and vinegar to season.

text: SURROUND WITH A GARNISH OF COOKED AND DICED CARROTS TURNIPS GREEN PEAS
whisper_text: Surround with a garnish of cooked and diced carrots, turnips, green peas.

text: SET INTO A COLD PLACE TO CHILL AND BECOME FIRM
whisper_text: Set into a cold place to chill and become firm.

text: POUR MAYONNAISE OVER ALL CHILL AND SERVE
whisper_text: Poor mayonnaise overall, chill and serve.

text: ADD TWO TABLESPOONS THICK SOUR CREAM TWO TABLESPOONS SUGAR A SPRINKLE OF MUSTARD AND HALF CUP OF VINEGAR
whisper_text: Add 2 tablespoons thick sour cream, 2 tablespoons sugar, a sprinkle of mustard and half cup of vinegar.

text: SALAD TWO CUPS OF APPLES CUT INTO SMALL PIECES ONE CUP CELERY CUT INTO SMALL PIECES ONE CUP ENGLISH WALNUTS
whisper_text: salad. Two cups of apples cut into small pieces, one cup celery cut into small pieces, one cup English walnuts.

text: SERVE ON A LETTUCE LEAF WITH MAYONNAISE DRESSING MADE WITHOUT MUSTARD AND THINNED WITH CREAM
whisper_text: Serve unalettus leaf with mayonnaise dressing, made without mustard and thinned with cream.

text: BEAT UNTIL THOROUGHLY MIXED POUR OVER THE CABBAGE AND TOSS LIGHTLY UNTIL UNIFORMLY SEASONED
whisper_text: Beat until thoroughly mixed, pour over the cabbage and toss lightly until uniformly seasoned.

text: CELERY AND NUT SALAD CUT ENOUGH CELERY FINE TO MEASURE TWO CUPS ADD ONE CUP OF FINELY SHREDDED OR SHAVED CABBAGE AND ONE AND ONE HALF CUPS OF WALNUT MEATS BROKEN IN SMALL PIECES BUT NOT CHOPPED
whisper_text: celery and nut salad. Cut enough celery fine to measure two cups. Add one cup of finely shredded or shaved cabbage and one and one half cups of walnut meats broken in small pieces but not chopped.

text: SERVE WITH FRENCH DRESSING HIDDEN UNDER THE LEAVES OF THE NEST
whisper_text: serve with French dressing hidden under the leaves of the nest.

text: GARNISH DISH THAT DRESSING IS MADE IN WITH A LITTLE GARLIC
whisper_text: Garnish dish that dressing is made in with a little garlic.

text: THIS DRESSING SHOULD STAND IN THE ICE BOX FOUR OR FIVE HOURS TO BECOME SEASONED
whisper_text: This dressing should stand in the icebox for or five hours to become seasoned.

text: WHEN THICKENED STRAIN AND COOL
whisper_text: when thickened, strain and cool.

text: PUT THE PULP INTO A BASIN WITH TWO OUNCES OF MELTED BUTTER TWO TABLESPOONFULS OF LEMON JUICE HALF A POUND OF CHESTNUTS BOILED AND GRATED AND SEASONING OF SALT AND WHITE PEPPER TO TASTE

whisper_text: Corley, do you consider majesty a proper word to use when addressing a queen?

text: IN THAT CASE SAID BUTTON BRIGHT YOU'RE ENTITLED TO THE BEST THERE IS TO PAY FOR YOUR TROUBLE
whisper_text: In that case, said button bright, you're entitled to the best there is, to pay for your trouble.

text: SINCE THAT TIME THEIR NUMBERS HAVE GRADUALLY DIMINISHED BUT A GOOD MANY ARE STILL TO BE FOUND IN THE WESTERN COUNTIES AND SEVERAL WITH A BETTER TEMPER THAN IN SEVENTEEN O SEVEN HAVE NOW TAKEN ARMS FOR GOVERNMENT
whisper_text: Since that time, their numbers have gradually diminished. But a good many are still to be found in the Western counties and several, with a better temper than in 1707, have now taken arms for government.

text: HE CERTAINLY POSSESSES TALENTS BEYOND THE RUDE SPHERE IN WHICH HE MOVES AND BEING NEITHER DESTITUTE OF AMBITION NOR ENCUMBERED WITH SCRUPLES HE WILL PROBABLY ATTEMPT BY EVERY MEANS TO DISTINGUISH HIMSELF DURING THE PERIOD OF THESE UNHAPPY COMMOTIONS
whisper_text: He certainly possesses talents beyond the root sphere in which he moves, and being neither destitute of ambition, nor encumbered with spruples. He will probably attempt by every means to distinguish himself during the period of these unhappy commotions.

text: WHEN I WAS A YOUNG MAN LIKE YOU MISTER WAVERLEY ANY SUCH HAIR BRAINED EXPEDITION I BEG YOUR PARDON FOR THE EXPRESSION WOULD HAVE HAD INEXPRESSIBLE CHARMS FOR ME
whisper_text: When I was a young man like you, Mr. Waverly, any such hair-brained expedition I beg your pardon for the expression would have had an expressable charms for me.

text: THEY HELD CONVENTICLES IN THE OPEN FIELDS AND BEING TREATED WITH GREAT VIOLENCE AND CRUELTY BY THE SCOTTISH GOVERNMENT MORE THAN ONCE TOOK ARMS DURING THOSE REIGNS
whisper_text: They held conventables in the open fields and being treated with great violence in cruelty by the Scottish government more than once took arms during those rains.

text: MISTER MORTON SEEMED PARTICULARLY STRUCK WITH THE ACCOUNT OF WAVERLEY'S VISIT TO DONALD BEAN LEAN
whisper_text: Mr. Morton seemed particularly struck with the account of Waverly's visit to Donald

text: EVIL TO HIM THAT THINKS OTHERWISE SAID MISTER MORTON OR WHO HOLDS CHURCH GOVERNMENT AND CEREMONIES AS THE EXCLUSIVE GAGE OF CHRISTIAN FAITH OR MORAL VIRTUE
whisper_text: "'Evil to him that thinks otherwise,' said Mr. Morton. "'Or who holds Church government and ceremonies as the exclusive gauge of Christian faith or moral for two?'

text: MISTER MORTON REPLIED THAT FAR FROM MAKING ANY CLAIM UPON HIS GOOD OPINION HIS ONLY WISH AND THE SOLE PURPOSE OF HIS VISIT WAS TO FIND OUT THE MEANS OF DESERVING IT
whisper_text: Mr. Morton replied, the far from making any claim upon his good opinion, his only wish and the sole purpose of his visit was to find out the means of deserving it.

text: CHAPTER THIRTY THREE A CONFIDANT
whisper_text: Chapter 33, A Confident.

text: HE HAD NEITHER SYMPATHY WITH MY INNOCENCE NOR WITH MY WRETCHEDNESS AND THE PETRIFYING ACCURACY WITH WHICH HE ATTENDED TO EVERY FORM OF CIVILITY WHILE HE TORTURED ME BY HIS QUESTIONS HIS SUSPICIONS AND HIS INFERENCES WAS AS TORMENTING AS THE RACKS OF THE INQUISITION
whisper_text: He had neither sympathy with my innocence nor with my wretchedness. And the petrifying accuracy with which he attended to every form of civility, while he tortured me by his questions, his suspicions, and his inferences, was as tormenting as the racks of the inquisition.

text: MISTER MORTON THEN MADE A CAREFUL MEMORANDUM OF THE VARIOUS PARTICULARS OF WAVERLEY'S INTERVIEW WITH DONALD BEAN LEAN AND THE OTHER CIRCUMSTANCES WHICH HE HAD COMMUNICATED
whisper_text: Mr. Morton then made a careful memorandum of the various particulars of way-release interview with Donald B. Leigh, and the other circumstances which he had communicated.

text: TWO BATTLEMENTED WALLS ONE OF WHICH FACED THE AVENUE AND THE OTHER DIVIDED THE COURT FROM THE GARDEN COMPLETED THE INCLOSURE
whisper_text: Two battle-minted walls, one of which faced the avenue and the other divided the court from the garden, completed the enclosure.

text: THE HOUSE WHICH SEEMED TO CONSIST OF TWO OR THREE HIGH NARROW AND STEEP ROOFED BUILDINGS PROJECTING FROM EACH OTHER AT RIGHT ANGLES FORMED ONE SIDE OF THE INCLOSURE
whisper_text: The house, which seemed to consist of two or three high narrow and steep-roofed buildings, projecting from each other at right angles, formed one side of the enclosure.

text: IT WAS ONE OF THOSE EFFECTS WHICH A PAINTER LOVES TO REPRESENT AND MINGLED WELL WITH THE STRUGGLING LIGHT WHICH FOUND ITS WAY BETWEEN THE BOUGHS OF THE SHADY ARCH THAT VAULTED THE BROAD GREEN ALLEY
whisper_text: It was one of those effects which a painter loves to represent and mingled well with the struggling light which found its way between the bows of the shady arc that vaulted the broad green alley.

text: STABLES AND OTHER OFFICES OCCUPIED ANOTHER SIDE OF THE SQUARE
whisper_text: Stables in other offices occupied another side of the square.

text: THE HOUSES SEEMED MISERABLE IN THE EXTREME ESPECIALLY TO AN EYE ACCUSTOMED TO THE SMILING NEATNESS OF ENGLISH COTTAGES
whisper_text: The houses seemed miserable in the extreme, especially to an eye accustomed to the smiling neatness of English cottages.

text: IT WAS ABOUT NOON WHEN CAPTAIN WAVERLEY ENTERED THE STRAGGLING VILLAGE OR RATHER HAMLET OF TULLY VEOLAN CLOSE TO WHICH WAS SITUATED THE MANSION OF THE PROPRIETOR
whisper_text: It was about noon when Captain Wave really entered the straggling village or rather hamlet of Tulee Vailon, close to which was situated the mansion of the proprietor.

text: THE EVIL AND REMEDY SUCH AS IT IS STILL EXIST BUT THIS IS REMOTE FROM OUR PRESENT PURPOSE AND IS ONLY THROWN OUT FOR CONSIDERATION OF THE COLLECTORS UNDER MISTER DENT'S DOG BILL
whisper_text: The evil and remedies such as it is still exist. But this is remote from our present purpose and is only thrown out for consideration of the collectors under Mr. Dent's dog bill.

text: EVERYTHING AROUND APPEARED SOLITARY AND WOULD HAVE BEEN SILENT BUT FOR THE CONTINUED PLASHING OF THE FOUNTAIN AND THE WHOLE SCENE STILL MAINTAINED THE MONASTIC ILLUSION WHICH THE FANCY OF WAVERLEY HAD CONJURED UP
whisper_text: Everything around appeared solitary, and would have been silent, but for the continued plashing of the fountain, and the whole scene still maintained the monastic illusion, which the fancy of Wey-Rally had conjured up.

text: OCCASIONALLY INDEED WHEN SUCH A CONSUMMATION SEEMED INEVITABLE A WATCHFUL OLD GRANDAM WITH HER CLOSE CAP DISTAFF AND SPINDLE RUSHED LIKE A SIBYL IN FRENZY OUT OF ONE OF THESE MISERABLE CELLS DASHED INTO THE MIDDLE OF THE PATH AND SNATCHING UP HER OWN CHARGE FROM AMONG THE SUNBURNT LOITERERS SALUTED HIM WITH A SOUND CUFF AND TRANSPORTED HIM BACK TO HIS DUNGEON THE LITTLE WHITE HEADED VARLET SCREAMING ALL THE WHILE FROM THE VERY TOP OF HIS LUNGS A SHRILLY TREBLE TO THE GROWLING REMONSTRANCES OF THE ENRAGED MATRON
whisper_text: Occasionally, indeed, when such a consummation seemed inevitable, a watchful old grandam with her close cap, disstaff, and spindle, rushed like a sibil in frenzy out of one of these miserable cells, dashed into the middle of the path, and snatching up her own charge from among the sun-burnt loiterers, saluted him with a sound cuff, and transported him back to his dungeon. The little white-headed, violet screaming all the while from the very top of his lungs a shrilly, treble to the growling remonstrances of the enraged matron.

text: THIS AVENUE WAS STRAIGHT AND OF MODERATE LENGTH RUNNING BETWEEN A DOUBLE ROW OF VERY ANCIENT HORSE CHESTNUTS PLANTED ALTERNATELY WITH SYCAMORES WHICH ROSE TO SUCH HUGE HEIGHT AND NOURISHED SO LUXURIANTLY THAT THEIR BOUGHS COMPLETELY OVER ARCHED THE BROAD ROAD BENEATH
whisper_text: This avenue was straight and of moderate length running between a double row of very ancient horse chestnuts planted alternately with sycamores which rose to such huge heights and Neurish so luxuriantly that their bows completely over arched the broad road beneath

text: THE COURT WAS SPACIOUS WELL PAVED AND PERFECTLY CLEAN THERE BEING PROBABLY ANOTHER ENTRANCE BEHIND THE STABLES FOR REMOVING THE LITTER
whisper_text: The court was spacious, well paved and perfectly clean. There are probably probably another entrance behind the stables for removing the litter.

text: NEITHER DID THE FRONT INDICATE ABSOLUTE SECURITY FROM DANGER
whisper_text: Neither did the front indicate absolute security from danger.

text: IT HAD BEEN BUILT AT A PERIOD WHEN CASTLES WERE NO LONGER NECESSARY AND WHEN THE SCOTTISH ARCHITECTS HAD NOT YET ACQUIRED THE ART OF DESIGNING A DOMESTIC RESIDENCE
whisper_text: It had been built at a period when castles were no longer necessary and when the Scottish architects had not yet acquired the art of designing a domestic residence.

text: THIS WORK OF ART WAS THE WONDER OF THE COUNTRY TEN MILES ROUND
whisper_text: This work of art was the wonder of the country 10 miles round.

text: YET THE PHYSIOGNOMY OF THE PEOPLE WHEN MORE CLOSELY EXAMINED WAS FAR FROM EXHIBITING THE INDIFFERENCE OF STUPIDITY THEIR FEATURES WERE ROUGH BUT REMARKABLY INTELLIGENT GRAVE BUT THE VERY REVERSE OF STUPID AND FROM AMONG THE YOUNG WOMEN AN ARTIST MIGHT HAVE CHOSEN MORE THAN ONE MODEL WHOSE FEATURES AND FORM RESEMBLED THOSE OF MINERVA
whisper_text: Yet the physiognomy of the people, when more closely examined, was far from exhibiting the indifference of stupidity. Their features were rough, but remarkably intelligent. Grave. But the very reverse of stupid, and from among the young women an artist might have chosen more than one model whose features and form resembled those of Minerva.

text: AFTER JUPITER HAD BOUND PROMETHEUS ON MOUNT CAUCASUS AND HAD SENT DISEASES AND CARES INTO THE WORLD MEN BECAME VERY VERY WICKED
whisper_text: After Jupiter had bound Prometheus on Mount Caucasus and had sent diseases and cares into the world, men became very, very wicked.

text: IN THOSE VERY EARLY TIMES THERE WAS A MAN NAMED DEUCALION AND HE WAS THE SON OF PROMETHEUS
whisper_text: In those very early times there was a man named Dukalian, and he was the son of Prometheus.

text: IS THERE ANYTHING THAT YOU WISH HE ASKED
whisper_text: Is there anything that you wish? He asked.

text: SURELY I DO NOT KNOW SAID DEUCALION
whisper_text: Surely I do not know," said Duke Alien.

text: WHAT DID HE MEAN ASKED PYRRHA
whisper_text: What did he mean? Asked Perra.

text: BUT DEUCALION AND PYRRHA WERE VERY SAD FOR THEY KNEW THAT THEY WERE THE ONLY PERSONS WHO WERE LEFT ALIVE IN ALL THE LAND
whisper_text: But Ducalian and Pira were very sad, for they knew that they were the only persons who were left alive in all the land.

text: GO ON DOWN THE MOUNTAIN SAID MERCURY AND AS YOU GO CAST THE BONES OF YOUR MOTHER OVER YOUR SHOULDERS BEHIND YOU AND WITH THESE WORDS HE LEAPED INTO THE AIR AND WAS SEEN NO MORE
whisper_text: Go on down the mountain, said Mercury. And as you go, cast the bones of your mother over your shoulders behind you. And with these words, he leapt into the air and was seen no more.

text: THE DAY IS COMING SAID PROMETHEUS WHEN JUPITER WILL SEND A FLOOD TO DESTROY MANKIND FROM THE EARTH
whisper_text: The day is coming," said Pometheus, when Jupiter will send a flood to destroy mankind from the earth.

text: NO ONE BUT DEUCALION THE SON OF PROMETHEUS WAS READY FOR SUCH A STORM
whisper_text: No one but to Calian, the son of Prometheus, was ready for such a storm.

text: WHEN AT LAST THEY REACHED THE PLAIN THEY FOUND THEMSELVES AT THE HEAD OF A NOBLE COMPANY OF HUMAN BEINGS ALL EAGER TO SERVE THEM
whisper_text: When at last they reached the plain, they found themselves at the head of a noble company of human beings, all eager to serve them.

text: WE SHOULD LIKE ABOVE ALL THINGS SAID DEUCALION TO SEE THIS LAND FULL OF PEOPLE ONCE MORE FOR WITHOUT NEIGHBORS AND FRIENDS THE WORLD IS A VERY LONELY PLACE INDEED
whisper_text: We should like above all things," said Eucanian. To see this land full of people once more, for without neighbors and friends, the world is a very lonely place indeed.

text: BUT MEN KEPT ON FIGHTING AND ROBBING EVEN WHILE THE RAIN WAS POURING DOWN AND THE SEA WAS COMING UP OVER THE LAND
whisper_text: But men kept on fighting and robbing, even while the rain was pouring down, and the sea was coming up over the land.

text: THESE MEN HE SAID TO HIS MIGHTY COMPANY ARE NOTHING BUT A SOURCE OF TROUBLE
whisper_text: These men, he said to his mighty company, are nothing but a source of trouble.

text: THE LADY IN WAITING BECAME VERY IMPATIENT AND AT LENGTH ANNOUNCED TO THE PRINCESS THAT THEY ALL WAITED FOR HER
whisper_text: The lady in waiting became very impatient, and at length announced to the princess that they all waited for her.

text: ONE OF THE YOUNG FAIRIES OVERHEARING HER AND FANCYING SHE MIGHT WORK SOME MISCHIEF TO THE LITTLE BABY WENT AND HID HERSELF BEHIND THE HANGINGS IN THE HALL SO AS TO BE ABLE TO HAVE THE LAST WORD AND UNDO ANY HARM THE OLD FAIRY MIGHT WISH TO WORK
whisper_text: One of the young fairies, overhearing her, and bansing she might work some mischief to the little baby, went and hid herself behind the hangings in the hall, so as to be able to have the last word and undo any harm the old fairy might wish to work.

text: HE TURNED TO SHOW THEM THE CASTLE BUT BEHOLD
whisper_text: He turned to show them the castle, but behold.

text: WHEN AT LAST THE QUEEN GAVE BIRTH TO A DAUGHTER THE KING WAS SO OVERJOYED THAT HE GAVE A GREAT CHRISTENING FEAST THE LIKE OF WHICH HAD NEVER BEFORE BEEN KNOWN
whisper_text: When at last the queen gave birth to a daughter, the king was so overjoyed that he gave a great christening feast, the like of which had never before been known.

text: MEANWHILE ALL THE REST OF THE PEOPLE IN THE CASTLE HAD BEEN WAKENED AT THE SAME MOMENT AS THE PRINCESS AND THEY WERE NOW EXTREMELY HUNGRY
whisper_text: Meanwhile, all the rest of the people in the castle had been awakened at the same moment as the princess, and they were now extremely hungry.

text: BUT THE FACES OF THE MEN WERE ROSY AND THE GOBLETS BY THEM HAD A FEW DROPS OF WINE LEFT
whisper_text: But the faces of the men were rosy, and the goblets by them had a few drops of wine left.

text: ONE SAID IT WAS AN ENCHANTED CASTLE ANOTHER THAT WITCHES LIVED THERE BUT MOST BELIEVED THAT IT WAS OCCUPIED BY A GREAT OGRE WHICH CARRIED THITHER ALL THE CHILDREN HE COULD CATCH AND ATE THEM UP ONE AT A TIME FOR NOBODY COULD GET AT HIM THROUGH THE WOOD
whisper_text: One said it was an enchanted castle, another that witches lived there. But most believed that it was occupied by a great ogre, which carried the other all the children he could catch and ate them up one at a time, for nobody could get Adams through the wood.

text: HE KNEW THAT SHE WOULD NOT AWAKE FOR A HUNDRED YEARS
whisper_text: He knew that she would not awake for a hundred years.

text: HE ENTERED A LARGE FORECOURT AND STOOD STILL WITH AMAZEMENT AND AWE
whisper_text: He entered a large forecord and stood still with amazement and awe.

text: SCARCELY HAD HE COME TO THE WOOD WHEN ALL THE TREES AND THORNS WHICH HAD MADE SUCH AN IMPENETRABLE THICKET OPENED ON ONE SIDE AND THE OTHER TO OFFER HIM A PATH
whisper_text: Scarsely had he come to the wood when all the trees and thorns which had made such an impenetable thicket, opened on one side and the other to offer him a path.

text: SHE HAD NO SOONER TAKEN UP THE SPINDLE THAN BEING HASTY AND CARELESS SHE PIERCED HER HAND WITH THE POINT OF IT AND FAINTED AWAY
whisper_text: She had no sooner taken up the spindle, than being hasty and careless. She pierced her hand with the point of it, and famed it away.

text: HE PASSED THROUGH ONE APARTMENT AFTER ANOTHER WHERE WERE LADIES AND GENTLEMEN ASLEEP IN THEIR CHAIRS OR STANDING
whisper_text: He passed through one apartment after another, where were ladies and gentlemen asleep in their chairs or standing.

text: HE ENTERED THE GUARD ROOM THERE THE GUARDS STOOD DRAWN UP IN LINE WITH CARBINES AT THEIR SHOULDERS BUT THEY WERE SOUND ASLEEP
whisper_text: He entered the guard room. There the guards stood drawn up in line with carbines at their shoulders. But they were sound asleep.

text: NOW FIFTEEN YEARS AFTER THE PRINCESS WAS BORN SHE WAS WITH THE KING AND QUEEN AT ONE OF THEIR CASTLES AND AS SHE WAS RUNNING ABOUT BY HERSELF SHE CAME TO A LITTLE CHAMBER AT THE TOP OF A TOWER AND THERE SAT AN HONEST OLD WOMAN SPINNING FOR SHE HAD NEVER HEARD OF THE KING'S EDICT
whisper_text: Now, fifteen years after the princess was born, she was with the king and queen, one of their castles, and as she was running about by herself, she came to a little chamber at the top of a tower, and there sat an honest old woman spinning, but she had never heard of the king's

text: THE YOUNG PRINCE AT THESE WORDS FELT HIMSELF ON FIRE
whisper_text: The young prince at these words, felt himself on fire.

text: IT IS TRUE I CANNOT ENTIRELY UNDO WHAT MY ELDER HAS DONE
whisper_text: It is true I cannot entirely undo what my elder has done.

text: THEY TALKED FOR FOUR HOURS AND HAD NOT THEN SAID HALF THAT WAS IN THEIR HEADS TO SAY
whisper_text: They talked for four hours, and had not then said half that was in their heads to say.

text: THE VIOLINS AND HAUT BOYS PLAYED OLD BUT EXCELLENT PIECES OF MUSIC AND AFTER SUPPER TO LOSE NO TIME THE GRAND ALMONER MARRIED THE ROYAL LOVERS IN THE CHAPEL OF THE CASTLE
whisper_text: The violins and hoboys played old but excellent pieces of music, and after supper, to lose no time, the grand almener married the royal lovers and the chapel of the castle.

text: THEN THE PRINCE TOOK THE PRINCESS BY THE HAND SHE WAS DRESSED IN GREAT SPLENDOUR BUT HE DID NOT HINT THAT SHE LOOKED AS HE HAD SEEN PICTURES OF HIS GREAT GRANDMOTHER LOOK HE THOUGHT HER ALL THE MORE CHARMING FOR THAT
whisper_text: Then the prince took the princess by the hand. She was dressed in great splendor. But he did not hint that she looked as he had seen pictures of his great grandmother look. He thought her all the more charming for that.

text: I HAVE WAITED LONG FOR YOU
whisper_text: I have waited long for you.

text: THE TURN OF THE OLD FAIRY HAD NOW COME AND SHE DECLARED WHILE HER HEAD SHOOK WITH MALICE THAT THE PRINCESS SHOULD PIERCE HER HAND WITH A SPINDLE AND DIE OF THE WOUND
whisper_text: The turn of the old fairy had now come, and she declared, while her head shook with malice, that the princess should pierce her hand with a spindle and die of the wound.

text: THEN THE WIND TOOK ANOTHER FROLIC ROUND THE GARDEN AND MADE UP TO THE LARGE WHITE LILY INTO WHOSE REFINED EAR HE WHISPERED A DOUBT AS TO THE NECESSITY OR ADVANTAGE OF HER THICK POWERFUL STEM BEING PROPPED UP AGAINST A STUPID UGLY STICK
whisper_text: Then the wind took another frolic round the garden, and made up to the large white lily, into whose refined ear he whispered a doubt as to the necessity or advantage of her thick, powerful stem, being propped up against a stupid ugly stick.

text: ECHOED THE FLOWERS TREMULOUSLY AS WITH A SORT OF FEARFUL PLEASURE THEY AWAITED HIS APPROACH
whisper_text: echoed the flowers, tremulously, as with a sort of fearful pleasure, they awaited his approach.

text: MAKING A SORT OF EDDYING CIRCUIT ROUND THE GARDEN HE KNOCKED OVER THE CONVOLVULUS POLE TORE THE STRIPS FROM THE STICK THAT HELD UP THE WHITE LILY LOOSED ALL THE CARNATION FLOWERS FROM THEIR FASTENINGS BROKE THE ROSE TREE DOWN AND LEVELLED THE SWEET PEAS TO THE GROUND
whisper_text: Making a sort of eddying circuit round the garden, he knocked over the convolvillus pole, tore the strips from the stick that held up the white lily, loosed all the carnation flowers from their fastenings, broke the rose tree down and levelled the sweet peas to the ground.

text: HE REALLY GRIEVED TO SEE IT
whisper_text: He really grieved to see it.

text: I AM NOT THINKING ABOUT THE GARDEN MAMMA REPLIED THE YOUNG GIRL WITHOUT LIFTING UP HER FACE WE CAN PLANT NEW FLOWERS AND TIE UP EVEN SOME OF THESE AFRESH
whisper_text: I am not thinking about the garden, Mama," replied the young girl, without lifting up her face. We can plant new flowers and tie up even some of these afresh.

text: WHAT A FUSS IS MADE ABOUT YOU MY DEAR LITTLE FRIENDS
whisper_text: What a fuss is made about you, my dear little friends.

text: BUT FOR THE SIGHT THAT AWAITED HIM HE WAS NOT PREPARED AT ALL
whisper_text: But for the sight that awaited him, he was not prepared at all.

text: WEEDS MEANWHILE SPRANG UP AND A DREARY CONFUSION REIGNED IN THE ONCE ORDERLY AND BRILLIANT LITTLE GARDEN
whisper_text: Weeds, meanwhile, sprang up, and a dreary confusion reigned in the once orderly and brilliant little garden.

text: YOU SURELY CANNOT SUPPOSE THAT IN A NATURAL STATE YOU WOULD BE FORCED TO CLIMB REGULARLY UP ONE TALL BARE STICK SUCH AS I SEE YOU UPON NOW
whisper_text: You surely cannot suppose that in a natural state you would be forced to climb regularly up one tall bare stick, such as I see you upon now.

text: THE MISTRESS HAD RETURNED AND THE YOUNG LADY WAS WITH HER AND HURRIED AT ONCE TO HER FAVOURITE GARDEN
whisper_text: The mistress had returned, and the young lady was with her, and hurried at once to her favorite garden.

text: THE HONEYSUCKLE ESCAPED NO BETTER AND THE CARNATION WAS READY TO DIE OF VEXATION AT FINDING THAT HER COVETED FREEDOM HAD LEVELLED HER TO THE DIRT
whisper_text: The honeysuckle escaped no better, and the carnation was ready to die of vexation, at finding that her coveted freedom had leveled her to the dirt.

text: YOUR COUSIN THE WILD CONVOLVULUS WHOM I LEFT IN THE FIELDS THIS MORNING DOES NO SUCH THING I ASSURE YOU
whisper_text: Your cousin, the wild convolvulus, whom I left in the fields this morning, does no such thing I assure you.

text: MY YOUNG PLANTS REQUIRE HEAT OR THEY WOULD NOT LIVE AND THE POTS WE ARE KEPT IN PROTECT US FROM THOSE CRUEL WIRE WORMS WHO DELIGHT TO DESTROY OUR ROOTS
whisper_text: My young plants require heat, or they would not live. And the pots we are kept in protect us from those cruel wire worms who delight to destroy our roots.

text: BEFORE THE DAY CLOSED THE GARDENER CAME WHISTLING FROM HIS FARM WORK TO LOOK OVER HIS PRETTY CHARGES
whisper_text: Before the day closed, the gardener came whistling from his farm work to look over his pretty charges.

text: IN THIS POSITION SHE REMAINED UNTIL A GENTLE HAND WAS LAID UPON HER SHOULDER
whisper_text: In this position she remained until a gentle hand was laid upon her shoulder.

text: MEANWHILE HOW FARED IT WITH THE FLOWERS
whisper_text: Meanwhile, how fair did it with the flowers?

text: WHY NOT ALLOW YOUR SILVER TUFTS TO LUXURIATE IN A NATURAL MANNER
whisper_text: Why not allow your silver tufts to luxuriate in a natural manner?

text: DID THAT LOVELY CREATURE SUPPOSE THAT NATURE WHO HAD DONE SO MUCH FOR HER THAT THE FAME OF HER BEAUTY EXTENDED THROUGHOUT THE WORLD HAD YET LEFT HER SO WEAK AND FEEBLE THAT SHE COULD NOT SUPPORT HERSELF IN THE POSITION MOST CALCULATED TO GIVE HER EASE AND PLEASURE
whisper_text: Did that lovely creature suppose that nature, who had done so much for her that the fame of her beauty extended throughout the world, had yet left her so weak and feeble that she could not support herself in the position most calculated to give her ease and pleasure?

text: INDEED NOT A FLOWER ESCAPED HIS MISCHIEVOUS SUGGESTIONS
whisper_text: Indeed, not a flower escaped his mischievous suggestions.

text: STILL THE ROSE TREE STOOD OUT THAT THERE MUST BE SOME GREAT ADVANTAGES IN A GARDENER'S CARE FOR SHE COULD NOT PRETEND TO BE IGNORANT OF HER OWN SUPERIORITY TO ALL HER WILD RELATIONS IN THE WOODS
whisper_text: Still, the rose tree stood out that there must be some great advantages in a gardener's care, for she could not pretend to be ignorant of her own superiority to all her wild relations and the woods.

text: OH THAT SHE WERE ONCE MORE CLIMBING UP THE FRIENDLY FIR POLE
whisper_text: Oh, that she were once more climbing up the friendly fur pole!

text: AS FOR THE EUCHARIST TRANSUBSTANTIATION THE REAL PRESENCE IT WAS ALL NO MYSTERY TO THEM BUT PALPABLE EVIDENCE AND YET THEY WERE NOT JESUITS
whisper_text: As for the Eucharist, Transubstantiation, the real Presence, it was all no mystery to them, but palpable evidence, and yet they were not Jesuits.

text: MY READERS MAY IMAGINE WHETHER WE FELT INCLINED TO LAUGH WHEN THE CHARMING CREATURE BADE US GOOD NIGHT THANKING US ALL WITH PERFECT GOOD FAITH
whisper_text: My readers may imagine whether we felt inclined to laugh when the charming creature beat us goodnight, thanking us all with perfect good faith.

text: BESIDES I WAS OF OPINION THAT A MAN'S PROFESSION WHATEVER IT MIGHT BE OUGHT TO SUPPLY HIM WITH ENOUGH MONEY TO SATISFY ALL HIS WANTS AND THE VERY POOR PAY OF AN OFFICER WOULD NEVER HAVE BEEN SUFFICIENT TO COVER MY EXPENSES BECAUSE MY EDUCATION HAD GIVEN ME GREATER WANTS THAN THOSE OF OFFICERS IN GENERAL
whisper_text: Besides, I was of opinion that a man's profession, whatever it might be, ought to supply him with enough money to satisfy all his wants. And the very poor pay of an officer would never have been sufficient to cover my expenses, because my education had given me greater wants than those of officers in general.

text: THEY BELIEVED THAT THROUGH ME THEY POSSESSED THE PHILOSOPHER'S STONE THE UNIVERSAL PANACEA THE INTERCOURSE WITH ALL THE ELEMENTARY HEAVENLY AND INFERNAL SPIRITS THEY HAD NO DOUBT WHATEVER THAT THANKS TO MY SUBLIME SCIENCE THEY COULD FIND OUT THE SECRETS OF EVERY GOVERNMENT IN EUROPE
whisper_text: They believe that through me they possessed the Philosopher's Stone, the Universal Panacea, the intercourse with all the elementary, heavenly, and infernal spirits. And they had no doubt whatever that, thanks to my sublime science, they could find out the secrets of every government in Europe.

text: I PICKED IT UP AND COMING UP TO HIM JUST AS HE WAS GOING DOWN THE STEPS I HANDED IT TO HIM
whisper_text: I picked it up and coming up to him just to see what was going down the steps, I hand it to him.

text: TAKING EVERYTHING UPON MYSELF I ORDERED A SERVANT TO HURRY OUT FOR A PHYSICIAN WHO CAME IN A SHORT TIME AND ORDERED THE PATIENT TO BE BLED AGAIN THUS APPROVING THE FIRST BLEEDING PRESCRIBED BY ME
whisper_text: Taking everything upon myself, I ordered a servant to hurry out for a physician, who came in a short time, and ordered the patient to be blood again, thus approving the first bleeding prescribed by me.

text: HE WROTE THE QUESTION AND GAVE IT TO ME I READ IT I COULD NOT UNDERSTAND EITHER THE SUBJECT OR THE MEANING OF THE WORDS BUT IT DID NOT MATTER I HAD TO GIVE AN ANSWER
whisper_text: He wrote the question and gave it to me. I read it. I could not understand either the subject or the meaning of the words, but it did not matter. I had to give an answer.

text: I DECLARED MYSELF QUITE WILLING FOR IT WAS NECESSARY TO BRAZEN IT OUT AFTER HAVING VENTURED AS FAR AS I HAD DONE
whisper_text: I declared myself quite willing, for it was necessary to brazen it out, after having ventured as far as I had done.

text: I JUMPED OUT OF THE GONDOLA AND FOUND MYSELF ON THE VERY SPOT WHERE THREE YEARS BEFORE I HAD TAUGHT RAZETTA SUCH A FORCIBLE LESSON I ENQUIRED FOR A SURGEON AT THE FIRST COFFEE HOUSE AND RAN TO THE HOUSE THAT WAS POINTED OUT TO ME

text: I HAVE REMAINED A PRISONER ONLY BECAUSE I WISHED TO BE ONE AND WITH THIS HE STEPPED FORWARD AND BURST THE STOUT CHAINS AS EASILY AS IF THEY HAD BEEN THREADS
whisper_text: I have remained a prisoner only because I wish to be one. And with this, he stepped forward and burst the stout chains as easily as if they had been threads.

text: WHERE IS THAT

text: OH NO I'M QUITE SURE HE DIDN'T
whisper_text: Oh no, I'm quite sure he didn't.

text: TRUE AGREED KALIKO
whisper_text: True, agreed Calico.

text: D'AVRIGNY SAID VILLEFORT BE SO KIND I BESEECH YOU AS TO ACCOMPANY THIS GENTLEMAN HERE IS THE KEY OF THE DOOR SO THAT YOU CAN GO IN AND OUT AS YOU PLEASE YOU WILL BRING THE PRIEST WITH YOU AND WILL OBLIGE ME BY INTRODUCING HIM INTO MY CHILD'S ROOM DO YOU WISH TO SEE HIM
whisper_text: Daverne said Willefort. Be so kind I would see you as to accompany this gentleman. Here is the key of the door so that you can go in and out as you please. You will bring the priest with you and will oblige me by introducing him into my child's room. Do you wish to see him?

text: FOR SOME TIME NOTHING WAS HEARD IN THAT CHAMBER BUT SOBS EXCLAMATIONS AND PRAYERS
whisper_text: For some time, nothing was heard in that chamber, but sobbs, exclamation and prayers.

text: NOIRTIER LOOKED UPON MORREL WITH ONE OF THOSE MELANCHOLY SMILES WHICH HAD SO OFTEN MADE VALENTINE HAPPY AND THUS FIXED HIS ATTENTION
whisper_text: Nautier looked upon morale with one of those melancholy smiles which had so often made Valentine happy and thus fixed his attention.

text: SAID MORREL SADLY YES REPLIED NOIRTIER
whisper_text: said morale sadly. Yes, replied no to you.

text: WHAT DO YOU MEAN SIR

text: GO DO YOU HEAR
whisper_text: Go! Do you hear?

text: GENTLEMEN HE SAID IN A HOARSE VOICE GIVE ME YOUR WORD OF HONOR THAT THIS HORRIBLE SECRET SHALL FOREVER REMAIN BURIED AMONGST OURSELVES THE TWO MEN DREW BACK
whisper_text: Gentleman, he sat in a horse voice. Give me your word of honor that this horrible secret shell forever remained buried amongst ourselves. The two men drew back.

text: IT WAS SOMETHING TERRIBLE TO WITNESS THE SILENT AGONY THE MUTE DESPAIR OF NOIRTIER WHOSE TEARS SILENTLY ROLLED DOWN HIS CHEEKS
whisper_text: It was something terrible to witness the silent agony, the mute despair of Nautier whose tears silently rolled on his cheeks.

text: BUT HE STOPPED ON THE LANDING HE HAD NOT THE COURAGE TO AGAIN VISIT THE DEATH CHAMBER
whisper_text: But he stopped on the landing. He had not the courage to again visit the death chamber.

text: MY FATHER HAS REVEALED THE CULPRIT'S NAME MY FATHER THIRSTS FOR REVENGE AS MUCH AS YOU DO YET EVEN HE CONJURES YOU AS I DO TO KEEP THIS SECRET DO YOU NOT FATHER
whisper_text: My father has revealed the culprit's name. My father thirsts for revenge as much as you do, yet even he conjures you as I do to keep this secret. Do you not, father?

text: BUT IN LESS THAN FIVE MINUTES THE STAIRCASE GROANED BENEATH AN EXTRAORDINARY WEIGHT
whisper_text: But in less than 5 minutes, the staircase groaned beneath an extraordinary weight.

text: MUST I LEAVE ALONE NO

text: AT THIS MOMENT THE WHOLE SOUL OF THE OLD MAN SEEMED CENTRED IN HIS EYES WHICH BECAME BLOODSHOT THE VEINS OF THE THROAT SWELLED HIS CHEEKS AND TEMPLES BECAME PURPLE AS THOUGH HE WAS STRUCK WITH EPILEPSY NOTHING WAS WANTING TO COMPLETE THIS BUT THE UTTERANCE OF A CRY
whisper_text: At this moment, the whole soul of the old man seemed centered in his eyes which became bloodshot. The veins of the throat swelled. His cheeks and temples became purple as though he was struck with epilepsy. Nothing was wanting to complete this but the utterance of a cry.

text: THE TWO DOCTORS THEREFORE ENTERED THE ROOM ALONE
whisper_text: The two doctors therefore entered the room alone.

text: MORREL SUFFERED AN EXCLAMATION OF HORROR AND SURPRISE TO ESCAPE HIM
whisper_text: Morrell suffered an exclamation of horror and surprised to escape him.

whisper_text: Noitier was near the bed, pale, motionless, and silent as the corpse.

text: AND THE CRY ISSUED FROM HIS PORES IF WE MAY THUS SPEAK A CRY FRIGHTFUL IN ITS SILENCE
whisper_text: and the cry issued from his pores if we may thus speak a cry frightful in its silence.

text: BUT CAN HE UNDERSTAND YOU YES
whisper_text: But can he understand you? Yes.

whisper_text: The district doctor approached with the indifference of a man accustomed to spend half his time amongst the dead. He then lifted the sheet, which was placed over the face and just unclosed to the lips.

text: OH YOU RAVE SIR EXCLAIMED VILLEFORT IN VAIN ENDEAVORING TO ESCAPE THE NET IN WHICH HE WAS TAKEN I RAVE
whisper_text: Oh, you rave, sir! Exclaimed Villifort, in vain, endeavoring to escape the net in which he was taken. I rave!

text: I AM GOING SIR AND I DO NOT HESITATE TO SAY THAT NO PRAYERS WILL BE MORE FERVENT THAN MINE
whisper_text: I am going, sir, and I do not hesitate to say that no prayers will be more fervent than mine.

text: D'AVRIGNY UNABLE TO BEAR THE SIGHT OF THIS TOUCHING EMOTION TURNED AWAY AND VILLEFORT WITHOUT SEEKING ANY FURTHER EXPLANATION AND ATTRACTED TOWARDS HIM BY THE IRRESISTIBLE MAGNETISM WHICH DRAWS US TOWARDS THOSE WHO HAVE LOVED THE PEOPLE FOR WHOM WE MOURN EXTENDED HIS HAND TOWARDS THE YOUNG MAN
whisper_text: Davani, unable to bear the sight of this touching emotion, turned away, and villafort, without seeking any further explanation, and attracted towards him by the irresistible magnetism which draws us towards those who have loved the people for whom we mourn, extended his hand towards the young man.

text: ASKED MORREL YES

whisper_text: The nearest, said the district doctor, is a good Italian abay who lives next door to you. Shall I call on him as I pass?

text: LOOK AT ME WELL IN SOOTH I'M BEATRICE
whisper_text: Look at me well in Su's I'm Beatrice.

whisper_text: By his default, short while he sojourned here. By his default to weeping and to toil, he changed his innocent laughter and sweet play.

whisper_text: Now, Helicon must needs poor forth for me, and with her choir, Uranium must assist me to put in verse things difficult to think.

text: NOR EVEN THUS OUR WAY CONTINUED FAR BEFORE THE LADY WHOLLY TURNED HERSELF UNTO ME SAYING BROTHER LOOK AND LISTEN
whisper_text: Nor even thus our way continued far before the lady wholly turned herself unto me, saying, Brother, look and listen.

whisper_text: The good supreme soul in itself delighting created man good and this goodly place gave him as handsel of eternal peace.

text: ALL WATERS THAT ON EARTH MOST LIMPID ARE WOULD SEEM TO HAVE WITHIN THEMSELVES SOME MIXTURE COMPARED WITH THAT WHICH NOTHING DOTH CONCEAL
whisper_text: All waters that on earth most limped are would seem to have within themselves some mixture compared with that which nothing does conceal.

text: THREE MAIDENS AT THE RIGHT WHEEL IN A CIRCLE CAME ONWARD DANCING ONE SO VERY RED THAT IN THE FIRE SHE HARDLY HAD BEEN NOTED

text: AND ONE OF THEM AS IF BY HEAVEN COMMISSIONED SINGING VENI SPONSA DE LIBANO SHOUTED THREE TIMES AND ALL THE OTHERS AFTER
whisper_text: And one of them, as if by heaven commissioned singing, Vaini Sponsor delibano shouted three times and all the others after.

whisper_text: And when the car was opposite to me, thunder was heard, and all that folk August seemed to have further progress interdicted.

whisper_text: The interval between these four contained a chariot, triumphal on two wheels, which by a Griffin's neck came drawn along.

whisper_text: In rear of all the group here treated of two old men I beheld, unlike in habit, but like in gate, each dignified and grave.

whisper_text: Thou makeest me remember where and what, Prosupina, that moment was when lost her mother her and she herself, the spring.

whisper_text: Dante, because Virgilius has departed, do not weep yet. Do not weep yet a while, for by another sword thou needs must weep.

whisper_text: And I beheld the flamelets onward go, leaving behind themselves the air depicted and they of trailing penins had the semblance, so that it overhead remained distinct with seven fold lists, all of them of the colors whence the sun's bow is made, and dealia's girdle.

whisper_text: So low he fell that all appliances for his salvation were already short, saved showing him the people of tradition.

text: ON PERCEIVING THIS CLAUDIA WHEN SHE HAD CONVINCED HERSELF THAT HER BELOVED HUSBAND WAS NO MORE RENT THE AIR WITH HER SIGHS AND MADE THE HEAVENS RING WITH HER LAMENTATIONS SHE TORE HER HAIR AND SCATTERED IT TO THE WINDS SHE BEAT HER FACE WITH HER HANDS AND SHOWED ALL THE SIGNS OF GRIEF AND SORROW THAT COULD BE CONCEIVED TO COME FROM AN AFFLICTED HEART
whisper_text: On perceiving this, Claudia, when she had convinced herself that her beloved husband was no more, rent the air with her size, and made the heavens ring with her lamentations. She tore her hair and scattered it to the winds. She beat her face with her hands and showed all the signs of grief and sorrow that could be conceived to come from an afflicted heart.

text: DULCINEA IS PERISHING THOU ART LIVING ON REGARDLESS I AM DYING OF HOPE DEFERRED THEREFORE UNTRUSS THYSELF WITH A GOOD WILL FOR MINE IT IS HERE IN THIS RETIRED SPOT TO GIVE THEE AT LEAST TWO THOUSAND LASHES
whisper_text: Dossenea is perishing, thou art living on regardless. I am dying of hope deferred, therefore untrust by self with a goodwill, for mine it is, here in this retired spot, to give thee at least 2,000 lashes.

whisper_text: Claudia would not on any account allow him to accompany her, and thanking him for his offers as well as she could, took leave of him in tears.

text: SEEING THIS SANCHO GOT UP AND GRAPPLING WITH HIS MASTER HE GRIPPED HIM WITH ALL HIS MIGHT IN HIS ARMS GIVING HIM A TRIP WITH THE HEEL STRETCHED HIM ON THE GROUND ON HIS BACK AND PRESSING HIS RIGHT KNEE ON HIS CHEST HELD HIS HANDS IN HIS OWN SO THAT HE COULD NEITHER MOVE NOR BREATHE
whisper_text: Seeing this, Sancho got up and grappling with his master, he gripped him with all his might in his arms, giving him a trip with the heel, stretched him on the ground on his back, and pressing his right neonist chest held his hands in his own so that he could neither move nor breathe.

text: DON QUIXOTE GAVE HIS PROMISE AND SWORE BY THE LIFE OF HIS THOUGHTS NOT TO TOUCH SO MUCH AS A HAIR OF HIS GARMENTS AND TO LEAVE HIM ENTIRELY FREE AND TO HIS OWN DISCRETION TO WHIP HIMSELF WHENEVER HE PLEASED
whisper_text: Don Quixote gave his promise and swore by the life of his thoughts not to touch so much as a hair of his garments, and to leave him entirely free and to his own discretion to whip himself whenever he placed.

text: AT ONE MOMENT IT SEEMED TO HIM THAT HE WAS IN THE CAVE OF MONTESINOS AND SAW DULCINEA TRANSFORMED INTO A COUNTRY WENCH SKIPPING AND MOUNTING UPON HER SHE ASS AGAIN THAT THE WORDS OF THE SAGE MERLIN WERE SOUNDING IN HIS EARS SETTING FORTH THE CONDITIONS TO BE OBSERVED AND THE EXERTIONS TO BE MADE FOR THE DISENCHANTMENT OF DULCINEA
whisper_text: At one moment it seemed to him that he was in the cave of Maltesinos, and Saul D'Alsania transformed into a country wench, skipping and mounting upon her she asks, again that the words of the sage Merlin were sounding in his ears, setting forth the conditions to be observed, and the exertions to be made for the disenchantment of D'Alsania.

text: DON QUIXOTE WAS ON FOOT WITH HIS HORSE UNBRIDLED AND HIS LANCE LEANING AGAINST A TREE AND IN SHORT COMPLETELY DEFENCELESS HE THOUGHT IT BEST THEREFORE TO FOLD HIS ARMS AND BOW HIS HEAD AND RESERVE HIMSELF FOR A MORE FAVOURABLE OCCASION AND OPPORTUNITY
whisper_text: Don Quixote was on foot with his horse unbridled and his lance leaning against a tree, and in short, completely defenseless. He thought at best, therefore, to fold his arms and bow his head and reserve himself for a more favorable occasion and opportunity.

text: THE REGENT'S LADY ORDERED ONE OF HER SERVANTS TO GIVE THE EIGHTY CROWNS THAT HAD BEEN ASSESSED AS HER SHARE AT ONCE FOR THE CAPTAINS HAD ALREADY PAID DOWN THEIR SIXTY
whisper_text: The Regents Lady ordered one of her servants to give the 80 crowns that had been assessed as her share at once, for the captains had already paid down their 60.

text: IN A WORD HE PLEDGED HIMSELF TO BE MINE AND I PROMISED TO BE HIS WITHOUT CARRYING MATTERS ANY FURTHER
whisper_text: In a word, he pledged himself to be mine, and I promised to be his without caring matters any further.

text: WHAT LED ME INTO IT WAS A CERTAIN THIRST FOR VENGEANCE WHICH IS STRONG ENOUGH TO DISTURB THE QUIETEST HEARTS
whisper_text: What led me into it was a certain thirst for vengeance, which is strong enough to disturb the quietest hearts.

text: THE WOUNDED GENTLEMAN OPENED HIS ALL BUT CLOSED EYES AND RECOGNISING CLAUDIA SAID I SEE CLEARLY FAIR AND MISTAKEN LADY THAT IT IS THOU THAT HAST SLAIN ME A PUNISHMENT NOT MERITED OR DESERVED BY MY FEELINGS TOWARDS THEE FOR NEVER DID I MEAN TO NOR COULD I WRONG THEE IN THOUGHT OR DEED
whisper_text: The wounded gentleman opened his all but closed eyes, and recognized in Claudia said, I seek clearly fair and mistaken lady, that it is thou that has slain me, a punishment not merited or deserved by my feelings toward thee. For never did I mean to, nor could I, wrong thee in thought or deed.

text: IT IS NOT TRUE THEN SAID CLAUDIA THAT THOU WERT GOING THIS MORNING TO MARRY LEONORA THE DAUGHTER OF THE RICH BALVASTRO
whisper_text: It is not true then, Zikladia. That thou were going this morning to Mary Leonora, the daughter of the rich Balvestro?

text: AND IF YOU HAVE ANY DESIRE TO SHORTEN THE JOURNEY AND PUT YOURSELF EASILY IN THE WAY OF SALVATION COME WITH ME AND I WILL SHOW YOU HOW TO BECOME A KNIGHT ERRANT A CALLING WHEREIN SO MANY HARDSHIPS AND MISHAPS ARE ENCOUNTERED THAT IF THEY BE TAKEN AS PENANCES THEY WILL LODGE YOU IN HEAVEN IN A TRICE
whisper_text: And if you have any desire to shorten the journey and put yourself easily in the way of salvation, come with me, and I will show you how to become a knight-errant, a calling wherein so many hardships and mishaps are encountered that if they be taken as penances, they will lodge you in heaven in a trice.

whisper_text: Give me my horse and arms, and wait for me here. I will go in quest of this night, and, dead or alive, I will make him keep his word plighted to so great beauty.

whisper_text: One of the squires observed in his mixture of gascon and cattle and this captain of ours would make a better fryer than highwayman. If he wants to be so generous another time, let it be with his own property in not hours.

text: WHO IS TOUCHING ME AND UNTRUSSING ME
